chapter.title: CHAPTER IX
chapter.p: 1BARAITHA. One should not take leave of his teacher or his friend without receiving permission. This rule of good manners all men may learn from the All-present, Who stood at the entrance of the Garden [of Eden] and called to Adam, as it is stated, And the Lord God called unto the man [’Adam], and said unto him: Where art thou?2

One should not be impatient during his meal. It is reported of Hillel that once a man came to have a meal with him, when a poor person arrived and, standing at the door of his house, said to his wife, ‘I am to be married today and I have no food’. She took the entire meal and gave it to him. Then she went and kneaded fresh dough, cooked another meal and came in and placed it before them. [Hillel] said to her, ‘My dear, why did you not bring this sooner?’ She told him what had happened; whereupon he said, ‘My dear, I did not judge you in the scale of guilt but in the scale of merit, because all your deeds are for the sake of Heaven’.

Let all persons always be in your eyes as robbers, but honour each with the respect due to Rabban Gamaliel.3 It is related of R. Joshua that he extended hospitality [to all]. A man arrived to whom he gave food and drink, took up to the attic and then removed the ladder from under him. What did the man do? He arose in the middle of the night, spread out his cloak, took the vessels [belonging to the room] which he wrapped in his cloak and was about to descend when he fell and broke his collar-bone. In the morning R. Joshua came and, finding him [on the ground], said to him, ‘You worthless person, do men act like you?’ He replied, ‘I did not know that you had removed the ladder from under me’. He said to him, ‘Were you not aware that we were on our guard against you since yesterday?’

Guests who are received in a house should do whatever the host bids them do. It is related of Simeon b. Anṭipaṭros that once guests came to him and he bade them eat and drink; but they, vowing and swearing in the name of the Torah, [declined to do so]. When they were about to depart, he administered to them forty lashes. On hearing of this, the Sages were angered4 by the incident and asked, ‘Who will find out for us why he did this?’ R. Joshua said to them, ‘I will go’. They said, ‘Go in peace’. He went and found [Simeon] sitting at the door of his house, and said to him, ‘Peace be upon you’, to which he answered, ‘Come in peace’, and asked him, ‘Is there anything you want?’ He replied, ‘A place to lodge’. [He said to him, ‘Sit down in peace’.]5 The two of them sat down and occupied themselves with the study of the Torah until the evening. [In the morning he said to him,]6 ‘Do you wish that we go to the bath-house?’ He replied, ‘As you wish’. [Simeon] said to him, ‘Sit down’, and he sat. As time went on, R. Joshua was afraid lest he would beat him upon his shoulders. [After they had finished eating and drinking,]7 he said to [Simeon], ‘Who will accompany me?’ He replied, ‘I will’.8 Now R. Joshua was turning things over in his mind, saying to himself, ‘What answer shall I give to the scholars who sent me?’ He turned round and [Simeon] asked him [55a], ‘Why have you turned round?’ ‘There is something which I must ask you’, he said. ‘Why do you beat men who come to you, but me you have not beaten?’ He answered, ‘Rabbi, you are a great scholar and possessed of good manners. When men come to me I bid them eat and drink, but they vow by the Torah [that they will not eat] and later break9 the vow; and I have heard from the Sages that he who makes a vow and breaks it is liable to receive lashes’. He replied, ‘I command you that you should give them twice forty [lashes], forty for me and forty for you’. R. Joshua then went and reported to the Sages what he had seen in connection with the son of Anṭipaṭros.

GEMARA. ‘Let all persons always be suspect in your eyes as robbers.’ But it is not so! For we have learnt:10 Do not judge thy fellow-man until thou art come to his place. There is no contradiction: the latter [refers to a man] whom you know and the other11 when he is unknown. Raba said: In one passage ‘persons’ is used and in the other ‘thy fellow-man’. Since [in Aboth the word used is ḥaberka],12 it clearly speaks of one who is known to him, but is the term ‘all persons’ [used in the Baraitha] not to include a ḥaber?13 No;14 the one is [to be explained] in its own way and the other in its own way.15

‘Guests who are received.’ But it is not so! For we have learnt:16 R. Eliezer [b. Jacob] said: Also he who wishes to subject his friend to a vow to eat with him should declare, ‘Every vow which I will make shall be null’. But perhaps these men [who visited Simeon b. Anṭipaṭros] annulled their vow and yet he beat them when they were about to leave! There is no one who accepts the view of R. Eliezer b. Jacob. Further, there17 it is the host who makes the vow, but here18 it is the guest as is evidenced by the words, ‘Whatever the host bids them do’.19

‘When they were about to depart, he administered to them forty lashes.’ Infer from this that the halakah is according to the view of R. Judah who said: One liable to flagellation is given forty [lashes] in full!20 Raba said: [The Baraitha] uses colloquial language.21 And as for R. Judah, does he not respect the prohibitory law,22 as well as the law derived from the words, If the wicked man deserve to be beaten?23 He will reply, ‘The extra lash is administered between his shoulders’.
chapter.ftnote: (1) This Baraitha is derived mainly from DER VI.
(2) Gen. III, 9. God was about to part from Adam (cf. ibid. 24).

(3) A Patriarch of Palestine and eminent teacher (1st cent. C.E.) of whom it was said, ‘When he died the honour of the Torah ceased, and purity and piety became extinct’ (Soṭah IX, 15, Sonc. ed., p. 266).
(4) Or, according to H’s reading, ‘puzzled’.
(5) Added by H.
(6) Added by H.
(7) So H. V reads: ‘he eventually parted from him in peace’, which is clearly out of place.
(8) Again V inserts wrongly, ‘eventually he went away in peace’.
(9) Reading with H mebaddin for V’s menaddin.
(10) Aboth II, 5 (Sonc. ed., II, 4, p. 14).
(11) In the Baraitha.
(12) Which also means ‘thy companion’. The translation which follows is based on the reading of H, who corrects לא in V to ליה.
(13) Even when one knows him. Ḥaber is used here in the sense of ‘scholar’, who is above suspicion.
(14) Such an inference is not to be drawn.
(15) A ḥaber, whether known to you or not, should not be suspected; but one who cannot be described as a ḥaber is to be suspected.
(16) Ned. 23a (Sonc. ed., p. 67).
(17) In the quotation from Ned.
(18) In the Baraitha.
(19) How was the guest to know beforehand what the host would bid him do? We are therefore not afraid lest the guest annulled the vow beforehand.

(20) Cf. Mak. 22a-23a (Sonc. ed., pp. 155-162). Whereas Deut. XXV, 2f., prescribes forty lashes, according to the Rabbis only thirty-nine were given as a precaution against the forty being inadvertently exceeded. R. Judah’s opinion was otherwise.
(21) i.e. people speak of ‘forty stripes’ when in fact they mean thirty-nine; therefore no inference can be drawn.
(22) In Deut. XXV, 3, Forty stripes he may give him, he shall not exceed.

(23) ibid. 2. The Heb. is בן הכות, which is read as בין, ‘between’ the shoulders. The thirty-nine lashes were divided into three groups of thirteen, administered first on the front of the man’s exposed body, and the remaining two groups on each shoulder respectively. Cf. Mak. 22b (Sonc. ed., p. 158).

chapter.title: CHAPTER X
chapter.p: BARAITHA.1 How does one dance2 before the bride? Beth Shammai said: The bride as she is; and Beth Hillel said: Beautiful and graceful bride!3 Beth Shammai said to Beth Hillel: Even if she is lame or blind? But it is written, Keep thee far from a false matter!4 Beth Hillel replied: If one has made a bad purchase, should one esteem it in his eyes or depreciate it? Surely one should esteem it in his eyes. Therefore Beth Hillel said: Always should the disposition of a man be pleasant towards his fellow-creatures.

GEMARA. But how can Beth Hillel [say of a bride] that she is beautiful when in fact she is not? [Beth Hillel can reply that in the circumstances people will understand it as] beautiful in her deeds and graceful in her person because we do not presume [to attribute to a person] what is unbecoming. And [what can] Beth Shammai [reply to this]? They can say: Is it written, ‘Keep far from a falsehood’? [It is written, From a false] matter,5 even if it be inexplicit.6 And [what can] Beth Hillel [reply to this]? They can say: When the All-present declared, Keep thee far from a false matter, it is in connection with what follows, And the innocent and righteous slay thou not;7 but where it is a case of preserving life8 it is in order [to depart from the strict truth]. Should the question be raised: Why do Beth Hillel in their refutation cite the example of ‘a bad purchase’, let them refute Beth Shammai from the Torah! For it has been taught:9 Great is peace, seeing that for its sake the Holy One, blessed be He, modified a statement. At first it is written, My lord being old,10 and afterwards, I … who am old.11 [Beth Hillel] can reply: There is no question [that what we say] is correct according to the Torah, but it is also correct by the standard of human beings; reverse it.12

[It was quoted above:] And the innocent and righteous slay thou not. Since you mention the innocent [may not be slain], obviously the righteous [may not]!13 [It denotes] ‘innocent because of witnesses’ and ‘righteous because of disciples’.14 From this we learn [the ruling]: Do not put to death ‘the innocent because of witnesses’ and ‘the condemned because of disciples’. [Do you think,] ‘Condemned because of disciples’? Say, because of one of the disciples.15

Raba expounded: What is the meaning of what is written, For the Lord is righteous, He loveth righteousness; the upright shall behold His face?16 If so, [the verse should read,] ‘He loveth the righteous’!17 But [it is to be understood] as Raba interpreted it:18 Abraham19 comes and brings [redemption to the wicked who are under sentence to suffer in Gehinnom, in agreement with] Resh Laḳish [who said: The fire of Gehinnom has no power over the transgressors in Israel,] or it may be deduced by an argument from minor to major [from the golden altar], as it is stated, Every one that is written unto life in Jerusalem.20

BARAITHA. One should not be joyous when in the presence of those who weep, or weep in the presence of those who rejoice. One should not be awake among those who sleep or asleep among those who are awake.

GEMARA. On what grounds does the Baraitha first teach, ‘One should not be joyous’? Let it first teach, ‘Or weep’, etc.! Firstly, because one should not begin with unfortunate circumstances,21 but on the contrary, priority should be given to the majority.22 [The Baraitha] follows the teaching of Solomon [who wrote], It is better to go to the house of mourning, than to go to the house of feasting.23 Here is an additional proof: [The Baraitha] reads, ‘One should not be joyous’ and not ‘One should not make merry’, and then ‘or weep’ and not ‘be serious’.24
BARAITHA. One should not be impatient at meals.

GEMARA. One should not be [impatient] at meals; [is it then to be inferred from this] that in giving an exposition [of Torah], in studying and in other matters one may be [impatient]? Did not Beth Hillel cite this and say to Shammai, ‘Although you are hot-tempered and consequently overawe your fellow-beings, yet do not display impatience [towards the members of your household]25 lest you hinder them from performing good deeds’?

26It once happened that two27 men made a wager with each other, saying, ‘He who goes and makes Hillel angry shall receive four hundred zuz’. Said one, ‘I will go and incense him’.28 That day was the Sabbath-eve, and Hillel was washing his head. He went, passed by the door of his house and called out, ‘Is Hillel here, is Hillel here?’28a Thereupon he robed and went out to him, saying, ‘My son, what do you require?’ ‘I have a question to ask,’ he said. ‘Ask, my son,’ he prompted. Thereupon he asked, ‘Why are the heads of the Babylonians29 round?’ ‘My son, you have asked a great question,’ replied he; ‘because they have no skilful midwives.’ He departed, tarried a while, returned and called out, ‘Is Hillel here, is Hillel here?’ He robed and went out to him, saying, ‘My son, what do you require?’ ‘I have a question to ask,’ said he. ‘Ask, my son,’ he prompted. Thereupon he asked, ‘Why are the eyes of the Palmyreans bleared?’ ‘My son, you have asked a great question,’ replied he; ‘because they live in sandy places.’ He departed, tarried a while, returned and called out, ‘Is Hillel here, is Hillel here?’ He robed and went out to him, saying, ‘My son, what do you require?’ ‘I have a question to ask,’ said he. ‘Ask, my son,’ he prompted. He asked, ‘Why are the feet of the Africans wide?’ ‘My son, you have asked a great question,’ said he; ‘because they live in watery marshes.’30 ‘I have many questions to ask,’ said he, ‘but fear that you may become angry.’ Thereupon he robed, sat before him and said, ‘Ask all the questions you have to ask’. ‘Are you the Hillel who is called the Nasi’ of Israel?’ ‘Yes,’ he replied. ‘If that is so,’ he retorted, ‘may there not be many like you in Israel.’ ‘Why, my son?’ queried he. ‘Because I have lost four hundred zuz through you,’ complained he. ‘Be careful of your moods,’ he answered, ‘Hillel is worth it that you should lose four hundred zuz and yet another four hundred zuz through him, yet Hillel shall not lose his temper.’

31It once happened that R. ‘Aḳiba, accompanied by an Athenian, went on a journey and chanced to stay with a Gentile. He prepared for them four beds, laid an abundant meal before them and gave them wine to drink. They said, ‘We discern that this wine [has the flavour of]the dead’. He brought them meat and they said, ‘This meat is dog’s flesh’. He brought them pickle and they said, ‘It contains urine’. He brought them mustard and they said, ‘It contains beetles’. [The host] went to the tavern-keeper and asked, ‘What happened to the wine?’ He replied, ‘Nothing’. He said, ‘I adjure you to tell me’. He replied, ‘The wine comes from my father’s vineyard where he is buried’. He went to the butcher who told him, ‘It was the meat of a lamb whose dam died and I made her suck from a bitch’. He went to the pickle-maker who told him, ‘One night I was drunk and [my family] locked me in. I wanted to pass water but was unable to go out, so I opened this [jar of pickle] and poured the urine into it’. He went to the mustard-maker who told him, ‘One night I left [the mustard] uncovered and beetles got into it’. He then took the trouble to prepare [another] meal for them. They said one to another, ‘We notice that the host’s legs are like those of a clown’. The host overheard this and said [to himself], ‘Perhaps these men speak the truth’. So he pretended to be very ill and people came to visit him. He said to his mother, ‘If you disclose to me the name of my father I will recover’. She told him, but he said to her, ‘You are telling a lie’. Since she noticed that he was grieved she said to him, ‘My son, once my husband brought a clown to me; I misconducted myself with him and conceived you’. He went and embraced them, bowed to them and exclaimed, ‘In truth you are the people of the Holy God’. This is what Solomon said, For in much wisdom is much vexation; and he that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow.32

33A man once entered a school and said to a child, ‘Take this money and bring me something of which we can eat our fill and leave some over to take home’. He brought him salt and said to him, ‘Sir, you may eat your fill and leave some over to take home’.

BARAITHA.34 A man should not eat leek or onion from its top but from the leaves; and if he did eat [in that manner] he is a glutton. A man should not eat using all his fingers because he has the appearance of a glutton; nor should one put his hand into his mouth.
GEMARA. Raba said: This35 applies only during the meal but not after it. Why? Because he may be delicate.36
BARAITHA. He should only fill his cup with as much as it is his intention [to drink].

GEMARA. What is the reason? Because of the ‘remnants’.37 For the master said: All the ‘remnants’ of cups make one dull except the ‘remnants’ of the Habdalah.38 One who drinks ‘remnants’ for forty [days] will not survive.

BARAITHA. One should not take a potsherd which is full to the brim and drink from it so as not to offend fastidious persons. One should not handle a vessel with greasy fingers; nor should one blow on water and drink it for two [reasons].39
GEMARA. The Rabbis have taught:40 There are three whose life is not life, viz. the [over-] compassionate, the hot-tempered and the fastidious. R. Joseph said: All these [qualities] are found in me.

[It is written,] All the days of the poor are evil—this refers to a discontented man. But he that is of a merry heart hath a continual feast41—this refers to a contented man.42 Another explanation: All the days of the poor are evil—this refers to the compassionate. But he that is of a merry heart—this refers to the cruel.

Raba expounded:43 Whoever is distinguished by the following three characteristics is certain that he is of the seed of our father Abraham: merciful, bashful and benevolent. This is all right with the benevolent, for it is written, Thou wilt show faithfulness to Jacob, mercy to Abraham;44 also bashful, as Raba interpreted: Behold now, I know that thou art a fair woman to look upon;45 but why merciful? Abraham had no mercy upon his son!46 Herein is to be found the greatness of Abraham, to make known how great was his love for the Holy One, blessed be He.47

BARAITHA.48 One should not move a piece of bread across the plate or wipe the plate with it. He should not drink from his cup and pass it to his friend; nor should he bite into the bread and pass it to his friend unless he knows his friend’s mind [that he does not object]. Five things have been said in connection with bread:49 [Raw meat should not be placed on bread, or a cup of wine on bread, or a plate on bread. Bread should not be thrown about, and one should not sit on articles of food].

GEMARA. Raba said: A piece of bread should not be placed on a book or a book on a piece of bread; a book should not be rested against a piece of bread or a piece of bread against a book. If it was his intention to recite Ḳiddush over it, he may not put it in an unclean place.
BARAITHA. A man should not send to his fellow a cask of water50 as oil.

GEMARA. What is the reason? It is forbidden to do anything which may give him offence; as it is written, Nor put a stumbling-block before the blind.51 The question was asked: May one send to a Gentile a thigh which has been cooked with the sinew?52 It is obvious that [one may not send to a Gentile] a limb cut from a living animal, for the master said:53 The sons of Noah54 were forbidden to eat a limb cut from a living animal; therefore [one who sent a Gentile meat with the sinew of the thigh would commit an offence] because of Nor put a stumbling-block before the blind. But here [with the sinew of the thigh] they were not [forbidden and a violation of the law would not arise]; or perhaps there is a difference between the two cases! Come and hear:54a A man may send to a Gentile a thigh wherein is the sinew.
BARAITHA.55 A man may not say to his fellow, ‘Take oil from the jar when it is [in fact] empty’.

GEMARA. He who steals the mind56 of his fellow is as though he deceived the All-present, because the Torah decreed that the robber must pay in full57 for the theft, but the thief must pay twofold in the case of articles, fourfold in the case of sheep, but fivefold in the case of cattle.58 Why [the difference]? Because the All-merciful showed consideration [to the thief for his trouble].
BARAITHA. A man should not eat [his breakfast] until four hours [of the day],59 or drink until four hours.

GEMARA. But it is not so! Did not Raba say to Rabbah b. Mari:60 Whence can the popular saying be derived, ‘Sixty runners may pursue him who has an early meal in the morning and will not overtake him’? And the Rabbis said: Have early breakfast in the summer because of the heat and in winter because of the cold! There it speaks of the morning meal [which is light], but here it deals with a heavy meal.
BARAITHA. A man should bathe at61 four hours.
GEMARA. This is an unnecessary statement.62

BARAITHA. When his cup is filled,63 he should pause in drinking it.64 How many [pauses]? If [it is mixed] with warm water, he should pause three times; if with cold, four times, so that [it is equivalent to] his having been given four cups.
GEMARA. But it says four!65 This refers to when the cup is mixed with warm water.66

BARAITHA. When about to enter the bath-house how should a man act? He says,67 ‘May it be Thy will, O Lord my God, that Thou bring me in in peace and bring me out in peace. Do Thou save me from this and similar [dangers] in the future and may no mishap befall me; and if it does, may my death be an atonement for all my sins’. Before entering and after he has recited the prayer, he takes off his shirt, loosens his girdle, removes his hat and then slips off his undergarment. It is similar with the [removal of the] tefillin: first he removes the phylactery of the head and then the phylactery of the hand.68

GEMARA. From this you may deduce that there is no sanctity attached to the hat.69 This applies only to the hat but not to the turban,70 as it is written, The counsel [sod] of the Lord is with them that fear Him [yere’aw].71

Why does the Baraitha use the verb ‘says’ and not ‘makes the benediction’:72 ‘May it be Thy will, O Lord my God, to deliver me from this and similar [dangers] in the future’; and when leaving he says, ‘Lord of the universe! I thank Thee for that Thou hast delivered me from sinking in the water73 and from being burnt by fire.74 May it be Thy will to deliver me from anything similar in the future’? [The Baraitha] is concerned with right conduct75 and not with the benedictions [to be recited]. But what about the following which is learnt at the end of the chapter:76 One who enters a privy says, “Be honoured [ye honoured and holy beings who minister to the Most High! Give glory to our God, remain in your place, be mindful, help me, guard me, wait for me until I shall have entered and left; for what I am doing is the way of men”]’? There it is not a case of a ‘benediction’, for the master said:77 If he wrapped himself in a ṭallith with fringes attached, he leaves it in the corner and he has no need to recite a prayer. Why, then, [does it continue with: One who leaves a privy says,] ‘Blessed be … Who hast formed man in wisdom’?78 While it deals with the one, it also [takes the opportunity] to deal with the other.
BARAITHA. One who enters the bath-house should not exercise himself,79 or scrape himself on the marble [slab], or have his limbs broken.80

GEMARA. What is the meaning of ‘exercise himself’? For example, pressing his head between his knees. ‘Or scrape himself’: but it is not so! For [we are informed that] the servant of Raba scraped him! It speaks of scraping with the hand. ‘Or have his limbs broken’; Rabban Gamaliel said: Whoever has his limbs broken on the marble is the companion of an ass.81

BARAITHA. In the bath-house, one who enters gives way to the one who is leaving.82 A man should not greet his friend in the bath-house,83 and if he greets him first he should say to him, ‘This is a bath-house’. One who eats in the street is the companion of a dog.84
GEMARA. This applies to bread and foods which [are eaten to satisfy] one’s hunger, but not to other things.
BARAITHA. A man should not leave oil85 in a glass because of danger.

GEMARA. What [danger] is there? Lest it be broken and endanger [the bathers]. As Samuel said:86 If one bathes without anointing [he is like water poured over a barrel].87 Say,88 ‘And has not anointed himself previously’.

BARAITHA. A man should not spit anywhere in front of his fellow or put his foot on the bath and jump into it, because it may lead to death. He who recites the Shema‘89 twice is reprehensible. So, too, is he reprehensible who immerses twice.90
GEMARA. Lest [the water from his head and beard] drip on to people without their noticing it.91
BARAITHA. If one bathes in hot water and does not slush himself with cold water he robs the public.

GEMARA. How is this? For example, he entered the bath and they brought him warm water, and he slushed himself with it and then went out; in such a case he has robbed the public!92 But should this not be excluded [from the category of robbery] seeing that his bathing is not beneficial to him?93 He warms himself at home; or [the bath-house] is near a river.94
BARAITHA. If one has robbed the public, what should he do [to atone for his sin]?95 He should dig wells, ditches and grottoes, or repair roads and streets; then he will be pardoned.96

GEMARA. In accordance with whose view [is this Baraitha]? R. ‘Aḳiba’s, who said:97 This is not the way that would absolve him from sin unless he pays [the full amount of the robbery] to each person. You might even say that it is in accordance with the view of R. Ṭarfon, because here [the amount] lies before them.98
BARAITHA.99 As for them who write [Torah] scrolls tefillin and mezuzoth, they, their traders and their traders’ traders100 do not see a sign of blessing.
GEMARA. ‘As for them who write scrolls’:101 because they may omit or add a letter.102

We have learnt there:103 If one says, ‘There is no precept of tefillin so that a Biblical law may be transgressed’, he is exempt [from punishment].104 [But if he rules that the phylactery of the head must consist of] five compartments, thus adding to the words of the Sages, he is liable.105 According to whom is this? It is according to R. Simeon who said: [It is written,] For thy love is better than wine:106 [these are the scribes]. Accordingly when the man107 uproots a whole [commandment of the Torah] or a whole verse, he is not liable;108 but where he uproots the law concerning a suspended letter109 or crownlets on letters110 he is liable.111

The Rabbis have taught:112 The [earnings of] writers of scrolls, [the wages of] interpreters,113 money which comes from countries overseas,114 and [the payment of] ḥazzanim115 never see a sign of blessing. ‘The [earnings of] writers of scrolls’: what are these scrolls? The twenty-four books116 if not examined. ‘Interpreters’: because they receive pay for work on the Sabbath. ‘Money which comes from countries overseas’: because a miracle happened.117 ‘And [the payment of] ḥazzanim’: Because [they are engaged] in the work of the Lord. It has been taught:118 They who write scrolls, tefillin and mezuzoth do not see a sign of blessing; but if they engage [in this task] for its own sake,119 they do see [a sign of blessing].
BARAITHA. He who looks to the earnings of his ass or to the earnings of his wife120 does not see a sign of blessing.

GEMARA. What is the reason? Because it is written, A righteous man regardeth the life of his beast:121 a beast does regard the life of a righteous man. ‘The earnings of his wife’: for it is written, [And there will be goat’s milk enough] for thy food, for the food of thy household; and maintenance for thy maidens.122 The Torah teaches that your food comes before the food of your household,123 and then comes the food of your maidens. Raba said: Whoever compels his wife or his household to work, the evil inclination departs from them;124 as it is stated, The wicked flee when no man pursueth; but the righteous are secure as a young lion.125 This conforms to what we learnt:126 Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel said: If a man forbade his wife under a vow to do any work, he must divorce her and give her her kethubah, because idleness leads to idiocy.
BARAITHA.127 He who trades in canes and jars will never see a sign of blessing.
GEMARA. Because [their bulk being large] the [evil] eye has power over them. Therefore128 this applies only to [jars of] oil but not of wine.129

BARAITHA.130 Once R. ‘Aḳiba was sitting and expounding beneath an olive-tree and said: They who breed small cattle,131 they who cut down beautiful trees,132 and they who teach young children but do not do their work conscientiously will not see a sign of blessing.

GEMARA. But it is not so! For R. Ḥanina said:133 If the value [of the tree for other purposes] exceeds that [of its fruit] it is permissible [to cut it down]. There134 it speaks of other kinds of trees and here of olive-trees. Deduce this from what [the Baraitha] teaches, ‘He was sitting beneath an olive-tree’. Why [an olive-tree]? Because the blessing [which it provides] is great and yet the man comes and cuts it down! [I quote against that reasoning] the first clause, ‘They who breed small cattle’! If it is because they are a blessing, why do they not see [a sign of blessing]? The text should read, ‘They who slaughter [small cattle]’.
BARAITHA.135 If he loosened his shoe and went out into the street he is regarded as haughty.

GEMARA. What is he to do? This is what it means to say: If he put on136 his shoe when he went out into the street he is regarded as haughty. Raba said: It is forbidden to bring a haughty man into one’s house; for the Rabbis said:137 Any man in whom is haughtiness of spirit will in the end stumble through an [unfaithful] married woman, as it is stated, Every one that is proud in heart is an abomination to the Lord.138 Even if he be learned in the Torah like Moses our teacher, he will not be free from the judgment of Gehinnom. As for everyone who is lowly of spirit, the Holy One, blessed be He, will save him from [evil] visitations that come upon the world; as it is stated, For thus saith the High and Lofty One that inhabiteth eternity, whose name is holy: I dwell in the high and holy place, with him also that is of a contrite and humble spirit, to revive the spirit of the humble, and to revive the heart of the contrite ones139 [55b].

(11) ibid. 13. When Sarah was told by the angel that she would have a son she laughed to herself and exclaimed, My lord being old; but when God repeated what she had said to Abraham, not to hurt his feelings He changed the word to I … who am old.

(12) The text should read kelappë ’alyah, lit. ‘towards the tail’, i.e. reverse it, and the word which follows is an explanatory gloss (Jastrow s.v. ’alyah). The meaning is, To meet the question raised, it would be best in the Baraitha first to cite the passage from Genesis and then the example of ‘a bad purchase’.

(13) The term innocent has a negative connotation, viz. one who keeps away from evil; but the term righteous has both a negative and positive connotation, viz. one who keeps away from evil and does good.

(14) These are forensic terms. I. Where two witnesses testify against a man that he had committed an offence but disagree on the details, the accused is discharged. E.g., two witnesses testify that they saw him worshipping idols; one says that he worshipped the sun and the other that it was the moon. Because the witnesses are in disagreement on details, the man is acquitted. He is technically termed naḳi me‘edim, ‘innocent (or, freed) because of [the disagreement of] witnesses’. II. In the criminal court young scholars sat in rows in front of the judges. When the trial ended and before the verdict was delivered, any one of these scholars could, if he knew anything in favour of the accused, come forward and speak for him, and if the judges accepted his statement they discharged the accused. He was then termed ẓaddiḳ min hattalmidim, ‘righteous (i.e. acquitted) because of the disciples’. If the disciple wished to testify against the accused, he was not permitted to do so. That would be a case of rasha‘ min hattalmidim, ‘condemned because of the disciples’, which was not allowed. Cf. Sanh. 33b-34a (Sonc. ed., p. 212) and Rashi ad loc.
(15) This refusal to listen to disciples’ statements against the accused holds good only when one disciple came forward. This procedure is based on Num. XXXV, 30; cf. Sanh. loc. cit.

There is a dispute between R. ‘Aḳiba and R. Ṭarfon. According to the former he has to leave the full amount of the robbery with every one of the persons involved; but R. Ṭarfon holds the view that he has to leave the amount of the robbery with the five claimants and withdraw.
(98) Every one of them can make use of the public facilities which the robber provided.
(100) i.e. all who trade with them directly or indirectly.
(101) V inserts: ‘Tosiftha, end of tractate Bikkurim’, a marginal note which was included in the text.

(102) Cf. ‘Erub. 13a (Sonc. ed., p. 81), R. Ishmael’s injunction to R. Meir, who was a scribe, ‘Be meticulous in your work, because your occupation is sacred; should you perchance omit or add one letter, you would thereby destroy all the universe’.

(104) Since all people know that the Torah commands the donning of tefillin.
(105) Because not everyone is aware of the rule that it must have four compartments.
(106) Cant. I, 2. In the Heb. the word for love is plural and interpreted by R. Simeon in the sense of ‘beloved men’, i.e. the scribes and scholars who are beloved of God.

(113) Officials who delivered the Sabbath lecture to the congregation. The Rabbi whispered his statements to the interpreter, who explained them to the people. The term may also denote those who translated the reading of the Torah in the service into Aramaic for the understanding of the congregation.
(114) Danger was involved in the transport of goods by sea and there was the risk of loss.
(115) Functionaries who combined the offices of supervisor of children’s studies in the Synagogue, beadle, court crier and janitor. Cf. Shab. 11a (Sonc. ed., p. 41, n. 7).
(116) On the number of the books of the Bible, cf. L. Blau, Zur Einleitung in die Heilige Schrift, pp. 6ff.
(117) And miracles do not happen every day; Pes. 50b (Sonc. ed., p. 240).
(118) Pes. loc. cit.
(119) i.e. their aim is to be of service to the community, profit being a secondary consideration.
(120) Pes. loc. cit. (Sonc. ed., p. 245).
(121) Prov. XII, 10.
(122) ibid. XXVII, 27.
(123) In Rabbinic phraseology the Biblical term ‘house’ is equated with one’s wife; cf. Yoma 2a (Sonc. ed., p. 1).
(124) Being fully occupied, they will have no time to indulge in wrong.
(125) Prov. XXVIII, 1.
(126) Keth. 59b (Sonc. ed., p. 353).
(128) Reading with H hilkak instead of V’s hilketha’.
(129) Presumably jars of wine were smaller than jars of oil.
(130) Pes. loc. cit.
(131) e.g. sheep and goats.
(132) To dispose of them for timber.
(134) In the statement of R. Ḥanina.

(135) Cf. DER XI, p. 565. The reading in the Baraitha must have been originally ‘if his shoe fell off and he went out’. Hence the point of the question in the Gemara: ‘What is he to do?’ His haughtiness is displayed in his desire to be different from others.

chapter.title: INTRODUCTION
chapter.p: Derek ’Ereẓ is the title of two tractates: Rabbah (the large) and Zuṭa (the small). They consist mainly of moral and ethical teachings. Contrary to what we might expect, they are not larger and shorter divisions of the same treatise, but independent works with but little in common. Consequently, the terms Rabbah and Zuṭa cannot have been parts of the original titles.

Many passages in Derek ’Ereẓ are to be found, with slight variations, in the Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmuds. For other sayings, however, no source is found in Rabbinic literature. This would indicate that these collections of Baraithoth belong mainly to the period of the Tannaïm. Subsequently, additions were made to the original text, since the tractates include dicta from much later authorities.

Among the early authorities the treatises were known as Hilkoth (the laws of) D.E., Masseketh (tractate) D.E., Middoth (rules of) D.E., Pirḳë (chapters of) D.E., Mishnath (the Mishnah of) D.E., or simply Derek ’Ereẓ. In the current editions printed in the Talmud, the tractates Rabbah and Zuṭa each consists of eleven chapters, several in the former being somewhat longer than in the latter. The text for the present translation follows in the main that of the Wilna-Romm edition; but note has been taken of the most important variants found in MSS. and other printed editions, some of which have been adopted in the translation, with explanations in the notes. Constant reference has also been made to the variant readings and emendations of the Wilna Gaon (GRA), as well as other commentaries printed in the same edition of the Talmud.

The term Derek ’Ereẓ signifies ‘good manners, propriety, correct behaviour, refinement, etiquette’. These have always been regarded as most important in Jewish life. Already in the Bible many instances are recorded of good manners and correct conduct. To quote but a few: the filial love and respect shown by Shem and Japheth in covering the nakedness of their father, Noah; Abraham waiving his right as the elder and allowing his nephew, Lot, to choose the land he desired; Abraham’s hospitality to the angels; Rebekah’s kindness to Eliezer and his camels; the gallantry displayed by Moses in helping Jethro’s daughters, which may serve as an instance of respect towards women; the command to rise before the aged and honour the elder; the duty to assist the poor with interestfree loans; the precept of humanitarianism and charitableness towards an enemy and his animals; the laws guaranteeing civil, moral and religious rights to the stranger and proselyte; and the exhortation to avoid personal and moral pollution by keeping the camp holy.

The first two chapters were also known under the title Tractate ‘Arayoth (prohibited marriages). According to the Wilna Gaon, they do not belong here but to Kallah. Several MSS., indeed, begin DER at the third chapter, and in them the whole work is entitled Pereḳ Ben ‘Azzai from the opening words. The author of the Maḥzor Viṭri (who was a disciple of Rashi) makes this tractate begin with the fourth chapter. Both these variants are noted in the current editions printed in the Talmud.

In Coronel’s edition of Ḥamishshah Ḳunṭrasim (1864) we find many passages in Kallah which are more suitable in Derek ’Ereẓ. Hence both these tractates may have been compiled about the same time, some passages becoming misplaced. In the view of Coronel there was also a Gemara attached to this tractate (as with Kallah Rabbathi) which antedated the redaction of the Talmud. But from a study of the language and style of the last-named it would seem to belong to a later period.

The first chapter was probably a separate work. It deals with marriages which are forbidden on account of consanguinity and concludes with some ethical maxims on the subject of marriage. The second chapter, too, may have been a separate collection, because its subject-matter is entirely different from the first. It contains reflections on twelve classes of persons who are to be condemned and twelve who are to be commended, with Biblical texts appropriate to each. Then comes a list of sins which bring about the eclipse of the heavenly luminaries and other misfortunes, and the chapter ends with some mystic remarks on God and Israel and the three hundred and ninety heavens.

The following chapters, much of whose contents is also found in ARN, consist of ethical, moral and social teachings generally expressed in pithy sentences, arranged in the style of the Pirḳë Aboth, except that they are anonymous. They conclude with a list of occupations which are to be avoided, followed by a collection of liturgical prayers for special occasions.

h1.small: DATE OF COMPOSITION AND THE TEXT

chapter.p: As already stated, the nucleus of the tractate was composed in the Tannaitic period, to which were added teachings of the early ’Amoraïm. Not only is the meaning of some passages so obscure that we must assume that obvious errors must have crept in, but some passages are clearly out of place. The current text is often corrupt. There are MSS. and editions of both Rabbah and Zuṭa which contain numerous variations both in text and order. Rabbi Dr. M. Higger, in his edition (New York, 1935), lists the most important of these differences.

The following reasons may be suggested as accounting for these variations. We must recognize a distinction between literature in the strict sense, i.e. a work composed in accordance with literary rules and conventions, and a compilation which was intended for oral transmission and only later reduced to writing. Each has its own characteristics. Oral tradition tends to develop certain peculiarities to aid the memory; e.g. the grouping together in convenient summaries of ten, seven, five or three; the juxtaposition of certain laws or sayings which have a common catchword.

With literary composition of the strict kind, on the other hand, the logical connection is the rule to be followed. From the Rabbinic dictum, ‘The words transmitted orally thou art not at liberty to recite from writing’ (Giṭ. 60b, Sonc. ed., p. 284), some scholars have inferred that no records of the oral Torah existed before the fifth century C.E., the great mass of rulings and opinions which developed through the centuries being retained in the Schools entirely without the aid of writing. But this view is based on a misinterpretation of the passage. It only means that the oral Torah may not be committed to writing to be used as textbooks in the Schools.

The objection to committing the oral Torah to writing arose from the fear that it might become confused with, and be given the same authority as, the text of the Torah. But the teachers must have possessed much material in written form, and no doubt prepared their lectures from collections of this kind, treating them, however, for reference only and not as textbooks. They were not allowed to read their lecture from MS., to avoid creating the impression that the discourse carried the same authority as the Scriptures. Even Rabbi Judah the Prince, who, as many maintain, wrote down the Mishnah, as did R. ‘Aḳiba and R. Meir before him in their codifications, intended it to be a work of reference and not a textbook.

Teaching continued to be oral and from memory until the sixth century, when new conditions demanded a change in method. The material was by that time too vast to be retained by memory only. The existence of the Academies was threatened by persecution, and it was resolved to reduce to definitive form all that had hitherto been preserved orally.

If errors could creep into halakic (legal) material, as we find, though great care must have been taken against this happening, how much more so with a subject like Derek ’Ereẓ, especially if it was committed to writing only after a lapse of time! Whereas with halakah notes of legal decisions might have been sufficient to aid one’s memory, with Derek ’Ereẓ the need was felt to have fuller notes, perhaps for the guidance of one’s family circle. In such a collection errors inevitably crept into the text, either from lapse of memory or through copyists’ mistakes.
[In the Talmud editions the chapters are not subdivided into paragraphs and numbered, but for the sake of convenience this is done in the translation according to Higger’s edition.]
M.GINSBERG.

chapter.title: DEREK ’EREẒ RABBAH
CHAPTER I
chapter.p: When a man betroths1 a woman, he debars himself from [marrying] seven blood relations, viz.: her mother, her mother’s mother, her father’s mother, her daughter, her son’s daughter, her daughter’s daughter and her sister while she herself is alive.2 In all these who are prohibited to him, the interdict is never lifted except in the case of his wife’s sister who is forbidden to him only during her lifetime;3 and never does he disqualify his wife [from cohabitation with him] through [his intercourse] with her mother, her daughter or her sister.4

If [after betrothal the woman] was raped, she is permitted to him,5 but should she have been a willing party she is forbidden to him. If she is the wife of a kohen, she is forbidden to him whether [it happened] under force or with her consent. [For it is stated, And she be not seized6—[only then] is she forbidden; if, however, she was seized7 she is permitted. There is another class of woman who is forbidden [to her husband] even though she had been seized; and who is that? The wife of a kohen.8 R. Ishmael9 said: And she be not seized she is forbidden; consequently if she had been seized she is permitted. There is another class of woman who is permitted [to her husband] even if she had not been seized; and who is that? A woman whose betrothal was mistaken.10]

If a divorcee who became betrothed was seduced, whether under force or of her free will, she is forbidden to return to her former husband.11 This is the opinion of R. Jose b. Ḳippar in the name of R. Eleazar b. Shammua‘. This is the reasoning by which R. Jose b. Ḳippar expounded his view:12 [It is written,] Her former husband, who sent her away, may not take her again to be his wife, after that she is defiled.13 In what circumstances did she become defiled?14 It can only be explained by what the Sages have said: If a woman [after betrothal] was forcibly seduced, she is permitted to [her husband]; if she was a willing party she is forbidden to him; but in this case,15 whether under compulsion or of her free will she is forbidden to return to her former husband.16

17 None of the women forbidden to him on account of incest requires a geṭ from him if he married any of them18 except his wife’s sister,19 his brother’s wife20 and a married woman,21 because these have a termination to their prohibition.22

The following exposition was given by R. Ḥanina b. Uri before [a gathering of] the Sages in the name of R. Nathan: Anyone who is included in the category Shall not enter [into the assembly of the Lord]23 disqualifies a woman by his cohabitation24 and disqualifies the child.25 They are: an Ammonite,26 Moabite,27 Egyptian,28 Idumean,29 slave, bastard, nathin,30 Samaritan31 and a ḥalal.32 The daughter of a ḥalal is fit33 although [her father] is within [the category of] shall not enter.34

If a man had intercourse with any of the women prohibited to him as forbidden relatives, he is still permitted to marry her near relatives.35 [For instance,] he who had intercourse with a married woman is permitted to marry her daughter.

This is the question which R. Jose b. Taddai of Tiberias put to Rabban Gamaliel: If I, who may cohabit with my wife, am prohibited from marrying her daughter, how much more should I be prohibited from marrying the daughter of a married woman, seeing that I am prohibited from cohabiting with her!36 He replied to him: Go and provide me [a wife] for the High Priest of whom it is written, A virgin of his own people shall he take to wife,37 and I will provide you [with wives] for Israel.38 Another explanation39 [in refutation of the reasoning is that] we do not use an a fortiori argument to abrogate a specific law of Scripture.40 Rabban Gamaliel excommunicated him.41

If a man cohabits with any woman forbidden him as incest, he does not thereby disqualify her from marrying a kohen.42 [If a kohen cohabits with his wife when she is] niddah, although he is liable to a penalty for the intercourse,43 the child [who is conceived] is qualified to stand and offer sacrifices upon the altar.44

A woman who had intercourse with that which is not a human being,45 although she is in consequence subject to the penalty of kareth,46 she is not disqualified from marrying a kohen. R. Jose said: It once happened at Haitali47 that while a young woman was cleaning the floor48 a gorilla49 came and covered her from the rear. When the case came before the Sages, they did not disqualify her from marrying a kohen.

The following are the forbidden relatives in the second degree: his father’s mother, his mother’s mother,50 the wife of his mother’s father, the wife of his father’s father,51 the wife of his son’s son, the wife of his daughter’s son, the wife of a father’s maternal brother, the wife of a mother’s paternal brother. Bar Ḳappara adds the mother of his father’s father and the mother of his mother’s father. The wife of his father’s brother is forbidden to him52 but the daughter [his cousin] is permitted to him; his father’s brother is permitted to marry his53 wife or his daughter; the wife of his mother’s brother is forbidden to him but his daughter is permitted to him. His mother’s brother is permitted to marry [the nephew’s] wife or daughter.

A man is permitted to marry the wife of his father-in-law54 and the wife of his son-in-law, but the Sages said that the wife of his father-in-law is not permitted to him because of appearance’s sake; [the mother-in-law’s] daughter is permitted to him.55 A man may not marry the daughter of his stepson,56 but [the stepson’s] wife is permitted to him. His stepson is permitted to marry [the stepfather’s] wife and daughter. A man may marry the wife of his brother’s son and the wife of his sister’s son.57

If a man remarried his divorced wife after her marriage [with a second husband who subsequently died or divorced her], he may not cohabit with her, neither may a levir marry her [if her husband died childless].58 The wife of a fit man who has a brother who is crushed in his privy parts59 is permitted to her husband but is prohibited to the levir.60 The rival61 of a soṭah is permitted to her husband but forbidden to the levir.62

A man who married a sister of his brother’s divorced wife or a sister of his brother’s ḥaluẓah, [though this sister] is permitted to her husband she is forbidden to the levir [if her husband died childless].

The wife of a man crushed in his privy parts who has a fit brother, though forbidden to her husband,63 is permitted to the levir. A soṭah is forbidden both to the husband and to the levir.64 A ḥaluẓah is likewise forbidden to both. The wife of a man crushed in his privy parts whose brother is similarly maimed is forbidden to both.

A female proselyte, captive woman, freed woman,65 the widow of one who was of mixed family,66 a soṭah, [56a] ḥaluẓah, divorcee and a ḥalalah are unfit to marry a kohen. If they were married to a lay-Israelite, the daughters [of the union] are fit to marry a kohen.67

He who cohabits with a maidservant is liable to the penalty for transgressing fourteen negative commands and also to the penalty of kareth at the hand of Heaven, viz.: Thou shalt not let thy cattle gender with a diverse kind;68 Thou shalt not sow thy field with two kinds of seed;69 Neither shall there come upon thee a garment of two kinds of stuff mingled together;70 Thou shalt not sow thy vineyard with two kinds of seed;71 Thou shalt not plough [with an ox and an ass together];72 Thou shalt not wear a mingled stuff;73 Thou shalt not commit adultery;74 Thou shalt not covet;75 And thou shalt not lie with any beast;76 Neither shalt thou profane the name of thy God;77 also one on account of [laws concerning] a non-Jewish maidservant, a harlot, a niddah and a heathen woman. And one punishment of kareth, as it is stated, May the Lord cut off to the man that doeth this him that calleth and him that answereth out of the tents of Jacob, and him that offereth an offering unto the Lord of hosts.78 If he was a lay-Israelite and profaned his seed with a maidservant or a heathen woman, he will have no ‘awakening’79 among the Sages and no ‘responding’ among the disciples. If he was a kohen, he will not have a son that offereth an offering unto the Lord of hosts.

Who marries a wife fitting for him;80 Elijah kisses and the Holy One, blessed be He, loves him; but who takes a wife who is not fitting for him, Elijah binds and the Holy One, blessed be He, lashes him.81 Woe to him who disqualifies his seed, blemishes his family and takes to wife one who is not fit for him. He who is himself unfit [continually] declares [others to be] unfit82 and never speaks well of anybody.83

Abba Hilfai said in the name of his father Abba Ḥagra: Do not be rash in making vows that you may not trespass in the matter of oaths,84 and do not be the guest of a kohen who is an ‘am ha-’areẓ lest he give you consecrated food85 to eat. Do not converse much with women because every conversation with a woman is only about unchastity.86 R. Aḥi of the School87 of R. Josiah said: He who gazes at a woman eventually comes to sin, and he who looks upon a woman’s heel will beget degenerate children,88 and he who has no shamefacedness89 is easily led to sin; as it is stated, The show of their countenance doth witness against them [and they declare their sin as Sodom, they hide it not].90 But he who is shamefaced91 will not easily sin, as it is stated, [And Moses said unto the people, fear not; for God is come to prove you] that His fear may be before your face that ye sin not.92

R. Measha,93 grandson of R. Joshua b. Levi, said: One who looks at a naked part of the body and does not feed his eyes on it94 will merit to receive the Divine Presence; as it is stated, And [he that] shutteth his eyes from looking upon evil,95 and immediately after it is written, He shall dwell on high,96 and it is written, Thine eyes shall see the king in his beauty.97
chapter.ftnote: (1) On the terms ‘betrothal’ and ‘marriage’ in Jewish law, cf. Kallah, p. 401, n. 1.
(2) Cf. Yeb. 40a, b (Sonc. ed., p. 249).
(3) Cf. Lev. XVIII, 18.

(4) The law applies to all the seven relatives. The three are mentioned probably because one might have thought that, on account of their close relationship, his wife would in such a circumstance be forbidden to him. Cf. Yeb. 94b-95a (Sonc. ed., pp. 643ff.).
(5) Cf. Deut. XXII, 23-27.

(6) Num. V, 13, E.V. neither she be taken in the act. The phrase is interpreted by the Rabbis in the sense that she did not act under compulsion but willingly, referring to a married woman who was defiled secretly without witnesses to testify against her.
(7) i.e. violated by force.
(8) Cf. Yeb. 56b (Sonc. ed., p. 378), Keth. 51b (Sonc. ed., p. 298).
(9) According to R. Ishmael there is no distinction between the wife of a kohen and a lay-Israelite in the case of rape.

(10) If, e.g., a condition were attached to the betrothal that remained unfulfilled. In such a case the woman may leave her husband without a geṭ, and in any subsequent intercourse, whether forced or willing, her status is that of an unmarried woman who had never been previously married. The passage within brackets is added by GRA and is necessary, otherwise R. Ishmael would be contradicting himself. Cf. Yeb. 100b (Sonc. ed., p. 692), Keth. loc. cit.

(11) If her second husband subsequently died or divorced her. She is, however, permitted to remarry her former husband after betrothal alone, where no marriage with the second man took place and he died.
(12) This is the reading of GRA as against V and H, who name R. Ishmael as the authority.
(13) Deut. XXIV, 4.
(14) If she was legally married to the second husband the term defiled is inapplicable.
(15) Of the divorcee who became betrothed and was then seduced. This is the reading of GRA. V and H have ‘the wife of a kohen’.
(16) So GRA. V and H ‘to him’.
(17) V and H insert here ‘and this is the reasoning by which R. Jose b. Ḳippar expounded in the name of R. Eleazar b. Shammua‘’.
(18) Such an unlawful marriage is regarded merely as harlotry, and we do not fear lest people infer that a married woman may leave her husband and remarry without a geṭ.
(19) Whom he married after he had been told that his wife, who had gone overseas, was dead.

(20) Whom he married on the evidence that his brother (the woman’s husband) was dead but later returned. The requirement of a divorce in these cases is only a preventive measure against the possibility of assuming that the second marriage was legal, and hence inferring that a married woman may leave her husband to marry another without a geṭ.

(21) Whose husband was reported by one witness to be dead and she remarried with the sanction of a Beth Din who accepted the evidence, and later the husband returned. In such a case the woman requires a divorce from her second husband as a preventive measure against the possibility of assuming that the first had divorced her and the second had married her legally, and consequently a married woman may leave her husband without a geṭ. Cf. Yeb. 94b (Sonc. ed., p. 641).
(22) lit. ‘a permission after their prohibition’; e.g. by the death of his wife, by the death of his brother and by being divorced.
(23) Deut. XXIII, 2-4.
(24) From marrying a kohen or from eating terumah if she was the daughter of a kohen. Cf. Ḳid. 74b (Sonc. ed., pp. 381f.).
(25) From his marriage. Such a child cannot be counted as belonging to the community. The reading of GRA is followed.
(26) Deut. XXIII, 4.
(27) ibid.
(28) ibid. 8f.
(29) ibid.
(30) A descendant of the Gibeonites; cf. Josh. IX, 27.
(31) Cuthean (Samaritan) was probably substituted from fear of the censor for an original goï (heathen).
(32) One unfit for the priesthood on account of his father’s illegitimacy.
(33) To marry even a kohen.

(34) This is in accordance with the opinion of R. Dosethai b. Judah in Ḳid. 77a (Sonc. ed., p. 395), who maintained that as the sons of Israel are a miḳweh of purification for ḥalaloth, so are the daughters a miḳweh of purification for ḥalalim, so that their issue is eligible for the priesthood. The Mishnah (ibid.) states: The daughter of a ḥalal is unfit to the priesthood for all time.
(35) Only relatives of a married wife are subject to the law of incest.
(36) The purpose of this a fortiori argument is to point out that one should not be allowed to marry anyone except the daughter of a widow or of a divorcee, because these are no longer a man’s wife.
(37) Lev. XXI, 14.

(38) Since a High Priest may not marry a widow or a divorcee, their daughters also ought to be prohibited according to R. Jose’s argument, and this would be contrary to the Scriptural text. Hence the reasoning must be fallacious. The premise is false, viz. that he is permitted to cohabit with his wife who was the daughter of a married woman.
(39) The Yalḳuṭ omits the words ‘another explanation’.
(40) It is explicitly stated, He shall take to wife, but if we adopt R. Jose’s argument, a High Priest could never marry.
(41) The Yalḳuṭ omits this sentence.

(42) Cf. Yeb. 61b (Sonc. ed., p. 409) where R. ‘Aḳiba maintains that the term harlot forbidden to a kohen applies only to one who is in fact a prostitute. GRA omits ‘not’. Higger quotes the suggestion of Prof. L. Ginzberg that there is a scribal error through dittography and the text should read: ‘Not only is the child a bastard but he even disqualifies her from marrying a kohen’.
(43) Cf. Lev. XVIII, 19.
(44) The offspring of a forbidden but valid marriage cannot be considered a ḥalal. Cf. Yeb. 60a (Sonc. ed., p. 399).
(45) i.e. an animal; ibid. 59b (Sonc. ed., p. 397).
(46) If the offence was committed in the presence of witnesses after due warning, the penalty is stoning (Lev. XX, 16); in the absence of witnesses and warning, she is under the penalty of kareth.
(47) The Babylonian form of Aitalu, the modern Aiterun, N.W. of Ḳadesh; cf. S. Klein, Beiträge, p. 47.
(48) lit. ‘house’; she must have been kneeling.
(49) In Yeb. loc. cit., ‘a wild dog’.

(50) The Bible only prohibits a man’s mother and the Rabbis extended the prohibition to his mother’s mother on account of his mother. His father’s mother is likewise prohibited as they are both called ‘grand-mothers’.
(51) The previous note applies here mutatis mutandis.
(52) Lev. XVIII, 14.
(53) The nephew’s.
(54) Cf. Yeb. 21a (Sonc. ed., p. 124).
(55) After the death of her sister, his wife.
(56) It is forbidden in Lev. XVIII, 17, and is not an incest of the second degree. It is only included here on account of the clause that follows. Cf. Yeb. loc. cit.

(57) This is a repetition of what is stated above in connection with a nephew’s wife and daughter. [A table of prohibited marriages is provided in Hertz, The Pentateuch and Haftorahs, Leviticus, pp. 186f., Sonc. ed., p. 559.]
(58) So GRA. Cf. Yeb. 11b-12a (Sonc. ed., pp. 57f.).
(59) Deut. XXIII, 2.
(60) If her husband died childless.
(61) Where a husband has more than one wife, each woman is a ‘rival’ in relation to the other.
(62) Both the rival and the soṭah are exempt from the levirate marriage and ḥaliẓah, because a soṭah is in the same category as a forbidden relative.
(63) Cf. Deut. XXIII, 2.
(64) lit. ‘to this one and to that one’.
(65) These are presumed to have had intercourse.

(66) lit. ‘a widow of dough’. ‘Dough’ is a designation for a mixed community or family, i.e. with an admixture of illegitimate persons or persons of doubtful legitimacy. The reference here is to a girl, and not necessarily to a widow of a member, of such a mixed family. This is in accordance with the opinion of Rabban Gamaliel; cf. Keth. 14a (Sonc. ed., p. 76).

Herford, Talmud and Apocrypha, pp. 163ff. [See also Büchler, Types of Jewish-Palestinian Piety, p. 66, n. 2.] The saying is based on Aboth I, 5 (Sonc. ed., p. 4).

chapter.title: CHAPTER II
chapter.p: Concerning Sadducees, informers, the wicked, profaners of God’s Name1 and heretics, Scripture declares, The wicked shall return to the nether-world.
Concerning the overbearing, haughty, proud, violent, insolent and pugnacious, Scripture declares, For the arms of the wicked shall be broken; but the Lord upholdeth the righteous.2

Concerning designers of evil, schemers of [wicked] plans,3 those who spurn with their lips and the smooth-tongued, Scripture declares, Let their way be dark and slippery, the angel of the Lord pursuing them.4

They who smite in secret, openly blaspheme, treat the public with contempt and causers of strife are destined to be like Ḳorah and his assembly, concerning whom Scripture declares, And the earth closed upon them, and they perished from among the assembly.5

Concerning them who hoard fruit,6 raise the prices, make the ephah small and the shekel great7 and lend money on usury, Scripture declares, The Lord hath sworn by the pride of Jacob: Surely I will never forget any of their works.8

The following do not bequeath anything to their children, and if they do bequeath to their children they do not cause their children’s children to inherit: the dice-gambler, the breeder of small cattle,9 one who transacts with money derived from the Sabbatical year,10 one whose money is derived from [transactions] with overseas countries11 and a kohen or Levite who borrowed on their portions.12
Concerning flatterers, liars and workers of iniquity,13 Scripture declares, The wicked shall return to the nether-world,14 and it further states, That which is crooked cannot be made straight.15

Concerning them who moan like a dove,16 who make motions with their hands [when talking],17 click their heels and walk on tip-toe, Scripture declares, Let not the foot of pride overtake me, and let not the hand of the wicked drive me away.18
Concerning haughty men, purveyors of slander, them who use lewd language and them who are wise in their own eyes19 Scripture declares, For, behold, the day cometh, it burneth as a furnace.20

Concerning him who takes a wife for his infant son, who marries his daughter to an old man21 and who does a favour to one without notifying him22 Scripture declares, The Lord will not be willing to pardon him.23

Concerning tax-collectors, confiscators, extortioners and collectors of customs, Scripture declares, Thy riches, and thy wares, thy merchandise, thy mariners, and thy pilots, thy calkers, and the exchangers of thy merchandise, and all thy men of war, that are in thee, with all thy company which is in the midst of thee, shall fall into the heart of the seas in the day of thy ruin.24

Concerning him who deceives his partner, who does not return a lost object to its owner, who lends money to his fellow with the object of foreclosing his house or his field, who indulges in perversion with his wife, and who lays wanton charges against his wife in order to divorce her, Scripture declares, I the Lord search the heart, I try the reins.25

Concerning them who suffer insults but do not insult, who hear themselves reviled and do not answer back, who perform [religious precepts] from love26 and rejoice in their chastisements,27 Scripture declares, But they that love Him be as the sun when he goeth forth in his might.28

Concerning them who have a humble opinion of themselves, who are low in their own estimation, who subdue their [evil] inclination and who are humble of spirit, Scripture declares, Thus saith the Lord, the Redeemer of Israel, his Holy One, to him who is despised of men, to him who is abhorred of nations, to a servant of rulers: Kings shall see and arise, princes, and they shall prostrate themselves.29

Concerning trustworthy men, them who keep a secret, who return a pledge and who restore a lost object [to its owner] Scripture declares, Mine eyes are upon the faithful of the land, that they may dwell with me.30

Concerning him who loves his wife as himself and honours her more than himself,31 who leads his children in the right path and marries his son just before he attains puberty, before he comes within the power of sin, Scripture declares, And thou shalt know that thy tent is in peace; and thou shalt visit thy habitation, and shalt not sin.32 Thou shalt know also that thy seed shall be great, and thine offspring as the grass of the earth.33

Concerning him who loves his fellow-men, who displays friendliness towards his relatives, who marries his sister’s daughter34 and lends a peruṭah to a poor man in the time of his need, Scripture declares, Then shalt thou call, and the Lord shall answer.35

Concerning them who confess their sins in earnestness,36 repent wholeheartedly, receive penitents and teach them to return from their sinful ways, Scripture declares, Then shall thy light break forth as the morning.37

Concerning them who judge in righteousness, who reprove with sincerity, who perform [their daily tasks] in a state of [ritual] cleanliness and who are pure of heart, Scripture, declares, Surely God is good to Israel, even to such as are pure in heart.38

Concerning them who sigh, grieve and look forward to [national] salvation and mourn for Jerusalem, Scripture declares, To appoint unto them that mourn in Zion, to give unto them a garland for ashes.39
Concerning them who are merciful, who feed the hungry, give drink to the thirsty, clothe the naked and distribute alms Scripture declares, Say ye of the righteous, that it shall be well with him.40

Concerning the poor, the bashful, the lowly of spirit, those who are gentle to the young41 and trustworthy men Scripture declares, Thou shalt also decree a thing, and it shall be established unto thee, and light shall shine upon thy ways.42

Concerning them who toil in [propagating] the Torah, who study the Torah for its own sake, who are constantly in search of performing meritorious deeds and who wait for [the opening of the doors of] temples [of prayer and learning] Scripture declares, Happy is the man that hearkeneth to me, watching daily at my gates, waiting at the posts of my doors.43

Concerning them who pursue righteousness, who seek peace for their people, who grieve with the community and stand by them in the hour of their distress Scripture declares, The Lord is good, a stronghold in the day of trouble; and He knoweth them that take refuge in Him.44

On account of four things is the sun in eclipse;45 on account of an ’Ab Beth Din who died and was not fittingly mourned;46 on account of a betrothed maiden who cried out aloud in the city and there was none to rescue her;47 on account of sodomy; and on account of two brothers whose blood was shed at the same time.

On account of four things are the luminaries48 in eclipse: on account of those who forge documents; on account of those who give false evidence; on account of those who breed small cattle;49 and on account of those who cut down good trees.50

51 On account of four things the wealth of householders is confiscated by the government: on account of those who retain in their possession bills which have been paid;52 on account of those who lend money on usury; on account of those who had the power to protest [against wrongdoing] and failed to do so; and on account of those who publicly donate specified sums for charity and do not give them.53

On account of four things is the property of householders appropriated by the State treasury:54 on account of those who withhold the hired labourer’s wages; on account of those who delay payment of the labourer’s wages; on account of those who remove the yoke from off their own neck and place it on their fellow-men;55 and [the sin of] arrogance is equal to them all.

R. Dosethai b. Judah said: One should always56 contend with the wicked, as it is stated, They that forsake the law praise the wicked; but such as keep the law contend with them.57 Should somebody whisper to you, ‘[But is it not written,] Contend not with evildoers, neither be thou envious against them that work unrighteousness?’58 answer him, ‘Only he whose conscience pricks him59 speaks thus. Contend not with evildoers means, to be like them; be not envious against them that work unrighteousness means, to emulate them’.
In the heavenly abode60 there is no sitting, eating, drinking, sleeping, procreation of children, enmity, hatred, rivalry, envy, obduracy, weariness or hindrance.

The same was said by David, king of Israel; for it is stated, He made darkness His hiding-place.61 With reference to whom did David say this verse? He only said it by way of praising the Holy One, blessed be He, Who is Yah ruling in the heights of the universe; He is One and His name is One, and He dwells in three hundred and ninety firmaments.62 Upon each firmament His Name and attributes are inscribed; in each are Ministering Angels, Seraphim, Ophannim,63 Cherubim, celestial spheres64 and the throne of glory. Do not wonder too much at this statement; because a king of flesh and blood has a number of residences, some for warm weather and some for cold weather; how much more so [can this be said] of the King, the Life of the universe, since everything belongs to Him!

When Israel perform the will of the All-present, [56b] He dwells in Araboth the seventh [heaven]65 and He does not disinterest Himself in anything [in the world]; as it is stated, From between the two cherubim; and He spoke unto him.66 But when He is wroth, He ascends and dwells in the upper heavens, and though people cry aloud and weep, their voices are not heard, even though they decree a fast, wallow in ashes, clothe themselves in sackcloth and shed tears.

(2) ibid. XXXVII, 17.

Such action is considered unfair and undignified.

(39) Isa. LXI, 3.

(43) Prov. VIII, 34.
(44) Nahum I, 7.
(45) lit. ‘smitten’.
(46) With an appropriate memorial address.
(47) Cf. Deut. XXII, 24.
(48) The moon and stars.
(49) Cf. above, §6.
(50) Even though they are their own property; cf. Suk. 29a (Sonc. ed., p. 131).
(51) [On this and the next paragraphs, cf. Büchler, op. cit., p. 90, n. 1.]

(54) For the fiscus.

chapter.Title: CHAPTER III
chapter.p: Ben ‘Azzai said: Whoever sets the following four things [constantly] before his eyes and upon his heart will never commit a sin: Whence he came, whither he goes, Who is his Judge and what he is destined to become. Whence he came? From a place of darkness. Whither he goes? To a place of thick darkness. [Another reading:] Whence he came? From a place of uncleanness. Whither he goes? To cause others to be unclean.1 [Another reading:] Whence he came? From a fetid drop and from a place which no person is able to behold.2 Whither he goes? To the nether-world to be judged in Gehinnom3 and burnt in fire. And Who is his Judge? He must realize that his Judge is not of flesh and blood but the Lord of all works, blessed be He, with Whom there is no injustice, forgetfulness, respect of persons or taking of bribes. What is he destined to become? A worm and maggot; as it is stated, How much less man, that is a worm! and the son of man, that is a maggot!4
R. Simeon said: A man is [full of] worms during his life and [full of] maggots when dead. He is full of worms during life—i.e. vermin, and full of maggots when dead—i.e. what swarms when he is dead.5

R. Eleazar b. Jacob said: Man is comely and praiseworthy but emits an ugly expression from his mouth. To what can this be compared? To a large salon in the middle of which a tannary pipe was fixed. So is man: if now when he discharges excrement from his bowels he prides himself over other creatures, should he emit from his bowels foliatum,6 balsam or any other kind of aromatic spice, how much more would he pride himself over other creatures!7

Shortly before R. Eleazar b. Azariah died, his disciples went in to visit him.8 They sat in front of him and said, ‘Master, teach us the ways of life’.9 He said to them, ‘My sons, what can I teach you? Go and let each of you be solicitous for the honour of his colleague; and when you stand up to pray, know before Whom you stand and pray; for on that account you will [be worthy to] enter into the life of the World to Come’.

Five things we learnt from R. Eliezer at the time of his death, and we had greater joy over what we then learnt than over what he taught us during his life.10 They are: a ball, a shoe-last, an amulet, tefillin and a cushion can become unclean, and [if unclean] may be immersed just as they are.11 Go and pay due regard to them, because they are important ordinances which were told to Moses on Mount Sinai.
chapter.ftnote: (1) The human body, when dead, causes ritual defilement.
(2) The womb.
(3) So GRA. V and H read ‘and Abaddon’, a name for the nether-world.
(4) Job XXV, 6.

(5) Another possible interpretation is that he feels the bite of maggots even when he is dead; cf. Shab. 13b (Sonc. ed., p. 54), ‘Worms are as painful to the dead as a needle in the flesh of the living’.
(6) An ointment or oil prepared from the leaves of spikenard.
(7) Following the text of GRA. Cf. above, p. 543.
(8) Cf. Ber. 28b (Sonc. ed., p. 173).
(9) So GRA. V has ‘only one subject’.
(10) They rejoiced because his teaching was accepted. The laws which he taught in his lifetime were rejected since he had been excommunicated. After his death the ban was lifted.
(11) For the explanation of this teaching, cf. ARN XIX, p. 108, n. 6. Instead of ‘as they are’ another reading is bemashehu, i.e. in a small quantity of water and not the full measure of forty se’ah.

chapter.title: CHAPTER IV
chapter.p: You should always be pleasant on entering and leaving [a house]. Spend less time on business and occupy yourself with [the study of] the Torah. It once happened that R. Simeon b. Eleazar1 was coming from Migdal Eder2 from the house of his teacher and was riding leisurely on his ass by the seaside.3 A certain man4 chanced to meet him, who was exceedingly ugly. He said to him, ‘Raḳa,5 how ugly are the children of Abraham our father!’6 The other replied, ‘What can I do for you? Speak to the Craftsman Who made me’. R. Simeon b. Eleazar immediately dismounted from the ass, prostrated himself before him7 and said to him, ‘I apologize to you, forgive me’. He replied to him, ‘I will not forgive you until you go to the Craftsman Who made me and say to Him, “How ugly is the vessel which You have made!” ’ R. Simeon walked behind him for three mil.8 When his fellow-citizens heard [of his arrival] they came out to meet him, greeting him with the words, ‘Peace be upon you, Rabbi’. The man said to them, ‘Whom are you calling Rabbi?’ They answered, ‘He who is walking behind you’. Thereupon he exclaimed, ‘If this man be a Rabbi, may there not be any more like him in Israel!’ He told them the whole story. They earnestly begged him to pardon him, and he replied, ‘I will forgive him, but only on condition that he does not act9 in the same manner again’.

That same day R. Simeon sat and expounded in his great Academy: Be always pliable like the reed and not unyielding like the cedar. In the case of a reed, though the four winds of the world were to blow upon it, the reed bends with them, and when the winds drop, it remains standing in its place, with the result that one is able to make a pen of it to write a scroll of the Torah. But the cedar is not like that: if the east, north [or] west wind blows upon it, it cannot move it from its place; but as soon as the south wind blows upon it, it uproots it and the result is that people come and cut it up,10 chop it and use it for building houses, and what is left is used for firewood. Therefore the Sages said: Be always pliable like the reed and not unyielding like the cedar.11

How does one honour his teacher? When they are both walking along the way, he must place himself at his12 left hand and not at his right. If three [were walking together] and a Sage or a teacher was among them, the teacher is to be in the middle, the more important of the other two on his right and the less important on his left. We find it so in connection with the three angels who came to Abraham our father, viz. Gabriel, Michael and Raphael. Gabriel came to overthrow Sodom and Gomorrah, Raphael came to heal Abraham13 and Michael came to announce to Sarah [that she would have a son]. Michael was in the middle, Gabriel on his right and Raphael on his left.14 When Abraham our father saw the Ministering Angels, the Divine Presence appeared and stood over him. He said to them, ‘Sires, wait until I take leave of the Divine Presence, which is greater than you’, as it is stated, And he said: My lord, if now I have found favour in thy sight, pass not away, I pray thee, from thy servant.15

When Abraham our father had taken leave of the Divine Presence, he came, bowed to them and led them beneath the tree, as it is stated, Let now a little water be fetched, and wash your feet,16 and afterwards [it is written], And I will fetch a morsel of bread.17 But [when the angels came] to Lot, what did he say? And tarry all night, and wash your feet.18 Others say: Lot spoke to them [in this manner] only as a clever device. He said [to himself], ‘If [the men of Sodom] find them with their faces, hands and feet already washed, the result will be that they will kill me, my wife and my daughters.19 Let them, therefore, find them with the dust still on their feet, and they will think that they have only just arrived’.

He who walks behind his teacher may not leave him without first obtaining his permission. If they were both equal in learning, the host enters [the house] first and then the guest, but when leaving the guest goes out first and the host leaves last.20 He who is about to leave the company of his fellow,21 whether he be greater than he or not, must say to him, ‘I am leaving’.
chapter.ftnote: (1) Others read ‘R. Eleazar b. R. Simeon’. But the story here related is more befitting the character of his son, R. Simeon. Cf. B.M. 85a (Sonc. ed., p. 487).
(2) In the extreme south of Judah.
(3) In Ta‘an. 20a (Sonc. ed., p. 100) ‘riverside’.
(4) According to some it was Elijah who wanted to teach him a lesson.
(5) lit. ‘empty one’, good-for-nothing.
(6) Some versions read: ‘Are all your fellow-citizens as ugly as you?’ Cf. above, p. 295.
(7) R. Simeon realized that he had done wrong.
(8) V and H ‘half a mil’.
(9) So GRA and H. V has ‘speak’.
(10) The translation follows the corrected text of GRA.
(11) Cf. Ta‘an loc. cit.
(12) The teacher’s.
(13) Of the effects of his circumcision.
(14) Cf. Yoma 37a (Sonc. ed., p. 172).
