(15) Gen. XVIII, 3. Abraham addressed the chief of them and consequently the word lord does not signify God. Others interpret that he spoke to God, praying Him to wait until he had attended to his guests. They therefore cite here ibid. XVII, 22, And He left off talking with him, and God went up from Abraham.
(16) ibid. XVIII, 4.

(18) ibid. XIX, 2. Abraham had mistaken the angels for Arabs, who worship the dust of their feet and, being anxious not to introduce idolatry in any form into his house, he asked them to wash their feet first. Lot, however, who had no such anxiety, offered them a night’s lodging before asking them to wash their feet. Others, who give the interpretation which follows in the text, maintain that Lot also was anxious that they should first wash their feet, a custom he had learnt from Abraham; but the reason that he told them to stay the night before washing was to deceive the people of Sodom.
(19) For not reporting their arrival earlier.
(20) The reason is not to leave the wife unprotected; cf. Ta‘an. 23b (Sonc. ed., p. 120).
(21) So GRA. V and H read ‘his teacher’.

chapter.title: CHAPTER V
chapter.p: A person should never leave [the company of his teacher or even] his fellow unless he had previously obtained his consent. All can learn such good manners from the All-present, Who said, as it were, to Abraham, ‘I am now leaving’, as it is stated, And the Lord went His way,1 as soon as He had left off speaking to Abraham; and Abraham returned unto his place.2

A man should never enter his fellow’s house suddenly;3 and all can learn such good manners from the All-present, Who stood at the entrance of the Garden [of Eden] and called to Adam,4 as it is stated, And the Lord God called unto the man, and said unto him: Where art thou?5

The story is told of the four Sages, viz. Rabban Gamaliel, R. Joshua, R. Eleazar b. Azariah and R. ‘Aḳiba, who were on their way to attend a Privy Council6 which also included a certain philosopher as a member. R. Joshua said to Rabban Gamaliel, ‘Master, would you like us to call on our companion the philosopher?’7 He replied, ‘No’. In the morning he again asked him, ‘Master, would you like us to call on our companion the philosopher?’ He replied, ‘Yes’. R. Joshua went and knocked on the door. The philosopher thought and said [to himself], ‘This can only be the manners of a Sage’. [When he knocked] a second time, [the philosopher] got up and washed his face, hands and feet. On the third knock he arose and opened the door and saw the Sages of Israel coming all together.8 Rabban Gamaliel was in the middle, R. Joshua and R. Eleazar b. Azariah on his right and R. ‘Aḳiba on his left.

The philosopher was meditating and saying [to himself], ‘How shall I greet these Sages of Israel? If I say, “Peace be upon you, Rabban Gamaliel”, I shall be guilty of derogatory conduct towards the [other] Sages. If I say, “Peace be upon you, Sages of Israel”, that would be an insult to Rabban Gamaliel’.9 As soon as he approached them, he greeted them with the words, ‘Peace be upon you, Sages of Israel, headed by Rabban Gamaliel’.

(We learn [this rule of etiquette] not from [this story of] Rabban Gamaliel but from the Divine Presence, as it is stated, I saw the Lord sitting on His throne, and all the host of heaven standing by Him on His right hand and on His left.)10

Always let all people [who visit you] be regarded by you as robbers, but show them the same respect as to Rabban Gamaliel. The story is told of R. Joshua on whom a certain person called early in the morning. He gave him food and drink, and took him up to the loft to sleep and then removed the ladder from under him. What did that man do? He arose in the middle of the night, collected the vessels11 and wrapped them up in his cloak. As soon as he started to descend,12 he fell from the loft and broke his neck. When morning came, R. Joshua rose early and found him where he had fallen. He said to him, ‘Raḳa!13 do all persons act as you have?’ He replied, ‘Master, I did not know that you had removed the ladder from under me’. He said to him, ‘Raḳa! Do you not know that already yesterday14 we were suspicious of you?’ Hence R. Joshua said: Always let all men be in your eyes as robbers, but show them the same respect as to Rabban Gamaliel.
chapter.ftnote: (1) God notified Abraham that He was departing.
(2) Gen. XVIII, 33. The translation follows the emended text of GRA. V’s reading is: ‘Who said to Abraham, “Abraham, has he any further need of Me?” He said before Him, “Lord of the Universe, no” ’.
(3) Cf. Nid. 16b (Sonc. ed., p. 112).
(4) To announce His presence.
(5) Gen. III, 9.
(6) Or, lit. ‘an interior kingdom’.
(7) To confer with him before the meeting.
(8) lit. ‘some from here and some from there’.
(9) Who had the title of Prince or Patriarch, and was President of the Great Sanhedrin in Jerusalem.

(10) 1 Kings XXII, 19. This passage is omitted by GRA and printed in V within brackets. He inserts it in chap. IV towards the end and reads: ‘We learn this [rule] not only from the angels but from the Divine Presence’, etc.
(11) Which were stored in the loft.
(12) Thinking that the ladder was still there.
(14) From the moment you arrived

chapter.title: CHAPTER VI
chapter.p: If one enters a house [by invitation], whatever the host tells him he must do.1 The story is told of R. Simeon b. Anṭipaṭros with whom many guests used to come and stay. When he pressed them to eat and drink, they vowed by the Torah that they would neither eat nor drink, but later they partook of food and drink. When the time came for them to depart he used to flagellate them. This matter came to the notice of Rabban Joḥanan b. Zakkai and the Sages who were angered by it. They said, ‘Who will go and inform us [of his action]?’ R. Joshua replied, ‘I will go and see how he conducts himself’.

He went and found him at the entrance of his house and greeted him, ‘Peace be upon you, Master’. The other replied, ‘Peace be upon you, Master and Teacher’. He said, ‘I need a lodging’. The other replied, ‘Lodge here in peace’. They sat down and occupied themselves in the study of the Torah until evening. In the morning [R. Joshua] said to him, ‘Master, I want to go to the bath-house’. He replied, ‘As you wish’;2 whereupon R. Joshua was afraid lest he would smite him on his thighs. After he returned [from the bath-house] they ate and drank. He then said, ‘Who will accompany me [on my way back]?’ The other replied, ‘I will’. R. Joshua was then meditating and saying [to himself], ‘What can I report to the Sages who sent me [to institute inquiries]?’3 He then turned [to look] back. [R. Simeon] asked him, ‘Master, why did you turn to look behind you?’ He replied, ‘I have something to ask you. Why did you flagellate other guests who stayed with you and me you did not flagellate?’ He said to him, ‘Master, you are a great Sage and you have good manners. The persons who stay with me I usually press to eat, but they vow by the Torah [not to eat] and transgress [their vow]; and so have I heard from the mouth of the Sages that whoever vows by the Torah and breaks his vow has to be given forty lashes’. He said to him, ‘May Heaven bless you for what you have done. By your life and by the life of your head! Whoever behaves in this manner, give him the forty lashes on your account [57a] and [another] forty on account of the Sages who sent me’.4 R. Joshua returned and reported to the Sages what he had witnessed while he was with Simeon b. Anṭipaṭros.

A man should never be fastidious concerning his meals. It once happened that Hillel the Elder had a certain man to a meal, when a poor person came and stood at his door and said, ‘I am to marry today and have no provisions at all’. Hillel’s wife took the entire meal [which she had prepared] and gave it to him. She then kneaded fresh dough, cooked another dinner and placed it before them. He said to her, ‘My dear, why did you not bring it to us sooner?’ She told him all that had happened. He said to her, ‘My dear, I, too, did not judge you in the scale of guilt but in the scale of merit, because everything you did was only in the name of Heaven’.

We do not leave over a portion of the food in a stew-pot, but we should leave over a portion of the food in the dish.5 It once happened that R. Joshua was the guest of a certain widow who served him with a dish of beans. He ate without leaving any. On the second occasion he also ate without leaving any. On the third occasion she over-seasoned it with salt; and as soon as R. Joshua tasted it he withdrew his hand from it and ate his bread dry. She asked, ‘Why did you withdraw your hand from the pounded beans?’ He replied, ‘I had already eaten earlier in the day’. She said to him, ‘You should then have withdrawn your hand also from the bread’. ‘Perhaps,’ she continued, ‘you left [the dish today] as compensation for the former meals!6 But have not the Sages said: We do not leave over a portion of the food in the stew-pot but we should leave over a portion of the food in the dish!’7

Hence R. Joshua said, ‘No one has ever had the better of me except this woman, a little boy and a little girl’. What was the incident with the little girl? Once R. Joshua was walking in a field when he met a little girl who called out to him, ‘Why are you walking across the field?’ He replied, ‘I am walking along a [trodden] path’. ‘Robbers like yourself,’ she retorted, ‘have trodden it down.’ What was the incident with the little boy? Once R. Joshua was on a journey and came across a little boy sitting at a cross-road. He asked him, ‘My son, by which road will I be able to go to the town, by this one or by that?’ He replied, ‘Both of them are before you; but this one is long and short and that one is short and long’. [He proceeded along the short but long road.] When he approached the city’s wall, he found that it was surrounded by gardens and orchards, and turned back. Noticing the same little boy sitting where he had left him, he said, ‘My son, why did you play a trick on me? Did you not tell me that this road was short?’8 ‘Master,’ he retorted, ‘you are a great Sage and this is your wisdom? Did I not tell you that it is long?’9 R. Joshua went and kissed him upon his head and exclaimed, ‘Happy are you, O Israel, for all of you are wise, both young and old’.

How does one dance before a bride?10 Beth Shammai said, ‘The bride as she is’.11 Beth Hillel said, ‘Beautiful and graceful bride’.12 Beth Shammai said to Beth Hillel, ‘According to your view, if she were lame or blind one still has to call her “beautiful and graceful bride”, but the Torah has declared, Keep thee far from a false matter!’13 Beth Hillel replied to Beth Shammai, ‘If one has made a bad purchase in the market, should one praise it in his eyes or depreciate it? Surely one should praise it in his eyes’. Therefore the Sages said: The disposition of man should always be pleasant with people.

One should break off a piece of bread14 only from the part that is baked to a crust and not from the soft part;15 neither should one hold in his hand a piece [of bread] as big as an egg,16 because one who acts in this manner is a glutton and a tippler, neither should a man drink his goblet of wine in one draught, and if he did so he is a tippler and a glutton. How many pauses should he make before drinking it up? [If he drinks it] in two draughts he shows good manners; in three he is of the arrogant.

A man should not begin to eat leek or onion from the top side but from the leaves, and if he did eat it so he is a glutton and a tippler. He should not drink two goblets for reciting Grace after meals because it makes him appear like a tippler.17
chapter.ftnote: (1) Some eds. add: ‘providing it is a thing permitted to be done’. Cf. Pes. 86b (Sonc. ed., p. 456, n. 6) where the margin adds ‘except depart’. This is probably meant humorously—a guest should not outstay his welcome until he is told to go! Others read מצא for מדא ‘except a forbidden thing’, which harmonizes with the addition in our text.
(2) Not a positive approval.
(3) Since there was nothing untoward in the man’s behaviour.
(4) i.e. I do not mind how much you flagellate him.

(5) The text is emended by GRA to agree with ‘Erub. 53b (Sonc. ed., p. 373). Cf. also Midrash Lamentations I (Sonc. ed., p. 85). V and H insert ‘not’ in the second instead of the first clause. When food is poured from the pot into the dish, none should be left over in the pot for the servant; but when the contents of the dish are ladled into the plates, some must be left in the dish for him.
(6) When you ate it all.
(7) The corrected text of GRA is reproduced in translation. The hostess subtly rebuked R. Joshua for not having left some of the food.
(8) So GRA.
(9) The last words are inserted by GRA.
(10) What does one recite or sing in praise of a bride?
(11) One should not exaggerate, and if she is obviously not beautiful one should not say that she is.
(12) Every bride should be complimented.
(13) Ex. XXIII, 7.
(14) For the purpose of reciting the Grace before meals.
(15) i.e. a piece of the outer surface must be taken for the purpose and not the inner dough.
(16) And eat it all at once; he should only eat a quantity as large as an olive.

(17) Cf. Ber. 51b (Sonc. ed., p. 310) where the reason given is connected with ‘pairs’, alluding to the idea that even numbers are unlucky and cause a person to come under the influence of evil spirits. Our text, however, can be explained in accordance with Pes. 110b (Sonc. ed., pp. 568f.) where it states that in Palestine they are not particular about ‘pairs’; it is nevertheless forbidden for the reason given here.

chapter.title: CHAPTER VII
chapter.p: When two sit at one table, the senior of them puts forth his hand first1 and then the junior; if the junior puts forth [his hand first] he is a glutton.

The story is told of R. ‘Aḳiba who prepared a meal for his disciples. They2 served them with two dishes, one raw and the other cooked. First they served them with raw foods. The bright [pupil] among them took hold of the stalk with one hand and with the other tried to break a piece off, and when it did not come off he withdrew his hands from it and ate his bread dry.3 The foolish [pupil], however, took hold of the stalk in one hand and bit into it with his teeth. R. ‘Aḳiba said to him, ‘Not so, my son; place your heel on it in the plate!’ After that a cooked dish was served to them, of which they ate their fill. Then [R. ‘Aḳiba] said to them, ‘My sons, I only did this to test whether you have good manners or not’.
A man should begin his mealtime at the fourth hour of the day4 and enter the bath-house only at the fourth hour of the day.5
Hot baths in large quantities are harmful to the body and beneficial in small quantities; wine is harmful in large quantities and beneficial in small quantities.6
The following three things are of equal importance, viz. wisdom, fear [of God] and humility.
When entering a privy one should not face west or east7 but only the sides.8 He should not expose himself until he sits, and should not wipe himself with the right hand but only with the left.9

It is related of R. ‘Aḳiba that he went into a privy behind R. Joshua to watch his behaviour. He noticed that he entered the privy only on the side, exposed himself10 only after he had sat down, and wiped himself only with the left hand. What is the reason that we do not wipe with the right hand? R. Eliezer said: Because one eats with it. R. Joshua said: Because one writes11 with it. Rabban Gamaliel said: Because one points with it to the cantillations of the Torah.12

A man should not rejoice when among people who weep or weep when among those who rejoice. He should not stay awake among people who sleep or sleep when among those who are awake. He should not be standing when all others are sitting or sit when all others are standing. This is the general rule: A man should not deviate from the custom of his companions or from society.13
chapter.ftnote: (1) To pick his portion from the dish. On the Oriental mode of dining, cf. Lane, Manners and Customs of the Modern Egyptians, p. 148.
(2) The waiters.
(3) He realized that he could only break off a piece by using much force and that would be unmannerly.
(4) i.e. 10 a.m., the beginning of the day being 6 a.m.
(5) Not earlier.
(6) Cf. Giṭ. 70a (Sonc. ed., p. 334).
(7) So as not to expose himself towards the Holy of Holies.
(8) i.e. north and south, which are not in line with the Holy of Holies; cf. Ber. 61b (Sonc. ed., p. 387).
(9) The Moslems have a similar practice and do not touch food with the left hand; cf. Lane, op. cit., p. 150, n. 2.
(10) In Ber. 62a (Sonc. ed., p. 388) ‘evacuated’.
(11) So GRA. V has ‘drinks’.
(12) [In a copy of the Heb. Bible when reading it aloud; cf. N.Y.]
(13) Cf. DEZ V 5, p. 581. This paragraph is omitted here in H.

chapter.title: CHAPTER VIII
chapter.p: A guest should not say to his host, ‘Serve me that I may eat’, but [must wait] until he is invited to eat. If they poured out a goblet [of wine] for him he must drink it with pauses.1 How many pauses should he make? In the case of warm [beverages] three and with cold four. R. Judah said: This applies only to goblets of Galilee,2 but with goblets used in Judah3 he drinks with as many pauses as he likes.4

A man should not say to his fellow, ‘Come and eat [with me in return] for the food you gave me’, because this is a kind of usury.5 In Jerusalem, however, they used to exchange invitations one with another.6

A man should not send to his fellow a barrel of wine and put oil at its mouth,7 because this may lead to fatal consequences. It once happened that a man arranged a banquet in honour of his son; when his guests arrived and sat down at the table, he went to get the oil.8 When he discovered that the barrel was full of wine he strangled himself and died.9 Hence the Sages said: A man should not send to his fellow a barrel of wine and put oil at its mouth, because it may lead to fatal consequences.

A man should not say to his fellow, ‘Take oil’ from an empty jar,10 because the latter would be grateful to him without cause.11 A man should not urge his fellow to dine with him knowing that he will not do so; and he should not offer him many gifts when he knows that he will not accept them.

A man should not pass off new wine for old12 when giving his friend a drink because that is a kind of robbery. If he was giving drink to ass-drivers, he may not say to them, ‘Take away this man’s cup and pass it to someone else’ because this is a kind of robbery.13

If a man was standing by sellers of produce in a market-place, he may not say to them, ‘What is the price of this article?’ when he has no intention of buying it,14 because he encourages the mind15 of the seller [that he will sell it].
chapter.ftnote: (1) Not in one draught. Cf. above, p. 554.
(2) Which were small.
(3) Which were large.
(4) Without appearing haughty.
(5) He may give him a more elaborate meal than he had eaten at the other’s house.
(6) So GRA. They did not take the question of usury into consideration.
(7) Leading him to believe that the whole barrel contained oil.
(8) So GRA and H. V reads ‘wine’, with a similar change in the next sentence.
(9) From shame, since he had nothing else prepared to set before his guests.
(10) When he knows that the man will not do so.
(11) He gains the gratitude of the man through something which he had no intention of doing. This is the reason in all the cases mentioned.
(12) So GRA. V reverses the adjectives. H omits this sentence.
(13) The suggestion is that he had had his drink when he had not.
(14) To pretend interest in a purchase when he has no money is deception; cf. B.M. 58b (Sonc. ed., p. 347).
(15) This, too, is deception. The translation is according to H and NY. V reads ‘mistake’.

chapter.title: CHAPTER IX
chapter.p: A man should not break bread over a dish,1 wipe the plate with a piece of bread, or gather the crumbs and leave them on the table, because such action is objectionable to men.2 One should not wipe the plate with a piece of bread and leave it on the table, because such action is objectionable to men. A man should not bite off a piece of bread and return it to the plate; similarly he should not bite off a piece of bread and give it to his fellow, because not all tastes are alike. He should also not drink from a cup and hand it to his fellow because of danger to life.3

Once R. ‘Aḳiba was staying at the inn of a certain man who handed him a goblet of wine from which he had already drunk. R. ‘Aḳiba said to him, ‘Take and drink it’. [The host] again handed him another goblet of wine from which he had previously drunk, and R. ‘Aḳiba said to him, ‘Take and drink it’. Ben ‘Azzai said to him, ‘How long will you give [R. ‘Aḳiba] goblets of wine which had previously been tasted!’

It is also related of R. ‘Aḳiba that he was staying at the inn of a certain man [57b] who took a piece of bread and used it to support his plate.4 R. ‘Aḳiba snatched [the bread] and ate it. [The innkeeper] said to him, ‘Master, have you no bread to eat other than that on which I rested the plate?’ He replied, ‘I imagined that you would be scalded with tepid water;5 but now6 [I see] that you are not scalded even with hot water’.
A man should not drink his goblet and place it upon the table; but he should retain it until the waiter comes and then hand it to him.7

Rabbi [Judah the Prince] said the following five things [concerning bread]: we may not place raw meat on bread,8 we may not pass a cup [full of wine] or a plate [of soup] over bread, we may not throw bread, we may not rest a dish on bread and we may not sit on articles of food because it would crush them.9

A guest may not take his portion and give it to the attendant, lest something untoward happen to [the rest of] the meal;10 but he should take [his portion], keep it in front of him and later hand it to the attendant.

Guests may not give anything [from what is set before them] to the host’s son or to his servant or deputy unless they have received the host’s permission to do so. It once happened that in a time of scarcity a man invited three guests to his house and only had three eggs11 which he set before them. When the host’s child entered and stood before them, one of the guests took his portion and gave it to him; the second guest did the same and so did the third. When the father came in and saw him with one egg in his mouth and holding two in his hands, he picked him up to his full height and flung him to the ground so that he died. When the mother saw her child dead she got up from [her seat] upon the roof12 and threw herself down and died. On seeing this, the father also stood on the roof and threw himself down and died. R. Eliezer b. Jacob said: Because of this three souls perished.
chapter.ftnote: (1) Lest crumbs fall into it and fastidious persons would not eat from the dish.
(2) Following the text of GRA; also in the next sentence.
(3) The man may be fastidious and yet be forced to drink from it. It is permitted only after he had poured out some water from the cup to cleanse the rim; cf. Tamid 27b (Sonc. ed., p. 9).
(4) Displaying disrespect for food.
(5) i.e. I gave you a plain hint that this must not be done.
(6) Because of the question.
(7) He may stain the tablecloth.
(8) So as not to spoil it; this is the reason in all the cases mentioned.
(9) It is disrespectful even if he does not make it repugnant. H reverses the order of the paragraphs.
(10) And the guest will have had nothing to eat.
(11) Some read ‘food of the size of three eggs’.
(12) The text in Ḥul. 94b (Sonc. ed., p. 529) states that she went up to the roof.

chapter.title: CHAPTER X
chapter.p: On entering a bath-house one should say, ‘May it be Thy will, O Lord my God, that Thou cause me to enter in peace and depart in peace, and that Thou cause me to return [to my house] in peace, and deliver me from this heat and its like in the future’.1

How should he conduct himself2 before entering? He removes his shoes, then his hat, then his cloak, then his girdle, then his shirt and finally his underwear. When he finished washing and left [the bath] and is handed a towel, he should dry his head and then the rest of his body. When he is given the oil3 he should oil his head4 and then the rest of his body. He then puts on his underwear and his shirt, binds his girdle, dons his cloak, [puts his hat on] and finally his shoes. [If he has his son with him or his servant, they put on the shoes for him.]5 He puts on the right [shoe] first and then the left, and when he removes them he takes the left off first and then the right.6 It is the same in connection with the tefillin: he puts on that of the hand first and then that of the head,7 and when he removes them he first takes off that of the head and then of the hand.8

Who enters a bath-house should not knead9 or scrape10 or urinate on the marble floor.11 It once happened that they begged Rabban Gamaliel, who was weak, to urinate on the marble floor but he refused.12 Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel said: He who urinates on the marble floor is the companion of an ass, and he who eats in the street is like a dog; some say that he is unfit to give evidence.13

In the case of a privy he who is inside must give way14 to him who enters;15 but in the case of a bath-house he who is about to enter must give way16 to him who is inside.17 One may not bring into the bath-house oil in a glass vessel because of danger.18 One may not spit in a bath-house because of danger.19 One may not spit anywhere in the presence of others.

One may cite the rules appertaining to a privy in a privy and the rules appertaining to a bath-house in a bath-house.20 One should not extend a greeting21 in a place where people are undressed22 but only in a place where the majority present are dressed.23 If most of the persons present are dressed it is as though they are all dressed; if the majority are undressed it is as though they are all undressed. A man may not give greeting to his fellow in the bath-house on account of danger, and if one does greet him he should say, ‘It is a bath-house!’ Others say that he may return the greeting and it does not matter.

A man should not let his feet [dangle] in a bath-tub while he lies stretched out [naked], because it is immodest. A man should not say to his fellow in a bath-house, ‘Rub me in well with your hand’, and he who says so will not depart from there unscathed. R. Judah said: This only applies when there is little water,24 but when there is plenty of water it is all right. It is discreditable for a man to read [the Shema‘] twice25 or to immerse [in a ritual bath] twice.26

If a man covers himself in his cloak and stays in the room where they sweat he is as if he robbed the public.27 He who washes himself in cold water and then sluices himself with lukewarm water is as if he robbed the public.28 And if one did rob the public what should he do?29 He should go and dig wells, ditches and grottoes, or repair highways and streets,30 and then he will be forgiven.
chapter.ftnote: (1) Cf. Ber. 60a (Sonc. ed., p. 376).
(2) i.e. in what order should he undress himself.
(3) This is a necessary part of one’s toilet in hot countries.
(4) Because it is ‘the king of all the limbs’, Shab. 61a (Sonc. ed., p. 286).
(5) To spare him the fatigue. The words within brackets are inserted by GRA and H.
(6) The right half of the body being stronger, more honour must be shown to it. Removing the left first is likewise a mark of honour to the right because the right shoe remains longer on the foot.
(7) Cf. Deut. VI, 8, where the hand is mentioned first.
(8) Cf. Men. 36a (Sonc. ed., p. 224).
(9) i.e. massage strongly.

(10) With a strigil to invigorate the circulation. Cf. Shab. 147a (Sonc. ed., p. 747) where this is forbidden only on the Sabbath. Perhaps here it is only forbidden in the presence of many but not in the inner room where few people congregate (so NY). Another reading is ‘or have his limbs broken’, by a very vigorous massage.
(11) In the presence of others, but he must retire to a corner.
(12) [The translation is conjectural and suggested by the context. As it stands the text is unintelligible, but shemen, ‘oil’, seems to indicate a corruption of mashtin, ‘to urinate’.]
(13) Lack of self-respect may lead to one testifying falsely. Cf. Ḳid. 40b (Sonc. ed., p. 203).
(14) i.e. hurry himself.
(15) Because to hold oneself back endangers health.
(16) i.e. wait.
(17) He must wash himself completely with hot and then cold water before leaving the bath-house. Cf. DEZ VIII, p. 588.
(18) In case the glass breaks.
(19) Someone may slip over it.
(20) Cf. ‘A.Z. 44b (Sonc. ed., p. 221), ‘One may not discuss questions relating to Torah in a bath’.
(21) lit. ‘inquire [after one’s peace] and reply’.
(22) Cf. Shab. 10a (Sonc. ed., p. 36) where ‘peace’ is said to be one of God’s names.
(23) So GRA. i.e. not in the inner chamber of the bath-house but in the outer chamber.
(24) When the rubbing may arouse unclean thoughts.

(25) Cf. Ber. 33b (Sonc. ed., p. 210, n. 7) where this applies only where he says each word of the Shema‘ twice. If he repeats the whole sentence he is to be silenced, because it may appear as if he addresses himself to two Powers, similar to the dualism of the Persians, a God of light and a God of darkness. NY suggests a reading ‘to wash himself twice’.
(26) Because people may suspect that he associates too much with women, a ritual bath being required after a seminal emission.
(27) He prevents another from using the bath.
(28) To wash oneself first in hot and then in cold water is beneficial to the body; to use up hot water after having already washed with cold is waste of water.
(29) To make redress.
(30) And so provide water for the general public among whom the aggrieved persons are to be found.

chapter.title: CHAPTER XI
chapter.p: If one starts out on a journey alone before cock-crow his blood is upon his head.1 R. Josiah said: [He should wait] until [the cock] crowed at least twice.2 What kind of cock? The average type,3 as it is stated, Who hath put wisdom in the inward parts? or who hath given understanding to the coc?4
If [immediately] on returning from a journey a man enters a bath-house, undergoes cupping, has marital intercourse and sleeps on the floor, his blood is upon his head.5
If one kills a louse upon his bed,6 or stands naked in front of a candle-light7 or in the moonlight, his blood is upon his head.
[He who eats peeled garlic, a peeled egg or a peeled onion which were kept overnight] and he who drinks diluted liquids or uncovered water which were kept overnight, his blood is upon his head.8

[One may not sit at his table9 under an olive-tree on account of danger.10] He who drinks water from brooks, rivers or pools [direct] with his mouth or by [drawing the water] with one hand,11 his blood is upon his head because leeches are there.12
If a man observes a fast after letting blood, his blood is upon his head.
They who write scrolls [of the Torah], tefillin and mezuzoth, they, their traders and traders’ traders13 will never see a sign of blessing [from their earnings].14
[They who deal in ritually unclean food and forbidden fat will never see a sign of blessing.]15
He who trades in canes and jars will never see a sign of blessing.16
They who cut down [beautiful] trees,17 breeders of small cattle,18 and they who trade on market-stands19 will never see a sign of blessing.
Anyone who sells his scroll [of the Torah] though he does not require it, or sells his daughter [to be a handmaid] though he has no food, will never see a blessing [from that money].
One who does work on the Ninth of Ab will never see a sign of blessing [in the work he does on that day].20 R. ‘Aḳiba said: Scholars should abstain from work [on that day].21

R. Isaac said: Slanderers are like shedders of blood, as it is stated, Thou shalt not go up and down as a talebearer among thy people; neither shalt thou stand idly by the blood of thy neighbour.22 R. Eliezer said: He who hates his fellow belongs to the shedders of blood, as it is stated, If any man hate his neighbour, and lie in wait for him, and rise up against him, and smite him, etc.23 Ben ‘Azzai said: He who hates his wife belongs to the shedders of blood, as it is stated, And if he lay wanton charges against her,24 with the consequence that he hires [false] witnesses and has her hastily brought to the place of stoning.25 R. Jose said: He who calculates the end26 has no portion in the World to Come.27 He who hates Sages and their disciples, a false prophet and he who spreads calumny have no portion in the World to Come.

R. Meir said: Whoever has a House of Study in his town and does not frequent it forfeits his life,28 as it is stated, Thus saith the Lord: What unrighteousness have your fathers found in Me that they are gone far from Me?29 How much more so [if he does not attend] an Academy which contains thousands and myriads of Biblical precepts! R. Meir said: Anyone who has a scholar near him and does not wait upon him [as a disciple] forfeits his life, as it is stated, Because he hath despised the word of the Lord.30

Anyone who goes into the street with his shoes unlaced is haughty of spirit. [He who walks] with his sanṭer31 hanging side-ways,32 or his cap turned backwards, or [sits] crosslegged, or holds in his hand the straps of the tefillin and puts them back while walking in the street belongs to the haughty of spirit. Every man in whom there is haughtiness of spirit is as though he worships idols,33 as it states, Thou shalt not bring an abomination into thine house,34 and it states elsewhere, Every one that is proud in heart is an abomination to the Lord:35 the word abomination is written in the one connection and also in the other—as the abomination mentioned in the one refers to idolatry so the abomination mentioned in the other refers to idolatry.

On going to bed one says, ‘Blessed … Who causeth [58a] the bands of sleep to fall upon my eyes’,36 and on waking he says, ‘O my God, the soul which Thou hast given me is pure’.37 On turning on his side from his sleep he says, ‘Blessed … Who looseneth the bound’.38

On entering a privy one should say, ‘Be honoured, ye honoured and holy beings who minister to the Most High! Give glory to our God and stay where you are. Help me, guard me, support me and wait for me until I enter and come out, for this is the way of human beings’.39 On leaving a privy one says, ‘Blessed is He Who has formed man in wisdom’.40 When he has washed his face he says, ‘Blessed … Who removest the bands of sleep from my eyes and slumber from my eyelids’.41

When he is clothed and goes out into the street he should say,42 ‘May it be Thy will, O Lord my God, that Thou conduct me in peace and uphold me in peace; and let me obtain grace, favour and mercy in Thine eyes and in the eyes of all who behold me; bestow lovingkindnesses upon me, and cause me to return to my house in peace. Deliver me from the hand of every enemy and ambush by the way and from an evil tongue. Let me not become accustomed to sin, transgression or iniquity, and let me not err in a matter of halakah or in any matter whatsoever. Deliver me from all kinds of harm and from all manner of afflictions which break forth and come upon the world that they do not injure me by day or by night. Blessed is He Who bestoweth lovingkindnesses upon His people Israel’.43
May it be the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, that He cause us to behold the rejoicing and comfort of Jerusalem, Amen.
chapter.ftnote: (1) He courts danger. Cf. Yoma 21a (Sonc. ed., pp. 90f.). Pes. 2a (Sonc. ed., pp. 1f.) states, ‘A man should always enter a town by day and set out by day’.
(2) Or, until he has heard at least two crow.
(3) That crows neither too early nor too late.
(4) Job XXXVIII, 36. E.V. the mind.
(5) Following the text of GRA in agreement with Giṭ. 70a (Sonc. ed., p. 334). He will soon die because he had already been exhausted by his journey.
(6) Perhaps what is intended is that he should remove it from the bed because killing it there is unhygienic.
(7) It is said to cause epilepsy; Pes. 112b (Sonc. ed., p. 579).
(8) So GRA. H omits the clause within brackets. Cf. Nid. 17a (Sonc. ed., p. 112).
(9) To eat.
(10) So GRA. H omits the clause within brackets. The branches become weighted with olives and one may fall upon him.
(11) Drawing the water with one hand and drinking it has to be done so rapidly that he has no time to examine it.
(12) And there is the danger of his swallowing a leech; cf. ‘A.Z. 12b (Sonc. ed., p. 63).
(13) i.e. all who trade in them directly or indirectly.
(14) Cf. Pes. 50b (Sonc. ed., p. 246).
(15) This paragraph is inserted by H.
(16) Their bulk is large and so the evil eye has power over them; Pes. loc. cit. (Sonc. ed., p. 245).
(17) To sell for timber and thereby evokes astonishment.
(18) Sheep, goats, etc.
(19) Market traders are exposed to the public gaze and so to the evil eye. Tosiftha Bek. II reads instead ‘shemiṭṭah’, the Sabbatical year when trading with its produce is forbidden.
(20) Added by GRA. Cf. Ta‘an. 30b (Sonc. ed., p. 161).
(21) Even in places where it is customary for people to work. It is the anniversary of the destruction of both Temples.
(22) Lev. XIX, 16.
(23) Deut. XIX, 11.
(24) ibid. XXII, 14.
(26) i.e. the advent of the Messiah.
(27) Because people will say that, since the predetermined time has arrived and the Messiah has not come, he will never come. Cf. Sanh. 97b (Sonc. ed., p. 659).
(28) Ber. 8a (Sonc. ed., p. 39) reads ‘Synagogue’, a dictum of Resh Laḳish.
(29) Jer II, 5. The proof-text is added by GRA.
(31) A kind of cloak.
(32) Over his shoulder.
(33) So GRA.
(34) Deut. VII, 26, the reference being to an idolatrous image.
(35) Prov. XVI, 5.
(36) So GRA. V has ‘upon men’. Cf. P.B., p. 293.
(38) P.B., p. 6. So GRA. V and H read: ‘Who openest the eyes of the blind’.
(39) Addressing the angels who are believed to accompany one to the privy, which was regarded as a haunt of evil spirits.
(41) ibid. p. 6 bot.
(42) From ‘blessed’ is substituted by GRA for ‘Amen’ in V and H.
(43) Cf. the prayer for going on a journey, P.B., p. 310.

chapter.title: INTRODUCTION
chapter.p: This tractate differs from Derek ’Ereẓ Rabbah in that its teachings are directed mainly at scholars. A close examination reveals that the tractate is not the work of one author. In the editions of the Talmud, chaps. V-VIII are noted as having been taken from the Maḥzor Viṭri. The author of Halakoth Gedoloth quotes the section corresponding to chaps. V-VIII under the name of Derek ’Ereẓ Zuṭa, but designates the other chapters Darkan shel Talmidë Ḥakamim, which is the opening phrase of chap. I.

It is possible that an unknown author compiled this shortened form of Derek ’Ereẓ and called it Zuṭa, and subsequently the term Rabbah may have been added to the original work to distinguish it from the smaller digest. The language and style of Zuṭa presuppose a much later date, probably after the completion of the Talmud. In some instances it is evident that the author must have had the Talmud before him. The first four chapters, however, appear to date from an earlier period. They may even have been an independent collection already in existence in the time of the Tannaïm, as they contain material which is old and often quoted as Baraithoth by the early authorities.

The different sections were put together by a later compiler, because all have the common factor that they contain exhortations to self-examination and meekness, and advocate temperance, resignation, gentleness, patience, respect for age, readiness to forgive, and the moral and social duties of a scholar.

Zuṭa is written mostly in the form of short, pithy and disconnected maxims arranged in the style of Pirḳë Aboth, except that they are anonymous. Here, too, the compiler attempted to arrange the teachings as far as possible according to external characteristics, the order followed being determined by the initial word or by the number of maxims. Precepts beginning with the same word are placed together even when unrelated in subject-matter. Especially are they so combined into groups of four, five or seven maxims, numbers which serve as an aid in memorizing the passages.

It has already been mentioned in the Introduction to Derek ’Ereẓ Rabbah that in Coronel’s edition of Ḥamishshah Ḳunṭrasim we find many passages in Kallah Rabbathi, with Gemara attached, which really belong to Derek ’Ereẓ. They are as follows: III-V in KR are similar to I-III in DEZ, while VI, VII, IX and X in KR are similar to III-XI in DER.

In chaps. I-IV disciples are exhorted to devote themselves to the study of the Torah, to be humble, modest and sin-fearing. The conclusion of chap. IV may well have been an oration delivered at the ordination of a Rabbi.
Chaps. V-VIII contain rules of conduct for various occasions such as when eating and drinking, and on social behaviour in general. Here we find repetitions of and similarities to the contents of DER.
Chap. IX consists of advice given by R. Eliezer Ha-Ḳappar to one of his disciples on a variety of subjects.
Like the Pereḳ Hashshalom, chap. X was probably a separate work which was later attached to the tractate. It deals with the signs of the coming of the Messianic era.

In DEZ the lack of redaction is more marked than in DER. In its present form it is later than DER (probably third century) and was quoted by ’Amoraïm as Baraithoth and interpreted by teachers of the fourth century. The fact that the Geonim make mention of this tractate indicates that its final redaction must have taken place before that of the Babylonian Talmud.
[In the Talmud editions the chapters are not subdivided, but for the sake of convenience the numbering of the paragraphs has been adopted mainly from Higger’s edition.]
M. GINSBERG.

chapter.title: DEREK ’EREẒ ZUṬA
CHAPTER I
chapter.p: The characteristics of a scholar are that he is meek, humble,1 alert, filled [with a desire for learning],2 modest, beloved by all, humble to the members of his household and sin-fearing. He judges a man [fairly] according to his deeds,3 and says ‘I have no desire for all the things of this world because this world is not for me’. He sits and studies,4 soiling his cloak at the feet of the scholars.5 In him no one sees any evil. He questions according to the subject-matter6 and answers to the point.7
Be like a gourd split open that the wind may enter,8 like a deep furrow which retains its water,9 like a jar coated with pitch which preserves its wine,10 and like a sponge which absorbs all.11

Be not like a wide opening which allows the wind to rush in,12 or like a narrow opening which injures the valuable [as they press through].13 Be like a doorstep on which everyone treads14 and like a low peg which is within the reach of all.15
If you suffered monetary loss, remember Job who was smitten both financially and physically. If you have been smitten physically, remember Dathan and Abiram who descended alive into Sheol.16
Do not be enticed into sin by your eyes, because enticement into sin is caused only through the eyes.17
Do not cause yourself to feel ashamed by your teeth18 lest you eat more than is good for you.19
Do not turn away from meritorious deeds and do not be attracted to heresy.20 Do not inquire of Sadducees21 lest you be drawn into Gehinnom.22

If others speak evil of you, answer them not; should it be a serious [calumny], regard it as slight. If, however, you spoke evil of others, though [the calumny] be slight, regard it as serious [and do not rest] until you go and pacify them.23
Let not your [behaviour during] adolescence be of blemished repute, for this would be derogatory to the Torah; but let it be of unblemished repute, for this would tend to glorify the Torah.24
Love and honour the Torah.25 Love your fellow-creatures and respect them.26

Set aside your will in face of the will of your fellow,27 for so did Rachel towards Leah and David towards Saul.28 Set aside your will and the will of your fellow in face of the will of Heaven, for so we find it with Jacob who did not kiss Joseph.29
Love the [term] ‘perhaps’ and hate the [expression] ‘how much?’30 R. Ḥidḳa expressed this in another way: Love the [term] ‘perhaps’ and hate the [expression] ‘what of it?’31
Keep aloof from anything that may lead to sin, from anything hideous and from whatever seems hideous,32 lest others suspect you of sin.
Slander not your fellow because there is no remedy for him who slanders his fellow.
Do not eat bread with a kohen who is an ‘am ha-’areẓ lest he give you sacred food to eat.33
Refrain from grumbling lest you grumble against others and be led into further sin.34

There were seven patriarchs with whom a divine covenant was made, viz.: Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Moses, Aaron, Phinehas and David. In connection with Abraham it is written, In that day the Lord made a covenant with Abraham saying.35 In connection with Isaac it is written, But My covenant will I establish with Isaac.36 In connection with Jacob it is written, Then will I remember My covenant with Jacob.37 In connection with Moses it is written, For after the tenor of these words I have made a covenant with thee and with Israel.38 In connection with Aaron it is written, It is an everlasting covenant of salt before the Lord.39 In connection with Phinehas it is written, And it shall be unto him, and to his seed after him, the covenant of an everlasting priesthood.40 In connection with David it is written, I have made a covenant with My chosen, I have sworn unto David My servant.41

The following seven patriarchs have gone to their eternal rest with great honour and worms and maggots had no dominion over them, viz.: Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Moses, Aaron, Miriam and their father Amram.42 Some say: Also David, as it is stated, Therefore my heart is glad, and my glory rejoiceth; my flesh also dwelleth in safety.43

There were nine44 who entered the Garden of Eden alive, viz.: Enoch the son of Yered, Elijah, the Messiah, Eliezer the servant of Abraham, Hiram, king of Tyre,45 Ebed-melech the Cushite, Jabeẓ the son of R. Judah the Prince, Bithiah the daughter of Pharaoh, and Seraḥ the daughter of Asher. Some say: Also R. Joshua b. Levi.
chapter.ftnote: (1) Cf. Aboth IV, 4 (Sonc. ed., p. 45).
(2) H reads memullaḥ, ‘bright’, as in Ḳid. 29b (Sonc. ed., p. 141). Cf. KR III, 2, p. 443, n. 13.
(3) He does not, e.g., interpret a man’s good actions as determined by ulterior motives and does not show favour where it is not deserved.
(4) H omits ‘and studies’.

(5) For meṭannef H reads mith‘aṭṭef, ‘wrapped in his cloak’, perhaps in the same sense as in Aboth I, 4 (Sonc. ed., p. 3), ‘Suffer thyself to be covered by the dust of their feet’, i.e. sit in the dust on the ground at their feet while they teach. GRA reads maṭṭil, ‘and throws his cloak in front of the feet of scholars’, perhaps for them to sit on. For a different explanation, cf. KR III, p. 444, n. 17.
(6) Cf. Shab. 3b (Sonc. ed., pp. 5f.), ‘R. Ḥiyya said to Rab: “When Rabbi is occupied with one tractate, do not ask him a question relating to another” ’.
(7) lit. ‘in accordance with the accepted decision’.
(8) Let your mind be open to receive instruction. For readings which add the negative, cf. ARN p. 85 and KR p. 449.
(9) Such a bed yields good produce; so must a scholar study continuously and raise good disciples.
(10) i.e. he must have a retentive memory.
(11) Cf. Aboth V, 18 (Sonc. ed., V, 15, p. 69).

(12) i.e. do not cultivate associates indiscriminately, yet do not be so unapproachable that worthy companionships cannot get near to you. Or, do not create a stir on entering and leaving; or, do not allow petty and frivolous ideas to enter your mind.
(13) By having to stoop or squeeze in; i.e. do not cause people worthy or your association to demean themselves or hold aloof.
(14) i.e. be ready to learn from all.
(15) lit. ‘on which all hang [their things]’.
(16) Cf. Num. XVI, 32f.
(17) Cf. Soṭah 8a (Sonc. ed., p. 35), ‘We have learnt a tradition that the evil impulse only bears sway over what a person’s eyes see’.
(18) GRA reads: ‘Do not be attracted to appetizing dishes’.
(19) lit. ‘more than is sufficient’. NY quotes a reading: ‘That you do not give them too much to eat’. Another and better variant is: ‘That you eat not’, etc., i.e. shello’ instead of shemma’.
(20) Heb. minuth, a term for the teachings of the early Jewish-Christians.

(21) A party holding views antagonistic to those of the Pharisees. They regarded only those observances obligatory which are in the written Torah and did not acknowledge what was derived by Rabbinical interpretation.
(22) By abandoning the Torah.
(23) On the evil of slander, cf. ‘Arak. 15b (Sonc. ed., pp. 86ff.).
(24) The translation follows GRA.
(25) By carrying out your duties towards God.
(26) By observing your duties towards them.
(27) When they conflict; cf. Aboth II, 4 (Sonc. ed., p. 14).
(28) Cf. KR IV, p. 454f.
(29) Cf. ibid.
(30) i.e. ‘how much harm will it do to me?’ Or, be envious of others by saying, ‘Look how much So-and-so possesses!’
(31) If I commit this trivial sin; so GRA, lit. ‘What is in it?’ it is of little consequence.
(32) Cf. Ḥul. 44b (Sonc. ed., p. 239).
(33) Cf. Ned. 20a (Sonc. ed., p. 56).
(34) Cf. below, IX, 1, p. 589.
(36) ibid. XVII, 21.
(37) Lev. XXVI, 42.
(38) Ex. XXXIV, 27.
(39) Num. XVIII, 19.
(40) ibid. XXV, 13.

(41) Ps. LXXXIX, 4. Perhaps this passage is quoted here to teach men to emulate their special characteristics. Abraham stands as the example of hospitality, Isaac of self-sacrifice, Jacob of scholarship (cf. Gen. XXV, 27, where according to Rabbinic interpretation tents means schools), Moses of meekness, Aaron of peace-making, Phinehas of zeal on behalf of God, and David of singing His praise.
(42) In B.B. 17a (Sonc. ed., p. 86), ‘and Benjamin the son of Jacob’.
(43) Ps. XVI, 9, the last words being understood as ‘unaffected by worms’.
(44) For the list, cf. KR III, p. 461, and notes
(45) It is more likely that the word king has crept in by mistake and the text should read ‘Hiram of Tyre’, who was of the tribe of Naphtali (1 Kings VII, 13f.).

chapter.title: CHAPTER II1
chapter.p: Let all your undertakings be for the name of Heaven.2 Love Heaven and fear Heaven. Hurry to perform in gladness all the precepts.

Sit before the Elders and incline your ear to hear their words. Listen carefully to the words of your fellow; be not hasty to answer but give proper thought to your words. Speak of the first [point] first and of the last [point] last, and admit the truth. Speak not before him who is greater than you in wisdom.

If you desire to study,3 do not say regarding what you do not understand, ‘I understand’.4 If you are questioned on [even] a trivial matter and you are not acquainted with it, be not ashamed to say, ‘I do not know’. If you were taught something which you did not grasp, be not ashamed to say [to the teacher], ‘Repeat it to me’ and do not pretend to yourself ‘I understood it’.

Do [good] deeds for the sake of their Maker5 and speak of them6 for their own sake.7 Make not of them a crown wherewith to adorn yourself, an axe with which to chop or a spade with which to dig.8 Undertake to study the Torah [even] in straitened circumstances and disregard any insult. A well-ordered [moral] stock-taking and a virtuous adolescence [yield] security and truth.9
Love and honour the Torah; love righteous ways, reproofs10 and uprightness. Do not run after honour; do not be presumptuous in giving decisions.

Realize that from now until tomorrow everything you have, whether it belongs to you or not, is not yours;11 because what is yours is [in reality] not yours, so how can what is not yours be yours! Of him who regards what is not his as his own, Scripture declares, Woe to him that increaseth that which is not his! How long? and that ladeth himself with many pledges!12

Accustom yourself to end on an auspicious note.13 Be modest and amiable towards all, and be humble and gentle of speech. Be quick [to render service] to a superior and easy of approach to a suppliant [for your service].14 [Be like] a good merchant15 and broad-shouldered.16

Keep aloof from anything which may bring you to sin. Recoil from [even] a minor sin that it may not lead you to a major sin. Hasten to [perform] a light precept17 and flee18 from even] a trivial transgression lest it will lead you to commit a grave transgression.

Let the honour of your fellow be as dear to you as your own.19 Show respect to all persons; say not, ‘I will flatter this man that he may give me to eat, or that he may give me to drink, or another man that he may clothe me, or yet another that he may give me shelter’.20

It is better that you be ashamed of yourself21 than be put to shame by others.22 Let not your teeth bring shame upon you,23 nor your mouth bring you to abuse.24 Let not your tongue [cause others to] curse you or your lips discredit you, and do not bow down to your words.25

If you desire to secure your fellow’s love, concern yourself with his welfare. If you want to keep away from sin, go, reflect and consider its consequences well. Take delight in the performance of a miẓwah, study hard and exult in [carrying it out] in all its details.26

If you did [someone] a great favour regard it as small, and do not say, ‘I did this good act with my own [money]’. Rather was it [from what God] had graciously given you and you should offer thanks to Heaven.27 If others have done you a slight favour regard it as if it were great, and do not say, ‘The favour was done to me because of my worthy acts’, but [say, ‘In spite of] my unworthy acts a favour was done to me’, as it is stated, And repayeth them that hate Him to their face, to destroy them.28

If you wronged someone slightly regard it as a great wrong and exclaim, ‘Woe is me, for I have sinned! Woe is me, because harm was done through me!’ If others did you a great wrong regard it as small and exclaim, ‘I suffered slightly; I deserved more’.
chapter.ftnote: (1) In H chap. II and the beginning of III are included, with many variants, in chap. I.
(2) Having a sincere and high purpose. ‘Heaven’ is a term for God.
(3) H adds ‘the Torah’.
(4) GRA reads: ‘and if he desires to teach [you a certain subject], do not say, “I have heard it” ’.

(5) i.e. God, Who decreed them (so RN to Ned. 62a); but Baḥya ibn Paḳuda, in the Introduction to his Duties of the Heart, interprets, ‘for the performance of them’, i.e. doing good for its own sake and not from an interested motive.
(6) viz. words of Torah.
(7) i.e. do not study in order to be called a Sage or Rabbi; cf. Ned. 62a (Sonc. ed., p. 197). So according to the emended text of GRA.
(8) Cf. Aboth IV, 7 (Sonc. ed., IV, 5, p. 46).

(9) GRA’s emendation may mean: ‘and your security will be real’, or, ‘your promise [which you give] will be true’. An alternative rendering of V may be: ‘[If your deeds] are well considered, and you have good breeding, your promise will be trustworthy’. Cf. the reading in KR IV, 7, p. 466.
(10) Levelled at you. Cf. Reprove a wise man, and he will love thee (Prov. IX, 8).
(11) ‘Is not yours’ is added by GRA.

(13) i.e. if you must criticize or predict misfortune, your last words should inspire confidence and comfort. Or, ‘accustom yourself to finish anything good which you began to do’, otherwise it will be credited to him who completes it. Other possible interpretations are: ‘Accustom yourself to complete a deal with goodness’, i.e. there should be no cause for resentment by the other party; ‘Accustom yourself to end everything well’.
(15) Who can distinguish between the genuine and the spurious; so know how to react towards different types of persons.

(16) i.e. able to deal with all types. H reads reḥab kesef, ‘liberal with money’. Another interpretation is: ‘Be like a good merchant (i.e. well stocked with goods so that a customer need not be kept waiting while the required article is brought from outside), and like a carrier who can carry a big load easily’. The meaning may then be: Be well stocked and carry a heavy load of learning, so that you are ready to supply knowledge to an inquirer.
(17) Cf. Ps. CXIX, 60. One is more liable to be slack and procrastinating with an easy task and so forget it; to obviate this a man should hasten to perform it as soon as it presents itself.
(18) Not merely avoid, but put as long a distance as possible between yourself and transgression.
(19) Cf. Aboth II, 15 (Sonc. ed., II, 10, p. 20).
(20) Cf. Beẓah 32b (Sonc. ed., p. 165): ‘He who is dependent on another’s table, the world is dark for him and his life is no life’.
(21) i.e. be the first to recognize your faults and rectify them.
(22) Cf. Sanh. 42a (Sonc. ed., p. 274).
(23) i.e. by spending more than you can afford on food so that you become reduced in circumstances.
(24) By drinking more than is good for you.

(25) Do not speak in haste without premeditation so that you will not have to humble yourself by asking pardon or having to retract. Other possible interpretations are: Do not regard your words as dogmatic; or, do not be self-opinionated; or, do not be a slave to your words, i.e. refrain from making a promise. H reads tishtaḥ, ‘do not spread your words’, i.e. do not be verbose.

(26) So GRA who conjectures bifraṭeha, but there is no MS. confirmation for it. A suggested reading is, shekan urebaẓ biftaḥeha, ‘Dwell and couch at the doors of [the Academy]’; i.e. by constant study make yourself familiar with the miẓwoth.
(27) For the means with which to do good.
(28) Deut. VII, 10. It is better not to receive the reward in this world but to store it up for the hereafter

chapter.title: CHAPTER III
chapter.p: Reflect before [the word] issues from your mouth. Consider your actions in accordance with good manners. Set a reward for every step you take.1 Submit to [divine] judgment and refrain from grumbling. Judge your fellow in the scale of merit2 and do not turn the scale against him.3 Rejoice in your lot and enjoy the little you have. Hate not him who reproves you. Your lot will always be blessed if you possess a bountiful eye4 and a contented soul.
Accustom your tongue to say, ‘I do not know’, lest you be led to falsehood and be apprehended.

If you are negligent in [the performance of] one precept you will eventually be negligent with another like it. If you belittle5 one precept you will eventually belittle others like it.6 If you transgress the words of the Torah intentionally, you will be made to transgress them intentionally or unintentionally.7 [58b] If you take for yourself anything which is not yours, what is yours will be taken from you.
Be careful with consecrated objects both when giving them8 and when eating them.9
Be humble and affable to all persons and particularly to the members of your household.10
The first stage of vowing leads to folly; the first stage of [ritual] uncleanness leads to idolatry; the first stage of levity with women leads to unchastity.11

If you make yourself a surety [for another] it should be with the object of paying [that surety];12 or if you become a guarantor it should be with the object of paying [the guarantee].13 If you borrow [money] it should be with the object of repaying [the loan];14 and if you lend money bear in mind that you may have to claim it15 and that you might [even] have to make a settlement.16
If one has acquired for himself a good name,17 he has acquired it for himself.18 If one has acquired for himself words of Torah, he has acquired for himself the life of the World to Come.

A shamefaced person is not apt to learn, nor is an impatient person fitted to teach. An ignorant person19 cannot be pious, an uncultured person20 sin-fearing,21 or anyone who engages much22 in business become a scholar. Put your mind, therefore, to the study of the Torah rather than to business.

Fifteen characteristics are mentioned in connection with a scholar, viz.: he is decorous in his entering and leaving,23 modest in his sitting,24 subtle25 in the fear [of God], shrewd in knowledge, discerning in his ways, [his mind] is absorptive and retentive, he answers fully,26 asks in accordance with the subject-matter27 and answers in accordance with the accepted decisions, listens [to others]28 and enlarges upon each subject, goes [to seek instruction] from the wise and learns in order to teach and practise.

Be not like the topmost lintel which is inaccessible to the feet or like the doorpost29 where anyone who sits by it is troubled and which ultimately collapses. Be like the doorstep30 on which most people tread but which remains when the whole building is in ruins.31
chapter.ftnote: (1) i.e. see that your steps are directed to perform deeds which deserve a reward.
(2) Seek a favourable interpretation of his actions even though they seem suspicious. Cf. Aboth I, 6 (Sonc. ed., p. 5).
(3) Take a charitable view of his deeds.
(4) Well disposed, generous; cf. Prov. XXII, 9.
(5) lit. ‘speak lightly of’.
(6) V adds in brackets ‘and you have done nothing for your trouble’ in fulfilling the precepts since you regard them of small worth.
(7) Circumstances will make it impossible for you to perform the precepts even if you are desirous of making good former lapses.
(8) To the kohen or Levite; do not withhold them.
(9) They must be eaten in a state of ritual cleanliness.

(10) According to the text emended by GRA. V and H read: ‘Be humble and affable to return [a salutation] to your acquaintance. Be lowly of spirit with all men, with the members of your household more than with all men; and if you grumble and fight with your household, your end is for Gehinnom’.
(11) Cf. Ned. 20a (Sonc. ed., p. 56).
(12) If called upon to do so.
(13) Therefore do not offer to become a guarantor lightheartedly.
(14) So borrow only if you are in a position to repay.
(15) And have difficulty in collecting it.
(16) And lose part of the sum loaned. Another reading is lehafsid, ‘lose the sum’.
(17) Cf. Prov. XXII, 1; Eccl. VII, 1; Aboth II, 8 (Sonc. ed., II, 7, p. 17).
(18) In the sense that, unlike any other possession, it cannot be transmitted to another.
(19) For this passage, cf. Aboth II, 6 (Sonc. ed., II, 5, p. 15, nn. 3-8).
(20) One devoid of knowledge and ethical principles.
(21) He may avoid sin from fear of the consequences but not from ethical motives.
(22) And leaves little or no time for study.
(23) ‘And leaving’ is inserted by GRA.
(24) Does not rush to occupy a front seat.
(25) In devising ways of manifesting his fear; cf. Ber. 17a (Sonc. ed., p. 102).
(26) He takes a considerable time before answering.
(27) Cf. above I, 1, n. 6.
(28) Added by GRA.
(29) lit. ‘the middle [post]’.
(30) lit. ‘the nethermost post’.

(31) Referring to the quality of humility. GRA emends the text to read: ‘Be not like a lintel which can injure the face (by a person crashing into it), nor like the doorpost which can hurt the legs and ultimately collapses; but be like the doorstep on which most people tread and which remains in its place even when the whole building collapses’.

chapter.title: CHAPTER IV
chapter.p: Scholars lend dignity to a company,1 but not so ignorant men.

He who occupies himself [only] with the study of Scripture is but of indifferent merit;2 with Mishnah is meritorious and rewarded for it; with Talmud there can be nothing more meritorious. Yet run always to the Mishnah more than to the Shas.3

Do your [teaching of] Torah gratuitously and accept no remuneration for it; because the Omnipresent gave it gratuitously4 and one may not take a fee for the [teaching of] words of Torah. If you should accept remuneration for the [teaching of] words of Torah, you will consequently destroy [the moral constitution of] the entire world. Say not, ‘I have no money’, since all money is His,5 as it is stated, Mine is the silver, and Mine the gold, saith the Lord of hosts.6

If you practise charity you will merit wealth; and if you merited wealth practise charity with it. While you still possess it [live in such a manner that you] gain through it this world and also inherit the World to Come; for if you do not practise charity with it, it will suddenly disappear, as it is stated, Wilt thou set thine eyes upon it? It is gone.7

Say not, ‘That man is wise8 but I am not wise’,9 because you did not attend [upon scholars] as he did.10 Say not, ‘That man is rich but I am not rich’,11 because not everyone has the privilege to enjoy two tables.12 Say not, ‘That man is handsome but I am ugly’, because at the hour of death man becomes carrion; furthermore [animal] carrion may be sold to a Gentile or may be given as a gift, but no one cares for human carrion.13 Say not, ‘That man is righteous but I am not righteous, because both of you are destined to give an account before the Most High. Say not, ‘That man is strong but I am weak’,14 because strength is only with [them who fulfil] the Torah, as it is stated, Bless the Lord, ye angels of His, ye mighty in strength, that fulfil His word, hearkening unto the voice of His word.15

Take these words to heart: Know whence you came, and whither you go, and before Whom you are destined to give an account and reckoning.16 Eye not [enviously] another’s wealth because it undermines the gates of heaven.17
Suffer not your ears to listen to idle chatter, because they are burnt first of [all] the organs.18 Eye not [enviously] another’s wealth, because it may cast you into thick darkness and gloom.

Let not your mouth repeat calumny, because it is the first to be summoned for judgment. Let there not be found with you calumny, any evil thing or anything stolen, because all your limbs will testify against you. Let not your feet hurry you to commit a sin lest the Angel of Death come to meet you.19

Be not afraid of an earthly court because the witnesses against you are lovers of money,20 but fear the heavenly Court because there are witnesses above who testify against you, and moreover [your sins] proclaim war on you incessantly.
If you fulfilled My words joyfully, My heavenly household will go out to greet you and I will greet you with the words, ‘Enter in peace’.

Because your eyes have not looked [enviously] on another’s wealth, they will shine amidst thick darkness and gloom, as it is stated, Then shall thy light rise in darkness, and thy gloom be as the noon-day.21 Because your ears have not listened to idle chatter they will hear [words of] peace for you in [this] world and cause you to hear them in the World to Come, as it is stated, And thine ears shall hear a word behind thee, saying: ‘This is the way, walk ye in it; when ye turn to the right hand, and when ye turn to the left.’22 Because your mouth did not recount calumny, all your adversaries will be slain by it.23 Because your mouth occupied itself with [the teaching of] the Torah, all who are worthy of a blessing will bless themselves through it.24 Because you withheld your hands from plunder, what can evil persons do to you? Because you did not close your hands from almsgiving, what can violent persons25 do to you? Because your feet did not hurry you to commit a sin, what can the Angel of Death do to you?
I admonish you with these words of Mine. You can do as you please26 but do not say, ‘I was not warned’.
chapter.ftnote: (1) Or, ‘behave well in a company’.
(2) lit. ‘it is meritorious and not meritorious’, because the Written Torah can only be understood with the aid of the Oral Torah.
(3) Because it is more easily absorbed. For this passage, cf. B.M. 33a, b (Sonc. ed., p. 206).

(4) Cf. Ned. 36b-37a (Sonc. ed., p. 113). As Moses taught the Elders gratuitously so must they pass their teaching on to others without pay. According to the Talmud, loc. cit., this does not apply to Scripture, for the teaching of which a fee is allowed.
(5) He will provide you with sustenance without having to take payment for teaching.
(6) Hag. II, 8.
(7) Prov. XXIII, 5.
(8) Endowed by nature with great intellectual gifts.
(9) i.e. I am not so endowed and therefore it is useless for me to study.
(10) One must make every effort to gain knowledge; cf. Meg. 6b (Sonc. ed., p. 30).
(11) Although I am more God-fearing than he.
(12) i.e. enjoy prosperity in this world and the bliss of the hereafter.
(13) So in death the difference between the handsome and the ugly ceases to exist.
(14) And therefore unable to control my sinful desires.
(15) Ps. CIII, 20. So occupy yourself with the study of the Torah and you will increase moral strength.
(16) Cf. Aboth III, 1 (Sonc. ed., p. 26).
(17) To the envious the luminaries of heaven shine but dimly.

(18) lit. ‘of the limbs’. From hearing unworthy or idle talk he may proceed to speak unworthy or idle words and then do unworthy or idle acts. The ear is, accordingly, the first organ to ‘catch fire’; cf. Keth. 5b (Sonc. ed., p. 18).
(19) Lest you die before you make atonement.

(20) i.e. subject to bribery. [H. Loewe, Rabbinic Anthology, p. 587, in agreement with a variant cited in H, omits the negative and renders: ‘Fear the earthly tribunal, even though witnesses against you can be bribed; fear yet more the heavenly tribunal’.]
(21) Isa. LVIII, 10.
(22) ibid. XXX, 21.
(23) So GRA.
(24) They will wish for no greater blessing than will come to you for what you have earned by your mouth.
(25) lit. ‘owners of an arm’, the emendation of GRA. V has ‘owners of silver and gold’.
(26) Since man is endowed with free will.

chapter.title: CHAPTER V
chapter.p: A scholar should not eat standing, lick his fingers or belch in the presence of his fellow. He talks little, jokes little, sleeps in moderation, is frugal in pleasures and minimizes ‘[Yes], yes’ or ‘No, no’.1
A man should always make a point of knowing with whom he is sitting or standing, with whom he is sitting at table, with whom he is conversing and who is his co-signatory to a deed.2
By four things are scholars3 recognizable: by their cup,4 their purse,5 their temper6 and by their attire.7 Some say: Also by their speech.8

The adornment of [knowledge of] Torah is wisdom, the adornment of wisdom is humility, the adornment of humility is fear [of God], the adornment of the fear [of God] is the performance of meritorious deeds, the adornment of the performance of meritorious deeds is modesty.9

A man should not be awake when among those who are asleep or asleep when among those who are awake. He should not weep when among those who are joyous or be joyous when among those who weep. He should not be sitting when among those who are standing or standing when among those who are sitting. He should not study Scripture when among those who study Mishnah or study Mishnah when among those who study Scripture. This is the general rule: A man should not act differently from the practice of his fellow-men.
chapter.ftnote: (1) Cf. Shebu. 36a (Sonc. ed., p. 211) where the repetition of ‘yes’ and ‘no’ is regarded as an oath. It may perhaps also mean to be sparing in making promises.
(2) Cf. Sanh. 23a (Sonc. ed., p. 131).
(3) In ‘Erub. 65b (Sonc. ed., p. 455) the wording is: ‘By three things may a person’s’, etc., not only a scholar.
(4) By the amount of liquor they consume.
(5) By what they spend their money on.
(6) In the Heb. there is an effective alliteration: kis (purse), kos (cup) and ka‘as (temper). The last indicates self-control.
(7) A scholar was expected to maintain cleanliness in his attire. Cf. Shab. 114a (Sonc. ed., p. 557).
(8) ‘Erub. adds ‘also by their laughter’ and omits ‘by their attire’.
(9) i.e. the unostentatious manner in which they are done.

chapter.title: CHAPTER VI
chapter.p: Four things are unbecoming to scholars. One should not start out on a journey by night,1 go out scented,2 be the last to enter the Synagogue,3 or frequent the society of ignorant persons.

On entering the elder precedes, on leaving the younger precedes;4 when ascending a staircase the elder precedes, when descending a staircase the younger precedes; [when entering] a Council Chamber the elder precedes; [when entering] a prison the younger precedes; to pronounce a blessing5 the elder takes precedence. The passer-by greets one who is sitting.

No person should sit down at table to eat before his elders [have taken their seat]. When cutting off a piece of bread [for Grace before meals] one should do so from the part that is baked into a crust.6 When one is about to eat a leek or onion, he should begin to eat from the leaves.7 One should not take hold of a loaf, bite a piece off and place it back upon the table. When about to drink water in public, one should turn his face away and drink.8
A man should not be a caviller, trickster or tippler. He should overlook an insult and not glorify himself by his fellow’s humiliation.9

The first stage in committing a sin is impure thought, the second is scoffing, the third haughtiness, the fourth cruelty, the fifth idleness, the sixth causeless hatred and the seventh an evil eye.10 That is what Solomon said, When he speaketh fair, believe him not; for there are seven abominations in his heart.11
chapter.ftnote: (1) Either because of danger or not to arouse suspicion of immoral intention.
(2) According to Ber. 43b (Sonc. ed., p. 266) this applies to scenting one’s clothes and in a place where people are suspected of sodomy.
(3) Ber. loc. cit., reads ‘Beth Hammidrash’.
(4) Or, ‘the more important … the less important’. Cf. Ber. 61a (Sonc. ed., p. 381): ‘In conferring honour we commence with the greatest’.
(5) At the beginning of a meal or to recite Grace after it.
(6) Cf. above, p. 553.
(7) And not from the top; cf. above, p. 553.
(8) Because it is customary for a scholar to exercise privacy both in eating and drinking.
(9) Cf. Meg. 28a (Sonc. ed., p. 168).
(10) An envious nature.
(11) Prov. XXVI, 25.

chapter.title: CHAPTER VII
chapter.p: There are seven characteristics in an uncultured man1 and seven in a wise man. A wise man does not speak before one who is greater than he in wisdom and in number,2 does not enter into the midst of the words of his fellow,3 is not hasty to answer; he asks in accordance with the subject-matter and answers in accordance with the accepted decision, speaks on the first [point] first and on the last [point] last, concerning what he has not heard he says, ‘I have not heard it’,4 and acknowledges the truth.5 The reverse of these are in an uncultured man.
A scholar must be modest in eating, drinking, washing, anointing,6 putting his shoes on, walking, his attire, [the modulation of] his voice, expectorating7 and good works.8

As a bride keeps herself secluded all the time she is in her father’s house and only makes herself known when she goes out9 [as if] to say, ‘Anyone who can testify anything against me,10 let him come and testify’, so must a scholar be modest in his [good] deeds but renowned for his conduct. He must seek truth and not falsehood, honesty and not robbery, meekness and not haughtiness, peace and not conflict, the counsel of the Elders and not the counsel of the young.11 He should rather walk behind a lion than behind a woman.12

He honours the wise13 [and does not show disrespect towards them.] What is meant by ‘honours the wise’? He gives him food and drink, dresses him and puts his shoes on for him, leads him in and out. This applies to both a teacher14 and a Sage.15 What is meant by ‘showing disrespect’? He must not sit in his [accustomed] place, speak16 in his stead or contradict his words.

R. Ḥiyya taught: Silence is good for the wise and how much more so for fools; and so did Solomon say, Even a fool, when he holdeth his peace, is counted wise.17 It is not necessary to say, ‘When a wise man holdeth his peace’.18
chapter.ftnote: (1) Heb. golem. Cf. Aboth V, 10 (Sonc. ed., V, 7, pp. 64f.).
(2) Of years.
(3) i.e. does not interrupt.
(4) Cf. above, p. 571, n. 4.
(5) He does not consider it inconsistent with his dignity to admit when he is in the wrong.
(6) i.e. rubbing with oil after a bath.
(7) i.e. clearing his throat.
(8) He should perform them unostentatiously.
(9) Leaves her father’s house for the wedding ceremony.
(10) Against her virtue.
(11) Cf. Meg. 31b (Sonc. ed., p. 192): ‘If old men say to you “Throw down” and young men say to you “Build up”, do the former’.
(12) To avoid unchaste thoughts.
(13) Added by GRA.
(14) A variant is ‘a father’ in agreement with Ḳid. 31b (Sonc. ed., p. 154).
(15) Although he is not his teacher.
(16) In Ḳid. ‘stand’; cf. also Midrash Rabbah, Num., XV, 17 (Sonc. ed., p. 660).
(17) Prov. XVII, 28.
(18) Because a wise man knows when to be silent.

chapter.title: CHAPTER VIII
chapter.p: Be pliable like the reed upon which the wind can blow from every direction it chooses;1 for the Torah can only endure with him who is humble in spirit.

Why is the Torah likened to water?2 It is to teach you that as water does not flow [from a lower] to a higher level but [from a higher level] to a lower, so the Torah endures only with him who is humble in spirit.3
Keep aloof from anything hideous and from whatever resembles it,4 and draw near to what [59a] is becoming and all that resembles it. Beware of one who counsels you in his own interest.5

Who waives his right to retribution6 is forgiven all his sins, as it is stated, Who is a God like unto Thee, that pardoneth the iniquity, and passeth by the transgression,7 [which means,] who is forgiven iniquity? He who passed by transgression [against himself].8

Whoever abases [mithnabbel] himself in connection with words of Torah9 will in the end be exalted on its account, as it is stated If thou hast done foolishly [nabalta] in lifting up thyself,10 [which means,] if you have abased yourself for words of the Torah, in the end you will be exalted.
He who seeks [knowledge of] the Torah, added wisdom will be given to him,11 as it is stated, Give to a wise man, and he will be yet wiser.12
So long as a person is a sinner he has fear of his fellow-creatures; but so long as he is not a sinner his fellow-creatures have fear of him.13

Whoever makes light of a single point of the Torah is liable to kareth, as it is stated, Because he hath despised the word of the Lord … that soul shall utterly be cut off.14 And he who makes light of the [precept of] washing the hands will be uprooted from the world.15

Whoever is not shamefaced will readily sin, as it is stated, The show of their countenance doth witness against them;16 but he who experiences shame17 will not readily sin, as it is stated, [And Moses said unto the people: ‘Fear not; for God is come to prove you] and that His fear may be before you, that ye sin not.18

It is unbecoming for a host to eat in the presence of his guest [without inviting him to join him]; it is more unbecoming for one guest to bring in another guest;19 it is still more unbecoming when one eats in the presence of a scholar. More unbecoming than these three is for a guest to cause trouble to another guest.20 R. Meir said: [Most unbecoming of all is] he who takes [food] set before him and gives it to the host’s child; for it once happened that [through such an action] a host killed his child.21
He who humbles himself will understand his instruction and whoever transgresses the words of the Sages deserves kareth.22 Whoever [continually] declares [others] unfit is [himself] unfit.23

R. ‘Aḳiba said: The beginning of my attendance upon the Sages24 was this. I was once on a journey when I came across a meth miẓwah which I carried about four mil until I brought it to a cemetery and buried it there. When I appeared before R. Eliezer and R.
