Joshua and told them what had happened, they said to me, ‘Every step you took is reckoned against you as if you had shed blood’.25 I said to them, ‘If, in a case where I intended to perform a meritorious act I have made myself liable like a wicked person, how much more [will I deserve punishment] when I have no [meritorious] intention! From that moment I did not let an opportunity pass to minister to the Sages’.26 He used to say: One who does not minister to the Sages deserves death.
He who enters a bath-house should first remove his cloak, then the shoes, then the trousers and then the shirt.27
He who is about to enter a bath-house should respect28 the one who is about to leave,29 and the one who is about to leave a privy must respect the one who is about to enter.30
chapter.ftnote: (1) Cf. DER IV, p. 545.
(2) Cf. Isa. LV, 1, Ho, everyone that thirsteth, come ye for water.
(3) It flows away from him who is haughty; cf. Ta‘an. 7a (Sonc. ed., p. 27).
(4) Cf. Ḥul. 44b (Sonc. ed., p. 239) and ARN II, 2, p. 18.
(5) lit. ‘in his own way’; cf. Sanh. 76b (Sonc. ed., p. 517).
(6) lit. ‘passes by his measures’, i.e. forgoes his right to exact punishment.
(7) Micah VII, 18.
(8) Cf. R.H. 17a (Sonc. ed., p. 67).
(9) i.e. is not ashamed to ask questions which may at first sound foolish; cf. Ber. 63b (Sonc. ed., p. 402).
(10) Prov. XXX, 32.
(11) Following the emended text of GRA.
(12) ibid. IX, 9.
(13) They are afraid of his knowing about their guilt.
(15) Added by GRA. Cf. Soṭah 4b (Sonc. ed., p. 16).
(16) Isa. III, 9.
(17) i.e. who is not callous, but is self-conscious when he is doing wrong.
(18) Ex. XX, 17; cf. Ned. 20a (Sonc. ed., p. 57).
(19) Cf. B.B. 98b (Sonc. ed., p. 410), a saying attributed to Ben Sira.
(20) GRA reads ‘his host’.
(22) GRA reads: ‘He who attends upon scholars comprehends his instruction, and whoever does not comprehend his instruction deserves death’.
(24) Cf. Semaḥoth IV, 16, above p. 342.
(25) He should have buried the corpse where he found it.
(26) He learned by associating with scholars.

(27) This rendering is in accordance with GRA and H. V reads: ‘If [the pupil] brought [the Sages] into a bath-house, he should first remove the cloak’, etc., referring to the duty to minister to the learned.
(28) By giving way.
(29) By not hurrying him unduly
(30) He must hurry so as not to keep the other waiting; cf. DER X, 2, p. 561.

chapter.title: CHAPTER IX1
chapter.p: R. Eliezer Ha-Ḳappar said: Keep aloof from making complaints, because if you complain against others you will be led to further sin.2
Love him who reproves you so that you may increase knowledge; and hate him who flatters3 you so that your knowledge may not decrease.

Love the Synagogue that you may receive your reward daily.4 Love the House of Study that your children may come to study the Torah.5 Love the poor that your children may not come to that condition. Love meekness that you may complete [the number of] your years.6 Love the pious7 that you may be saved from the Angel of Darkness.8

Be heedful in the reading of the Shema‘ and the ‘Amidah9 that you may be saved from the judgment of Gehinnom. Let your house be open wide10 that you may have no lack of food. Be heedful not to shut the doors of your house when you sit down to eat and drink, because the doors of your house may bring you to poverty.10a

Be heedful to honour11 your wife12 that she become not barren. Be happy when sufferings come upon you, because they deliver you from the punishment of Gehinnom.13 Rejoice at your table when the hungry benefit from it so that your life may be prolonged in this world and in the World to Come.

Be happy when you donate gifts [of charity] quietly14 so that the anger [of the Angel of Death]15 may be diverted from you, as it is stated, A gift in secret pacifieth anger, and a present in the bosom strong wrath.16

If you have restrained yourself from doing a good deed, the Angel of Death will come to meet you.17 If you have exerted yourself18 in connection with the poor or the fulfilment of a precept, there will be fulfilled in you Blessed shalt thou be when thou comest in, and blessed shalt thou be when thou goest out.19 If you guarded your mouth from slander, all the days of your life will be spent in peace; but if you were presumptuous towards a person greater than yourself, you will ultimately be stricken with skin disease.20

If you withheld yourself from performing a meritorious act and occupied yourself with a sinful act, your wife will ultimately die of a stroke, as it is stated, Son of man, behold, I take away from thee the desire of thine eyes with a stroke.21

If you bestirred yourself to honour a Sage, you will have perfect sons and daughters; and if you bestirred yourself to honour a poor man, you will have children in Israel who are learned in Torah and perform the commandments. If you were present at the death of a Sage, do not leave him until you have accompanied him to the grave,22 so that when you die you may enter and rest in the grave in peace.23

If you notice that your fellow’s face is worried because he has become poor, do not send him away empty-handed, in order that you may be delivered from all evil;24 as it is stated, Whoso keepeth the commandment shall know no evil thing.25 If you have given him a loan in the time of his emergency, there will be fulfilled in you Then shalt thou call, and the Lord will answer.26

If you have humbled yourself, the Holy One, blessed be He, will lift you up; if you have exalted yourself before your fellow, the Holy One, blessed be He, will set you low. Should people strive27 with you, whether it be in the House of Study or at a social gathering,28 make peace with them, so that when you leave them29 they may speak well of you, as was spoken of Phinehas the son of Eleazar.30

And so used R. Eleazar Ha-Ḳappar to say: Love peace and hate dissension. Great is peace, for even if [Israel] were to practise idolatry but maintained peace among themselves, the Divine Presence, as it were, would be unable to do them harm, as it is stated, Ephraim is joined to idols; let him alone.31 But if there is dissension between them, what is stated of them? Their heart is divided; now shall they bear their guilt.32

A house in which is dissension will ultimately be destroyed. A Synagogue [in which is dissension] will ultimately be turned into a place of idolatry.33 If two scholars reside in the same city who have set up separate Courts of Law and dissension occurs between them, they will ultimately die [prematurely].34 Abba Saul said: Dissension between separate Courts of Law is the ruination of the world.

Abba Isi b. Joḥanan said in the name of Samuel the Small: This world is likened to a person’s eyeball: the white of the eye [corresponds to] the ocean which surrounds the whole world; the iris to the [inhabited] world; the pupil of the eye to Jerusalem; the face in the pupil to the Temple. May it be rebuilt speedily in our days and in the days of all Israel, Amen.
chapter.ftnote: (1) In H this chapter is the continuation of the preceding.
(2) To hatred, quarrel and slander; cf. above I, 15, p. 569.
(3) lit. ‘honours, praises’. Praise may discourage one from further study.
(4) Cf. Ber. 8a (Sonc. ed., p. 39).
(5) Copying the example of their parents.
(6) So GRA. V reads ‘fill your hands’; H ‘your days’, reading yameka for yadeka.
(7) By emulating them.
(8) According to NY he is so called because the Angel of Death makes the face of man black. H reads ‘Angel of Death’.
(9) To recite them at the proper time and with devotion; cf. Aboth II, 18 (Sonc. ed., II, 13, p. 22).
(10) ibid. I, 5 (Sonc. ed., p. 4).
(10a) They will shut out prosperity from you.
(11) GRA omits ‘to honour’ and reads ‘with respect to your wife’, alluding to conjugal rights. Cf. B.M. 59a (Sonc. ed., p. 352).
(12) A wife is sensitive and quick to feel and resent a hurt.
(13) So GRA. If sufferings are interpreted as punishment for wrongdoing they induce a feeling of remorse and lead to repentance.
(14) lit. ‘from your house’.
(15) GRA omits ‘the Angel of Death’ and it may refer to God’s anger.
(16) Prov. XXI, 14.
(17) And you will be prevented from making good the omission.
(18) lit. ‘scattered your foot generously’.
(19) Deut. XXVIII, 6.
(20) Cf. ‘Arak. 16a (Sonc. ed., p. 91): ‘Because of seven things the plague of leprosy is incurred: These are: slander’, etc. Cf. the incident of Miriam (Num. XII, 1ff.).
(21) Ezek. XXIV, 16.
(22) Cf. Shab. 105b (Sonc. ed., p. 509) for rites to be observed on the death of a Sage.
(23) From ‘so that’ is added by GRA instead of V which inserts here the last clause of §11.
(24) ‘In order … evil’ is added by GRA.
(25) Eccl. VIII, 5.
(26) Isa. LVIII, 9.
(27) So GRA; V ‘honour’.
(28) lit. ‘in a sitting [for study] or in a reclining [at a meal]’.
(29) lit. ‘on your return [home]’.
(30) Cf. Num. XXV, 10-13. The translation follows GRA instead of V’s senseless ‘so that he may come and rest upon your bed’.

(31) Hos. IV, 17. Cf. Midrash Rabbah, Num., XI, 7 (Sonc. ed., p. 441) where the reading is: ‘The Holy One, blessed be He, as it were, says: Satan shall not touch them’. In Midrash Rabbah, Gen., XXXVIII, 6 (Sonc. ed., p. 306) the version is: ‘The Holy One, blessed be He, says: I have no dominion over them’.
(33) So GRA; cf. Yeb. 96b (Sonc. ed., p. 660). V reads: ‘The Sages said: When there is dissension in a Synagogue it will be cut in pieces’.
(34) Cf. Soṭah 49a (Sonc. ed., p. 263).

chapter.title: CHAPTER X
chapter.p: R. Simeon b. Joḥai said: As for the seven-year cycle in which the son of David will come, in the first year will be fulfilled And I caused it to rain upon one city, and caused it not to rain upon another city;1 in the second, the arrows of hunger will be sent forth;2 in the third there will be a severe famine in the course of which men, women and children will die, pious men and miracle workers become scarce, and the Torah will be forgotten by its students;3 in the fourth, there will be partial plenty;4 in the fifth, great plenty when men will eat, drink and rejoice and the Torah will be restored to its disciples;5 in the sixth [there will be heard heavenly] sounds;6 in the seventh, wars [will be waged]; and at the expiration of the septennate the son of David will come.7

Rabban Gamaliel said: In the generation when the son of David comes, the house of assembly8 will be a brothel, Galilee will be in ruins, and the inhabitants of Gablan9 will wander about [begging] from city to city without experiencing pity; the wisdom of scribes will be in disfavour and God-fearing men despised, the leaders of the people10 will be dog-faced;11 truth will be lacking, and he that departs from evil will be regarded as demented.

R. Nehorai said: In the generation when the son of David comes, young men will insult the old, the aged will stand up before youth,12 a daughter will rise up against her mother and a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law,13 and a son will not be abashed in his father’s14 presence.

R. Nehemiah said: In the generation when the son of David comes, impudence will increase, esteem will be perverted,15 the vine will yield its fruit yet wine will be dear,16 and the government will be converted to heresy17 with none to reprove. 2. R. Jose said: Two are better than three,18 and alas for the one thing19 which goes and does not return. He used to say: We do not appoint as leader of the community one who is a blood-letter,20 a tanner or a builder;21 nor do we appoint any of them as an administrator.22 He used to say: They who dwell in villages and they who travel in the wilderness lead a miserable life,23 their money is not secure,24 and their children are not their own.25

Four peruṭoth26 are without a sign of blessing.27 They are: the wages of scribes,28 the wages of interpreters,29 money that came from overseas,30 and he who marries for the sake of a dowry.31 These will not be able to bequeath anything to their children or grandchildren.

There are some who marry for sexual indulgence, and there are some who marry for money. There are some who marry for social advancement32 and there are some who marry with sincere intention.33 Of him who marries for sexual indulgence Scripture declares, They have dealt treacherously against the Lord, for they have begotten strange children.34 Of him who marries for money Scripture declares, Now shall the new moon devour them with their portions,35 [implying] a month comes and a month goes and their money is gone. He who marries for social advancement will ultimately be deposed from his high position; but he who marries with sincere intention will ultimately have children who will be saviours of Israel.

The adornment of God is mankind; the adornment of mankind is the Torah;36 the adornment of the Torah is wisdom; the adornment of old age is grey hair; the adornment of youth is the fear of sin; the adornment of an ‘am ha-’areẓ is a curse.37

He who learnt Scripture but not Mishnah is a boor; he who learnt Mishnah and not Scripture is an ‘am ha-’areẓ;38 he who learnt Scripture and Mishnah but has not expounded them is a scholar; he who learnt Scripture and Mishnah and expounded them is an intelligent man; and as for him who learnt neither Scripture nor Mishnah, better for him if he had not been born.

One who has wisdom but no fear [of God] is contemptible;39 [one who has] fear [of God] but no wisdom is poor;40 [one who has] neither wisdom nor fear [of God] is thoroughly wicked; [one who has] wisdom and fear [of God] is thoroughly righteous.
chapter.ftnote: (1) Amos IV, 7. There will be famine in one place and plenty in another.
(2) i.e. not actual famine, but the first signs of it, nobody being completely satisfied.
(3) Through lack of food.
(4) lit. ‘plenty and no plenty’.
(5) ‘And the Torah’, etc., is added by GRA.
(6) Either heavenly voices announcing the advent of the Messiah or the blasts of the great shofar; cf. Isa. XXVII, 13.
(7) Cf. Sanh. 97a (Sonc. ed., pp. 654f.) for this and the following passages; also Midrash to Song of Songs II, 13 (Sonc. ed., p. 126).
(8) Where scholars gather.
(9) The Jews living along the borders of the Land of Israel. Gablan is to be read for Galil, ‘Galilee’, as in Sanh., loc. cit. (Sonc. ed., p. 655, n. 4).
(10) lit. ‘the face of the generation’.
(11) Shameless.
(12) To do them honour.
(13) Cf. Micah VII, 6.
(14) So GRA and H. V has ‘mother’s’.
(15) No one will esteem another. Or, even the nobility and most honoured will degenerate.
(16) Drunkenness will increase so that in spite of the abundant yield there will be a scarcity.

(17) Heb. minuth. By ‘the kingdom’ the Roman Empire is meant, and the statement is a remarkable forecast by R. Nehemiah (100 C.E.) of the conversion of Rome to Christianity under Constantine the Great in 313 C.E. Cf. however, Herford, Christianity in Talmud and Midrash, pp. 207ff., Sanh., loc. cit. (Sonc. ed., p. 656, n. 4).
(18) So GRA. The two legs in youth are better than the three, i.e. the addition of a stick in old age for walking.
(19) Youth.
(20) lit. ‘a scraper’, one who makes incisions in the skin to draw off blood.
(21) Because their occupation is mean; cf. Ḳid. 82a (Sonc. ed., p. 424).
(22) ibid.
(23) lit. ‘their life is no life’.
(24) lit. ‘not their money’; they can easily be robbed.
(25) Their wives are not safe from attack; cf. ‘Erub. 55b (Sonc. ed., p. 391).
(26) i.e. the monies earned from the four occupations enumerated.
(27) It is therefore not advisable to engage in them.
(28) Cf. Pes. 50b (Sonc. ed., p. 246) where the reference is to writers of Torah-scrolls, tefillin and mezuzoth; if they become wealthy they would no longer write them.

(29) Officials who delivered the Sabbath lectures of the Rabbi to the congregation. The Rabbi whispered his statement to the interpreter, who elaborated it to the people. It includes the translators of the weekly lections of the Torah on the Sabbath in the Synagogue. The reason given in Pes. is that it appears like wages for Sabbath work.
(30) Danger attended the transport of freights by sea and one might suffer loss.
(31) Pes. has instead ‘the profit of orphans’, i.e. derived by trading with trust money.
(32) lit. ‘greatness’.
(33) lit. ‘for the sake of heaven’, to fulfil the command to procreate.

(34) Hos. V, 7. In Ḳid. 70a (Sonc.ed., p.354) the verse is applied to one who marries for money and it states that ‘he will have unworthy children’, the word strange meaning ‘strange from the ways of decency’.
(35) ibid.
(36) So GRA. V has ‘their garments’; cf. Shab. 113b (Sonc. ed., p. 556).

(37) The opposite of ‘blessing’ which he deserves for the neglect of the Torah. The meaning is obscure. Two possibilities suggest themselves. 1) That he deserves nothing more than a curse (and this reflects the reciprocal hostility we find elsewhere between the ע״ה and the scholar. 2) That a curse comes most readily to the lips of an ע״ה.
(38) The reading in Ber. 47b (Sonc. ed., p. 287) and Soṭah 22a (Sonc. ed., p. 110) is: ‘Even if he learnt Scripture and Mishnah but did not attend upon Rabbinical scholars, he is an ‘am ha-’areẓ’.
(39) Or his knowledge is contemptible, because he does not use it for a good purpose.
(40) The clause is added by GRA. He lacks what is essential; or, his fear of God is of poor quality.

chapter.title: INTRODUCTION
chapter.p: In the edition of the Wilna Talmud, Derek ’Ereẓ Zuṭa consists of eleven chapters, the last being entitled Pereḳ Hashshalom. It is, however, not part of that tractate but a separate collection of dicta on the theme of Peace.

The probability is that it was appended to the tractate because it concludes with a description of the state of degeneracy which will precede the coming of the Messiah, whose advent will bring abiding peace to the world. Or it was attached to chap. IX, originally the end of the tractate, which touches on the blessings of peace.
No information is available on the authorship and date of this chapter.
M. GINSBERG.

chapter.title: PEREḲ HASHSHALOM
chapter.p: R. Joshua b. Levi said: Great is peace, for peace is to the world as leaven is to dough. Had not the Holy One, blessed be He, given peace to the earth, the sword and the beast would have robbed the world1 of its children. Whence2 [do we know this]? From what is written, And I will give peace in the land … and I will cause evil beasts to cease out of the land, neither shall the sword go through your land;3 and land means nothing else than Israel, as it is stated, And all nations shall call you happy; for ye shall be a delightsome land.4 [And so Solomon declared,] One generation passeth away, and another generation cometh; and the earth abideth for ever:5 Solomon said:6 Although a generation passes away and another generation comes, one kingdom goes and another kingdom comes, one decree passes away and a new decree is imposed upon Israel,7 the earth abideth for ever, i.e. Israel will abide for ever,8 they are not forsaken nor will they be forsaken, they are not destroyed nor will they be destroyed, as it is stated, For I the Lord change not; and ye, O sons of Jacob are not consumed9—as I have not changed nor will I change, so you, the House of Jacob, are not destroyed and will not be destroyed, but [as it is stated], But ye that did cleave unto the Lord your God are alive every one of you this day.10

There11 they taught: Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel used to say: By three things does the world endure: justice, truth and peace.12 R. Muna said: The three are one, because if justice is done, truth has been effected and peace brought about; and all three are mentioned in one verse, as it is stated, Execute the judgment of truth and peace in your gates,13 [indicating that] wherever justice is done peace is to be found.

R. Joshua said: Great is peace, for when Israel stood [at Sinai] and declared, All that the Lord hath spoken we will do, and obey,14 [59b] the Holy One, blessed be He, rejoiced in them and gave them His Torah and blessed them with peace, as it is stated, The Lord will give strength15 unto His people; the Lord will bless His people with peace.16

Hezekiah said: Great is peace, for in connection with all other precepts in the Torah it is written, If thou see,17 etc., If thou meet,18 If there chance,19 If thou buildest,20 [implying,] if a precept comes to your hand, you are bound to perform it;21 but what is written in connection with peace? Seek peace, and pursue it,22 [meaning,] seek it in your place and follow it to another place.23

Hezekiah said: Great is peace, for with regard to all the journeyings [of Israel] it is written, And they journeyed … and they pitched,24 [the plural number implying that] they journeyed in dissension and encamped in dissension. When, however, they came to Mount Sinai, they all became one encampment, [as it is stated,] And there Israel encamped25 before the mount.26 The Holy One, blessed be He, said, ‘Since Israel hate dissension and love peace and became one encampment, this is the time when I will give them My Torah’.

Adonijah was slain only because he was a quarrelsome person,27 and it is permissible to slander a quarrelsome person; for thus did Nathan the prophet say to Bathsheba, I also will come in after thee, and confirm thy words.28 And Rabbi [Judah the Prince] said: All falsehoods are prohibited, but it is permissible to utter a falsehood for the purpose of making peace between a man and his fellow.28a

Bar Ḳappara said: Great is peace, for we find that the Torah modified a statement in order to maintain peace between Abraham and Sarah. It is stated, And Sarah laughed within herself, saying … my lord being old;29 but in the sequel30 it is written, I who am old.31

Bar Ḳappara said: Great is peace, for we find that in the prophets, too, Scripture modified a statement for the purpose of maintaining peace between Manoaḥ and his wife. At first32 it is written, Behold, now, thou art barren … but thou shalt conceive and bear a son;33 but in the sequel34 it is written, Behold thou shalt conceive and bear a son,35 and there is no mention of the words behold thou art barren.

Bar Ḳappara said: Great is peace, for even the angels among whom there is no enmity, jealousy, hatred, strife, rivalry or dissension [have need for] the Holy One, blessed be He, to make peace among them; as it is stated,36 Dominion and fear are with Him; He maketh peace in His high places37—dominion alludes to Michael and fear to Gabriel, one being of fire and the other of water38 and yet they do not injure one another;39 how much more so then do mortal beings, among whom all these dispositions exist, [have need of peace] !

R. Ishmael said: Great is peace, for we find that the Holy One, blessed be He, permitted His Name, though written in holiness, to be blotted out in water,40 for the purpose of restoring peace between husband and wife.
R. Joshua said: Great is peace, for the covenant with the priests was made with [the word] ‘peace’, as it is stated, Behold, I give unto him My covenant of peace.41

R. Joshua said: Great is peace, for the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, is called ‘peace’, as it is stated, And he called it42 ‘Adonai-shalom’.43 44R. Ḥiyya b. Abba said: Hence it can be deduced that a person may not extend a greeting of peace to his fellow in a place of filth, because it is stated, And Gideon built an altar there unto the Lord and called it ‘Adonai-shalom’. Now if an altar which does not eat, drink or smell and was erected only to make an atonement for [the sins of] Israel is called ‘peace’, he who loves peace and pursues peace, who welcomes people with the greeting of peace45 and responds with peace, and who maintains peace between Israel and their Father in heaven, how much more so! R. Jose the Galilean said: Even the name of the Messiah is called ‘peace’, [as it is stated,] And his name is called … Abi-ad-sar-shalom.46

R. Joshua said: Great is peace, for [the children of] Israel are called ‘peace’, as it is stated, For as the seed of peace, the vine shall give her fruit.47 To whom will peace [be given]? To the seed of peace.

R. Jose the Galilean said: Great is peace, seeing that when king Messiah will reveal himself to Israel, his first message will be peace, as it is stated, How beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of the messenger of good tidings, that announceth peace.48

R. Jose the Galilean said: Great is peace, since even in a time of war one should begin [by attempting to arrange] peace, as it is stated, When thou drawest nigh unto a city to fight against it, then proclaim peace unto it.49
R. Joshua said: Great is peace, since the Holy One, blessed be He, will in the hereafter support the righteous with peace, as it is stated, The mind stayed on Thee Thou keepest in perfect peace.50

R. Joshua said: Great is peace, for it is given [as a blessing] to the living and the dead. Whence to the living? [As it is stated,] And Jethro said to Moses: ‘Go in peace’.51 And whence to the dead? [As it is stated,] But thou shalt go to thy fathers in peace.52

Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel said: Great is peace, for we find that the tribes53 reported an untrue statement in order to maintain peace between Joseph and his brethren; as it is stated, And they sent a message unto Joseph, saying: Thy father did command before he died, saying: So shall ye say unto Joseph: Forgive, I pray thee now, the transgression of thy brethren and their sin,54 but we do not find that [Jacob] had given them any such command.55

Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel said: Great is peace, for Aaron the [High] Priest was praised only for peace; for he loved peace, pursued peace, greeted with the salutation of peace and responded with it, as it is stated, He walked with Me in peace and uprightness.56 It teaches that when he noticed two persons at enmity one with the other, he used to go first to one of them and say to him, ‘Why do you hate So-and-so? He has already come to my house, prostrated himself before me and said to me, “I sinned against So-and-so”. Go and pacify him’. When he left this one, he went to the other and spoke to him similarly, and so made peace, love and friendship between a man and his fellow. What is written subsequently? For he is the messenger of the Lord of hosts.57

R. Joshua said: The prophet is called ‘messenger [of the Lord]’ and the priest58 is called ‘messenger [of the Lord]’. The prophet is called ‘messenger [of the Lord]’, as it is stated, Then spoke Haggai the Lord’s messenger;59 and the priest is called ‘messenger [of the Lord]’, as it is stated, For he is the messenger of the Lord of hosts.60 Lest you think that this applies even to a priest who is an ‘am ha-’areẓ, the text declares, And they should seek the law at his mouth.61

R. Joshua of Siknin said in the name of R. Levi: Great is peace, for all benedictions and prayers conclude with ‘peace’. In the case of the benedictions of the Shema‘62 one concludes with ‘peace’: ‘[Blessed art Thou, O Lord,] Who spreadest the tabernacle of peace’;63 in the case of prayers64 one concludes with ‘peace’: ‘[Blessed art Thou, O Lord,] Who makest peace’.65

R. Joshua b. Levi said: The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Israel, ‘You have brought about the destruction of My Temple and the dispersion of My children; pray, therefore, for the peace [of Zion] and I will give you peace’;66 as it is stated, Pray for the peace of Jerusalem,67 and it also declares, Peace be within thy walls,68 and it is also stated, For my brethren and companions’ sakes, I will now say: Peace be within thee.69

As for him who loves peace, pursues peace, and gives the greeting of peace and responds with peace, the Holy One, blessed be He, will cause him to inherit life in this world and life in the World to Come, as it is stated, But the humble shall inherit the land, and delight themselves in the abundance of peace.70 [60a]

chapter.title: INTRODUCTION
chapter.p: The Hebrew term for a proselyte is ger, plural gerim. Its original definition is ‘an alien’ resident in the Holy Land; but when it came to denote a proselyte to Israel’s faith, as a consequence of such conversions, the former had to be described differently and he was known as a ger toshab, ‘a resident alien’.

In the Bible there is abundant evidence that converts were accepted. Apart from the instance of Ruth and what is recorded in Esth. VIII, 17, the legislation mentions them specifically. Ex. XII, 48 directs what is to be done when a stranger shall sojourn with thee who wishes to observe the Passover. He must subject himself to the same restrictions as a born Israelite on the Day of Atonement (Lev. XVI, 29). The law concerning defilement by contact with the dead and the rite of purification applied equally to him (Num. XIX, 10). The regulations concerning certain offerings were the same for him as any other member of the community (ibid. XV, 14).

The hope that Gentiles will ultimately accept the God of Israel is often expressed. A section of Solomon’s prayer at the dedication of the Temple is devoted to them (1 Kings VIII, 41-43). References in the prophetical literature are numerous (cf. Isa. II, 2f., XIV, 1, LVI, 3-6; Jer. III, 17, XII, 16; Zech. XIV, 9).

Contrary to the prevailing idea that post-Biblical Judaism all but excluded proselytes from the community, the evidence proves that an almost unceasing stream of converts swelled the ranks of the Jewish people. The testimony of Philo and Josephus on this point is corroborated by Roman writers like Tacitus and Juvenal (on the whole subject, cf. J.E. X, pp. 220-224, G. F. Moore, Judaism, I, pp. 323-353).

Among the Rabbis of the Talmudic era differences of opinion existed on the desirability of accepting converts. On one side is the statement of R. Eleazar, ‘The Holy One, blessed be He, did not exile Israel among the nations save in order that proselytes might join them’ (Pes. 87b, Sonc. ed., p. 463). At the other extreme is the harsh saying of R. Ḥelbo, ‘Proselytes are as hard for Israel [to endure] as a sore’ (Yeb. 47b, Sonc. ed., p. 312), playing on the verb in Isa. XIV, 1, The stranger [ger] shall ioin himself [wenispeḥu] with them and the noun sapaḥath, ‘a scab’ in Lev. XIII, 2.

The position is fairly summed up by Professor Moore as follows: ‘Speaking generally the tone of the utterances about proselytes is friendly, though not unduly enthusiastic. This is the more to be noted because the Jews’ experience with proselytes must at times have been decidedly discouraging. It can hardly be doubted that in perilous times many apostatized. In the outside lands, at least, many went over to Christianity. In the persecution under Hadrian they were under strong temptation to clear their own skirts by turning informers. It would be nothing surprising if under such circumstances the Rabbis should have looked askance at all proselytes. There is, however, little evidence of such a temper’ (op. cit., p. 342).

This work is one of the ‘Seven Minor Tractates’. Its material is in the main gathered from what is found in the early Rabbinic sources and the Talmud. Whether the collection was made before or after the redaction of the Talmud is a disputed question (cf. the Editor’s Preface).

In its extant form the tractate in all probability dates from the Geonic period. The subject was at that time of more than theoretical or academic interest. Referring to the laws which were enacted prohibiting proselytization by Jews under severe penalties, Professor Moore remarks, ‘Against all such attempts of pagan or Christian rulers to shut up Judaism in itself and prevent its spread, the Jews persisted in their missionary efforts to make the religion God had revealed to their fathers the religion of mankind’ (op. cit., p. 353). [The existence of Masseketh Gerim—a manual of the laws relating to converts—is in itself a substantiation of this statement.]

Chapter I commences with a full description of the method by which a would-be proselyte is received into the fold. Then, after specifying who is a genuine proselyte, it lays down what is to be done with his wine (and incidentally what is to be done with the food of any ‘am ha-’areẓ who becomes a ḥaber), and how far he is exempt from the laws relating to usury and priestly dues.

Chapter II deals with circumcision, lustration and sacrifice as prerequisites for entering into the Israelite covenant, and with the question whether proselytes are called to account for sins committed before their conversion.

Chapter III commences by defining the ger toshab and laying down rules for his treatment. It then discusses how far the Jewish laws of consanguinity apply to a proselyte, and gives regulations on what is to be done with the property of a proselyte after his death.

Chapter IV is a Midrashic disquisition on the consideration which should be shown to proselytes and on the favour with which they are regarded by God for following the example of the Patriarch Abraham.
M. SIMON.

chapter.title: GERIM
CHAPTER I
chapter.p: RULE 1. If a man wishes to become a proselyte he is not accepted at once but they1 say to him, ‘Why do you want to become a proselyte? Do you not see that this people are debased, oppressed and degraded2 more than all other peoples, that diseases and chastisements come upon them and they bury their children and children’s children, that they are slaughtered for [observing] circumcision, immersion3 and the other precepts [of the Torah] and cannot hold up their heads4 like other peoples?’
RULE 2. If he says, ‘I am not worthy’, they dismiss him and he goes his way.5

RULE 3. If, however, he undertakes [to become a proselyte], they take him down to the place of immersion, cover him in water up to his middle,6 and tell him some of the details of the precepts. [He is informed that he is accepted only] on condition that he will give gleanings, forgotten sheaves, the corner of the field and tithes.7
RULE 4. As they say this to a man, so they say to a woman that [she is accepted] on condition that she will be particular in regard to niddah, ḥallah8 and the kindling of the Sabbath lamp.

RULE 5. When he has bathed and come up [out of the water], they speak to him words of kindness and comfort9 [saying], ‘To Whom are you cleaving? Happy are you! [You are cleaving] to Him Who spoke and the world came into being, blessed be He; for the world was created only for the sake of Israel;10 only Israel are called “sons of God”,11 and only Israel are [described as] “beloved of God”.12 All the things we have said to you13 we have said only to increase your reward’.

RULE 6. If a proselyte has been circumcised but has not yet bathed [he is a proselyte]; if he has bathed but not yet been circumcised [he is not yet a proselyte]; everything depends on the circumcision. This is the view of R. Eliezer, but R. ‘Aḳiba said: Also14 [the lack of] bathing is a bar.

RULE 7. Anyone who becomes a proselyte for the sake of [marrying a Jewish] woman, or out of fear, or love15 is not a proselyte. Similarly R. Judah and R. Nehemiah said: All [the Gentiles] who were converted in the days of Mordecai and Esther were not genuine proselytes, as it is stated, And many from among the peoples of the land became Jews; for the fear of the Jews was fallen upon them.16 Anyone who is not converted from purely religious motives17 is not a proselyte. [60b]
RULE 8. A man gives immersion to a man, and a woman to a woman but not to a man.

RULE 9. If a man became a proselyte who had vessels of wine18 in his possession and he says, ‘I am positive that none of it has been poured out as a libation’, the wine is permitted to him and forbidden to others. R. ‘Aḳiba said: 19If it is forbidden to others, surely it is forbidden to himself! If he says, ‘[The wine has been made] in a state of purity in the presence of So-and-so who is a ḥaber, he is believed’.

Similarly should an ‘am ha-’areẓ take upon himself to become a ḥaber, and he had food which should be in a state of ritual purity and said, ‘I am positive that it has been prepared in ritual cleanliness’, it is permitted to him and forbidden to others. R. ‘Aḳiba said: If it is forbidden to others, all the more it is forbidden to himself! But if he said, ‘It was prepared in ritual cleanliness in the presence of So-and-so who is a ḥaber’, he is believed.20

RULE 10. If an Israelite lends money to a Gentile or a Gentile lends money to an Israelite and he became a proselyte, he collects the principal but not the interest.21 R. Judah said: If before conversion he turned the whole into a loan,22 he collects the whole.

RULE 11. How [is the law]? If a first-born son was born to him before he was converted, he is exempt;23 but if after he was converted he is liable; in case of doubt he is exempt. If he had dough ready for baking and a field ready for reaping, until he is converted he is exempt24 but from the time he is converted he is liable. If there is doubt he is exempt.
chapter.ftnote: (1) The Rabbis who consider his application.
(2) ‘Debased’ in themselves, ‘oppressed’ by others, and ‘degraded’ in consequence. MS.K. and H read ‘lowly and persecuted’.
(3) To purify themselves after ritual defilement.
(4) lit. ‘behave in public’.

(5) MS.K. and H read: ‘If he says, “I am not worthy to place my neck under the yoke of Him Who spoke and the world came into being, blessed be He”, they receive him forthwith, and if not he is dismissed and goes his way’. In Yeb. 47a. (Sonc. ed., p. 311), the reading is ‘I know and yet am unworthy’ of the privilege of membership of Israel.
(6) The place of nakedness.
(7) Cf. Lev. XIX, 9; Deut. XXIV, 19; Num. XVIII, 26ff.; Deut. XIV, 22ff.; XXVI, 12ff.
(8) Added by MS.K. and H.
(9) So MS.K. and H, V ‘appropriate words’.

(10) [Cf. Midrash Rabbah, Leviticus, XXXVI, 4 (Sonc. ed., p. 461): ‘The heaven and earth were only created for the sake of Israel’, because God foresaw that they alone would accept the Torah, without which the universe could not endure.]
(11) [Cf. Deut. XIV, 1.]

(12) [To be understood in the light of the dictum, ‘Beloved are Israel, for unto them was given the desirable instrument’, i.e. the Torah (Aboth III, 18, Sonc. ed., III, 14, p. 37).] MS.K. omits the clause.
(13) viz. at the beginning, ‘Why do you want to become a proselyte?’
(14) Reading ’af with MS.K. and H instead of ’en (not) in V. [Cf. the discussion on the subject in Yeb. 46a, b (Sonc. ed., pp. 302ff.).]
(15) [Of the Jews, perhaps deriving material advantage from his conversion.]
(16) Esth. VIII, 17.
(17) lit. ‘to the name of Heaven’.
(18) [Wine in the possession of a Gentile is termed yayin nesek, ‘wine of libation’, and is forbidden to Jews on the suspicion that it may have been used in idolatrous rites.]

(19) A comparison with Tosiftha Ṭohoroth sec. 9 shows that there is a lacuna in the text and that R. ‘Aḳiba is speaking of the case where the wine had not been made by the proselyte himself but by another Gentile.
(20) This paragraph is omitted in V and inserted in MS.K. and H.

(21) MS.K. reads: ‘One (i.e. the proselyte) takes the capital only (because being now a Jew he may not take interest from a Jew [cf. Lev. XXV, 36f.], and the other (the Jew) takes the interest as well’. The reason is that if this were not done, it might be suspected that the Gentile became a convert to escape paying the interest.
(22) i.e. added the interest to the principal and wrote a fresh contract for the whole sum as a loan.
(23) From his redemption (cf. Ex. XXXIV, 20). MS.K. and H read: ‘If a son were born to him or his cow calved or his cow were slaughtered before he was converted, he is exempt’ from the priestly dues.
(24) From ḥallah and the tithe.

chapter.title: CHAPTER II
chapter.p: RULE 1. There is a proselyte who is circumcised at eight days old1. How is this? If he was born before his mother [who became a convert] underwent immersion he is circumcised at a day old,2 but if after his mother underwent immersion at eight days old.3

RULE 2. If a proselyte was already circumcised, or if a child was born circumcised, it is necessary to draw from him blood of the covenant,4 according to Beth Shammai; but Beth Hillel say that it is not necessary.

RULE 3. R. Mathia b. Ḥeresh said in the name of R. Ishmael:5 Beth Shammai and Beth Hillel did not differ on the question of a proselyte who was already circumcised or a child who was born circumcised. On what did they differ? On a child who was born circumcised on the Sabbath. Beth Shammai said: We override the Sabbath on his account to draw from him blood of the covenant, and Beth Hillel said that this is not necessary.6

RULE 4. If a slave underwent immersion before his master7 he becomes free. It is related of Queen Valeria8 that some of her slaves underwent immersion before her and some after her, and when the case came before the Sages they said that they who underwent immersion before her were free, but they who underwent immersion after her were still enslaved.

RULE 5. Just as Israel were initiated into the covenant by three precepts, so proselytes are initiated by circumcision, immersion and a sacrifice. [The omission of] the first two debars him [from becoming a proselyte], but [the omission of] the third does not debar him. R. Eliezer [b. Jacob] said: The omission of the sacrifice is also a bar.9 This was the ruling of R. Eliezer b. Jacob: A proselyte who becomes a convert is required to set aside a fourth part [of a dinar] for his sacrifice of birds;10 but R. Simeon says that he is not required to do so.

RULE 6. Proselytes are punished [for their sins before conversion] in the opinion of R. Jose; R. Judah said: He is not punished [61a] but is like a new-born child. R. Ḥanina b. Gamaliel said: Why are proselytes afflicted?11 Because they calculate a year before or two years before [their conversion], saying, [‘I shall become a proselyte] when I have collected my debts and when I have finished what I have to do’. R. Jose said to him,12 ‘If they were to lose money [only as a punishment] you would be right; but they [sometimes] bury their children and grandchildren and sore diseases and chastisements befall them. Why are they afflicted? Because of their [transgression13 of] the seven commandments which were given to the descendants of Noah’.14
chapter.ftnote: (1) So MS.K. and H. V wrongly, ‘a proselyte is always circumcised at eight days old’.
(2) i.e. he is made a proselyte at the earliest moment.
(3) Like a child of a Jewish mother.
(4) A slight incision is made to draw a drop of blood.
(5) So MS.K. and H. V has ‘Samuel’.
(6) To set the Sabbath aside, and the blood should be drawn on another day. Both Schools agreed that it was necessary to draw the blood of the covenant.
(7) A Gentile who was being made a convert.
(8) [In Yeb. 46a (Sonc. ed., p. 299) ‘Queen’ is omitted. R.H. 17b (Sonc. ed., p. 70) mentions ‘Valeria the proselyte’.] Some of her slaves became Jewesses while she was still a heathen.
(9) Omitted by V but added by MS.K. and H. Cf. Kerith. 9a (Sonc. ed., p. 66).
(10) To be offered when the Temple will be rebuilt; Kerith. loc. cit. (Sonc. ed., p. 67, n. 12).
(11) By God.
(12) ‘R. Jose … him’ added by MS.K. and H.
(13) While they were still Gentiles.
(14) [The practice of equity, and prohibitions against blasphemy, idolatry, immorality, bloodshed, robbery and eating a limb torn from a live animal; Sanh. 56a (Sonc. ed., pp. 381f.).]

chapter.title: CHAPTER III
chapter.p: RULE 1. What is a ‘resident proselyte’?1 Whoever undertakes to abstain from idolatry, in the view of R. Meir; R. Judah said: Whoever undertakes not to eat flesh that has not been ritually slaughtered.2

RULE 2. His spittle, his seat, his couch and his urine are unclean; his bread,3 his oil and his wine are clean. The prohibitions thou shalt not do him wrong,4 thou shalt not oppress5 and the wages of a hired servant shall not abide with thee all night6 apply to him.
RULE 3. We do not marry him [to a Jewess] or take to wife women from him.7 We do not lend to him or borrow from him on interest.

RULE 4. We do not settle him on the frontier8 or in an unhealthy district, but in a pleasant district in the centre of the Land of Israel,9 where he can find scope for his occupation, as it is stated, With thee he shall dwell in thy midst, in a place which he shall choose in one of thy gates, thou shalt not wrong him.10
RULE 5. Every incestuous marriage which is forbidden to Israel under pain of death at the hands of a Beth Din is11 forbidden to proselytes.
RULE 6. How is this? If he was married to the sister of his mother and her sister from the [same] mother, R. Meir says that he must dismiss her, but the Sages say that he may keep one of them.12

RULE 7. An Israelite13 who has had intercourse with the daughter of a Gentile is to be tried according to the non-Jewish law, but a Gentile who has had intercourse with the daughter of an Israelite is to be tried according to Jewish law.

RULE 8. If a proselyte died leaving a son or daughter who became a convert with him, his property is ownerless14 and his slaves regain their freedom. If the slaves were minors15 they are acquired by ‘drawing’,16 because [the Sages] said that movable property is acquired by ‘drawing’ and immovable property by seizure.17

RULE 9. R. Eliezer said: [Immovable property] is acquired only by seizure; but if someone was walking in the field [of a proselyte who died] and a man came up to him to whom he said, ‘The field is mine’, the field is his; but the Sages say that he does not acquire the property until he has taken possession of it.18

RULE 10. If one man comes from the south and another from the north, each one acquires the part which he traverses. This is the view of R. Eliezer; but the Sages said: Neither acquires until he has taken possession.

RULE 11. [If a proselyte died] while liable for his wife’s kethubah and [the claim of] a creditor and she says, ‘This part of the property belongs to me and this part is due to me under my kethubah’, she is entitled [to the whole]. If she says, ‘This part is due to me under my kethubah and this part belongs to me’, she is entitled only to her kethubah.

RULE 12. Similarly, if a creditor says, ‘This part belongs to me and that part is for my debt’, he is entitled [to the whole]; but if he says, ‘This part is for my debt and that part belongs to me’, he is entitled only to his debt.

RULE 13. If he had slaves pasturing a flock19 and someone came and said, ‘These slaves and the flock are mine’, they are his; but if the slaves are shrewd they can say, ‘We are free men and the flock belongs to us’.20
chapter.ftnote: (1) Heb. ger toshab as distinguished from ger ẓedeḳ, ‘a righteous proselyte’.

(2) According to ‘A.Z. 64b (Sonc. ed., p. 314) a ger toshab is defined as one who undertook to keep all the commandments except the prohibition against eating flesh not ritually slaughtered, and perhaps that should be the reading here.
(3) So MS.K. and H; V ‘his dough’.
(4) Lev. XIX, 33.
(5) Deut. XXIV, 14.
(6) Lev. XIX, 13.
(7) Those within the category of ger toshab.
(8) [Where he would be exposed to attack, or by intercourse with foreign neighbours lapse into heathenism.]
(9) The words ‘in the centre of the Land of Israel’ are superfluous and should perhaps be omitted.
(10) Deut. XXIII, 17.
(11) So MS.K. V and H insert ‘not’. [The question is debated in Sanh. 57b-58a (Sonc. ed., p. 393).]

(12) This is the lit. rendering of V, which is hopelessly corrupt. MS.K. and H read: ‘How is this? If he was married to the sister of his father from the same father or the sister of his father from the same mother, R. Meir says that he must dismiss her, but the Sages say that he may keep her. [If he has married] two sisters from the same mother, R. Meir says that he must dismiss both, but the Sages say that he must dismiss one of them’. The instance here adduced has nothing to do with the statement which precedes. In Sanh. loc. cit. it is adduced as an illustration of the statement that ‘a proselyte whose conception was not in holiness, but whose birth was in holiness (i.e. after his mother’s conversion) is forbidden to his mother’s relatives but not to his father’s’. In that case, however, we should certainly have to read here, ‘if he had married his father’s sister from the same father he may keep her, but if from the same mother, R. Meir says’, etc.
(13) This is an obvious mistake for ‘a Gentile’. [Cf. Sanh. 57b (Sonc. ed., p. 393) where it is explicitly stated.]
(14) [There is nothing in V corresponding to ‘is ownerless’ which is required by the context. MS.K. and H insert ‘is like the deer’, i.e. free, ownerless.]

(15) [This is the reading suggested by N.Y.; V, MS.K. and H have ‘shrewd’. This version agrees with Ḳid. 23a (Sonc. ed., p. 110): ‘If a proselyte dies [without heirs] adult slaves acquire their freedom, but as for minors, whoever takes possession of them gains a title to them’.]
(16) [‘Taking possession by drawing towards one’s self the object to be acquired’ (Jastrow).]

(17) [This is the correct reading as against V’s ‘the Sages said that movable property is acquired by seizure’. Cf. Ḳid. I, 5 (Sonc. ed., p. 124). ‘Movable property’ is lit. ‘property which has no security’, i.e. on which a creditor cannot distrain if sold; ‘immovable property’, on the other hand, like real estate, can be mortgaged for the owner’s debts.]
(18) [By performing some act such as levelling, etc. Cf. B.B. 100a (Sonc. ed., p. 418, n. 7).]
(19) Following the text of MS.K. and H.
(20) By declaring themselves freemen they can inherit their master’s property.

chapter.title: CHAPTER IV
chapter.p: RULE 1. And a stranger [ger] shalt thou not wrong, neither shalt thou oppress him:1 you shall not wrong him in speech or oppress him in money dealings. Do not say to him,2 ‘Yesterday you were worshipping Bel, Ḳores and Nebo, and till now pig’s flesh was between your teeth, and now you stand up and speak with me!’ And whence [do I learn] [not] to wrong him? He can retort, For ye were strangers in the land of Egypt?3 Hence R. Nathan used to say: Do not taunt your neighbour with the blemish which you yourself have.4

RULE 2. R. Eliezer b. Jacob said: Because [the proselyte’s] original nature was evil,5 Scripture gave many warnings in connection with him, as it is stated, And a stranger shalt thou not wrong, neither shalt thou oppress him; for ye know the heart of a stranger.6 Hence because his original nature was evil, Scripture gave many warnings concerning him.

RULE 3. Beloved are proselytes [by God], for [Scripture] everywhere uses the same epithets of them as of Israel; [61b] as it is stated, But thou, Israel, My servant, Jacob whom I have chosen.7 The term ‘love’ is applied to Israel, as it is stated, I have loved you, saith the Lord,8 and the term ‘love’ is applied to proselytes, as it is stated, And He loveth the stranger, in giving him food and raiment.9 Israel are called ‘servants’, as it is stated, For unto Me the children of Israel are servants,10 and proselytes are called ‘servants’, as it is stated, To be His servants.11 The term ‘acceptable’ is used of Israel, as it is stated, And it shall be always upon his forehead, that they may be accepted before the Lord,12 and the term ‘acceptable’ is used of proselytes, as it is stated, Their burnt-offerings and their sacrifices shall be acceptable upon Mine altar.13 The term ‘keeping’ is applied to Israel, as it is stated, The Lord is thy keeper, the Lord is thy shade upon thy right hand,14 and the term ‘keeping’ is applied to proselytes, as it is stated, The Lord preserveth the strangers.15 The term ‘ministering’ is applied to Israel, as it is stated, But ye shall be named the priests of the Lord, men shall call you the ministers of our God,16 and the term ‘ministering’ is applied to proselytes, as it is stated, Also the aliens, that join themselves to the Lord, to minister unto Him.17

Beloved are proselytes seeing that our father Abraham did not circumcise himself when he was twenty or thirty years of age, but when he was ninety-nine years old;18 since if he had circumcised himself when he was twenty or thirty years old, no Gentile would have become a proselyte when he had passed the age of twenty or thirty. The Holy One, blessed be He, kept putting it off19 until he had reached ninety-nine years, so as not to close the door in the face of proselytes, [and to allow more days and years so as to increase the reward of those who do His will, as it is stated, The Lord was pleased, for His righteousness’ sake, to make the teaching great and glorious].20

Our father Abraham called himself a ger, as it is stated, I am a stranger [ger] and a sojourner with you.21 Similarly David, king of Israel, called himself a ger, as it is stated, For I am a stranger [ger] with Thee,22 and likewise it states, For we are strangers before Thee.23

Beloved is the Land of Israel because it makes proselytes fit [to be received]. If a man says in the Land of Israel, ‘I am a proselyte’, he is accepted at once, but outside the Land of Israel he is not accepted unless his witnesses are with him. Beloved is the Land of Israel because it atones for iniquities and transgressions, as it is stated, And the inhabitant shall not say: ‘I am sick’, the people that dwell therein shall be forgiven their iniquity.24

And so you find in the four classes that stand before the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is stated, One shall say: ‘I am the Lord’s’; and another shall call himself by the name of Jacob; and another shall subscribe with his hand unto the Lord, and surname himself by the name of Israel.25 One shall say: ‘I am the Lord’s’—this alludes to one who belongs wholly to the Omnipresent and has no admixture of sin. Another shall call himself by the name of Jacob—this alludes to the proselytes of righteousness.26 Another shall subscribe with his hand unto the Lord—this alludes to those who repent. And surname himself by the name of Israel—this alludes to those who fear Heaven.

(6) Ex. XXIII, 9.

(7) Isa. XLI, 8. Jacob is here interpreted as ibid. XLIV, 5, And another shall call himself by the name of Jacob—these are the proselytes of righteousness (cf. towards the end of this tractate). The order of the quotations in V is confused.

(11) Isa. LVI, 6.
