chapter.title: INTRODUCTION
chapter.p: The people named in the Bible Kuthim are the descendants—actual or supposed—of the immigrants who were settled by Shalmaneser, king of Assyria, in the region of Samaria when he drove the Northern Kingdom into exile and who adopted the way of life of the Israelites (cf. 2 Kings XVII, 24ff.). After the Jews returned from Babylon, the question arose in an acute form whether the Kuthim should be regarded as members of the community in view of their claim to share in rebuilding the Temple. [For a critical inquiry into the origins of this people, cf. J. A. Montgomery, The Samaritans, 1907, and for an account of them cf. J.E. X, pp. 669-681.]

Not until the third century C.E. was the decision finally taken to treat the Samaritans as Gentiles although they had adopted many Jewish rites. Inasmuch as this tractate evidently presupposes that the question was still open, it must have been compiled in its original form before then. This view seems to be confirmed by the favourable attitude which the tractate generally adopts towards them; but there are traces of later additions in accordance with the change in the relationship between the two communities.

[Much of the material contained in the tractate is culled from Talmudic sources. The conclusion of Montgomery is: ‘Most of the independent halakoth are favourable to them, and so may be presumed to be discarded Baraithoth. On the other hand, the halakoth which have been bodily applied to the Samaritans from the law concerning the Gentiles, testify to the later practical identification of the two classes’ (op. cit., pp. 196f.).]

It begins by laying down the principle that while in most respects Samaritans are on the same footing as Jews, in some they are on the same footing as heathens; and it proceeds to give a number of rules for regulating Jewish intercourse with them. These rules relate to the Temple Service, to the right to gleanings, etc., to the observance of tithe and ‘erub, to social and business relationship with them and to their reliability as witnesses.

Chapter II deals chiefly with the permissibility of various Samaritan foods, such as meat and cheese, and with the status of Samaritan priests; also with the position of Samaritans in the matter of legal penalties and damages. It concludes with explaining why they have been forbidden to intermarry with the Israelites and how they may one day obtain acceptance into the fold.
[In the Talmud editions the text of the chapters is continuous. It has here been divided into paragraphs and numbered in agreement with Higger’s edition.]
M. SIMON.

chapter.title: KUTHIM
CHAPTER I
chapter.p: The Samaritans in some of their ways resemble the Gentiles and in some resemble Israel, but in the majority they resemble Israel.

We do not accept from them for offering [in the Temple] sacrificial birds brought by males with a flux,1 or sacrificial birds brought by females with a flux,2 or sacrificial birds brought by women after childbirth,3 or sin-offerings or trespass-offerings, but we receive from them vows and free-will-offerings.4
We do not transfer to them anything attached to the soil,5 or sell to them sheep to shear, or crops to reap6 or trees attached to the soil,7 but we sell them animals to slaughter.
We do not sell them large cattle even if they are mutilated, or foals or calves;8 but we may sell them a mutilated animal which can never recover.9
We do not sell them weapons of war or anything which can cause injury to the public.
We do not give to them [Israelite women] in marriage or take wives from them,10 but we lend to them and borrow from them on interest.11

We give them gleanings, forgotten sheaves and the corner of the field;12 they too observe [gleanings], forgotten sheaves and the corner of the field,13 and their word can be taken in regard to gleanings, forgotten sheaves and the corner of the field in their season and in regard to the tithe of the poor in its year.14 Their produce is reckoned as ṭebel15 like the produce of Gentiles, and they make the ‘erub ineffective like Gentiles.16
An Israelite woman should not act as midwife to a Samaritan woman or suckle her child;17 but a Samaritan woman can act as midwife to an Israelite woman and suckle her child on her premises.

An Israelite may circumcise a Samaritan and a Samaritan can circumcise an Israelite. R. Judah said: A Samaritan may not circumcise an Israelite because he only circumcises him in the name of Mount Gerizim.18

We may stall an animal in the inn of a Samaritan, and [an Israelite] may hire a Samaritan to follow his beast. He may also entrust his cattle to a Samaritan shepherd,19 and he may entrust his son to a Samaritan to teach him a trade.20 We may associate with them and converse21 with them in any place, which is not so with Gentiles.22
He performs ḥaliẓah for his sister-in-law and gives a geṭ to his wife, and a Samaritan may be relied on to bring a geṭ23 from foreign countries to Israel.

These are the things which we do not sell them: animals which died of themselves or have been improperly slaughtered, animals forbidden [to an Israelite] as food,24 reptiles,25 a shoe made from the skin of an animal which died of itself,26 oil into which a mouse has fallen,27 or [the flesh of] a koskos28 or of an embryo. Although Israelites eat a koskos and an embryo we do not sell them to the Samaritans, because such a sale would be under false pretences. And just as we do not sell these to them so we do not buy these from them, as it is stated For thou art a holy people unto the Lord thy God29—since thou art holy, thou must not make another people holier than thyself.30

A Samaritan may be trusted if he says that he has buried [a miscarriage] or not buried it,31 and, with regard to an animal, that it has brought forth its first-born32 or not brought forth. A Samaritan may be trusted with regard to the plantation of the fourth year and uncircumcised fruit33 and grave-signs,34 but not with regard to overhanging boughs, protruding stones,35 land of the peoples,36 or a beth peras,37 because they are suspected [of carelessness] in these matters. The general principle is that in regard to matters in which they are suspected [of carelessness] they are not trusted.
chapter.ftnote: (3) ibid. XII, 6, 8.
(4) The words ‘vows and free-will offerings’ have dropped out of the printed text and MS.K., but are added by H in agreement with Shek. I, 5 (Sonc. ed., p. 3).

(5) Lest they should transfer it to Gentiles to whom such ownership is forbidden. [In ‘A.Z. 20b (Sonc. ed., p. 107) this rule is stated in connection with Gentiles. As with several other rulings which follow it was subsequently applied to Samaritans.]
(6) The correct reading is probably ‘unripe produce (for cattle food) to clip’.
(7) The words ‘to be cut down’ should certainly be inserted.
(8) [From the fear that the owner will not allow them to rest on the Sabbath; cf. ‘A.Z. 15a (Sonc. ed., p. 75).]
(9) [Because it will not be put to work and so the fear, previously stated, does not apply.]
(10) [For the reason, cf. below II, 7, n. 13.]
(11) [Either the text should be emended to ‘and we do not lend to them’, etc., or the clause is a later insertion at the time of the final repudiation of the Samaritans. Cf. Kirchheim ad loc.
(12) Cf. Gerim I, 3, n. 7.
(13) And therefore no tithe need be given for them.
(14) The tithe of produce was given to the poor in the third and sixth year of the seven-year cycle.
(15) i.e. produce from which the heave-offering and tithe have not been separated.
(16) Cf. ‘Erub. 61b (Sonc. ed., p. 433, n. 1).

(17) [Based on Mishnah ‘A.Z. II, 2 (Sonc. ed., p. 129) where it speaks of ‘a heathen woman’ and the reason given is ‘because she would be delivering a child to idolatry’. Since the Tosiftha ‘A.Z. III permits it in the case of a Samaritan, the text here is probably a later adaptation and] originally read ‘may act as midwife … and suckle’.

(18) The mountain sacred to the Samaritans as the Temple Mount in Jerusalem was to the Jews. [The phrase ‘seems to mean simply, “with the intention of attaching the person to the community of Gerizim” ’ (Montgomery, The Samaritans, pp. 170f.).]
(19) [Because a Samaritan is not suspected of perverted practices with an animal. Cf. ‘A.Z. 15b (Sonc. ed., p. 78).]
(20) [We do not fear that he will influence the boy against Judaism.]
(21) The correct reading according to Kirchheim is מסתפרין, ‘may have the hair cut by them’, instead of מספרין [in agreement with Mishnah ‘A.Z. II, 3 (Sonc. ed., p. 135).
(22) Who are suspected of murderous intent.
(23) i.e. his word is taken that he witnessed the signing and sealing of the geṭ.
(24) Lest they should sell them to Israelites as fit for consumption.
(25) Lest they should mix them with things sold to Israelites.

(26) Cf. Ḥul. 94a (Sonc. ed., p. 528, n. 4): ‘The animal may have died through the bite of a serpent and the hide of the animal may thereby have become contaminated’. Rashi ad loc. explains that the leather of an animal which died of itself is inferior to that of a healthy animal, and to sell shoes from this leather is false pretences.
(27) [The oil would thereby become unclean, and in this matter the Samaritans were scrupulous.]
(28) ‘A בוס בוס’ is added by MS.K. and H. It is the term for an animal which has been hurriedly slaughtered because otherwise it would soon have died naturally.
(29) Deut. XIV, 21.

(30) ‘Since thou art holy’, etc., is omitted in V. [Kirchheim explains that the underlying principle is that which is laid down in Pes. 50b-51a (Sonc. ed., p. 247): ‘Things which are permitted, yet others treat them as forbidden, you may not permit it in their presence’. It is there expressly applied to Samaritans.]
(31) [Cf. Nid. 56b (Sonc. ed., p. 397). If the foetus was buried in a room, any person entering it would be rendered ritually unclean.]
(32) [Then the subsequent birth would not come under the law of the firstling, which was a priestly due.]
(33) Cf. Lev. XIX, 23f.
(34) If he says that there is no grave in a place which is not marked.
(35) Which form a ‘tent’ for communicating ritual defilement. [Cf. Nid. Sonc. ed., p. 399, n. 2.]
(36) [i.e. countries outside the Holy Land in matters which concern ritual purity.]

chapter.title: CHAPTER II
chapter.p: We do not buy meat from a Samaritan butcher except that of which he is prepared himself to eat, nor [do we buy from him] baskets of birds unless he first puts them in his mouth.1 He must not give them to an Israelite to eat, since the Samaritans have from of old been suspected of giving Israelites carrion to eat.

The Samaritan is on the same footing as an Israelite in regard to all damages mentioned in the Torah. Whether an Israelite kills a Samaritan or a Samaritan kills an Israelite, if he did it by inadvertence he goes into exile [to a City of Refuge], if wilfully he is put to death. If the ox of an Israelite gored the ox of a Samaritan he is exempt from damages;2 but should the ox of a Samaritan have gored the ox of an Israelite, if the ox is tam he pays half the damage and if it is mu‘ad3 he pays the whole damage. R. Meir said: If an ox of a Samaritan gores the ox of an Israelite, whether it is tam or mu‘ad the owner pays the whole damage and pays from his best possessions.4

Their cheeses are permitted. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: Those of private persons are permitted, but those of wholesalers5 are forbidden. Their cooked and preserved vegetables, into which they usually put wine or vinegar,6 are forbidden.

Israelite priests7 share with Samaritan priests in the latters’ districts because they, as it were, rescue [the produce] from their hands, but not in Israelite districts lest [Jews appear to] confirm their priesthood. If a Samaritan priest offers from what he is eating to an Israelite, should [the priest] be unclean it is permissible, but if clean it is forbidden.8

We do not buy [bread] from a Samaritan baker on the outgoing of Passover until after three bakings [have been made], or from private persons until three weeks have passed, or from the villages until after three bakings.9 When does this apply? When they have not prepared their unleavened bread together with Israelites or they observed Passover one day earlier; but if they baked their unleavened bread together with Israelites or observed Passover one day later, their leaven is permitted. R. Simeon forbids it because they do not know how to observe the law of unleavened bread like the Israelites.

At first they said: The wine of Gedor is forbidden on account of the wine of Kfar Paggasha.10 Later they revised this rule and said: Wherever [Samaritans] are suspected because of their mingling with Gentiles, if [their wine is] in an open [vessel] it is forbidden,11 and if in a closed [vessel] it is permitted. R. Meir said: All their wine is permitted except that which is in open [vessels for sale] in the markets; but the Sages said: In an open [vessel] it is everywhere forbidden and in a closed [vessel] permitted, while [a vessel] which has been pierced and then sealed is like one which is sealed. Their jars when new are permitted but when old are forbidden.12

Why are Samaritans forbidden to enter the Jewish community? Because they have become mixed up with the priests of the high places. R. Ishmael said: They were originally genuine proselytes. Why, then, are they forbidden? Because of the illegitimate females13 and because they do not perform the levirate duty to a married woman.14 When may they be received into the Jewish community? When they have renounced Mount Gerizim and acknowledged Jerusalem and the resurrection of the dead.15 From then onwards one who robs a Samaritan is like one who robs an Israelite. [62a]
chapter.ftnote: (1) [Ḥul. 4a (Sonc. ed., p. 10) reads: ‘[The Israelite] cuts off the head of one of the birds and gives it to the Samaritan; if he ate it, then we may eat of his slaughtering’.]
(2) i.e. if it was not known to have a tendency to be a gorer.
(3) תם (innocuous) denotes an ox which had not previously gored, mu‘ad (warned) one which had done so and the owner had been warned.
(5) H reads ‘those of the villages’. [The reason is that these cheeses are made for sale, and the makers are not particular to enclose them in skins of ritually clean animals.]
(6) [Cf. Gerim I, 9, n. 18.]

(7) About the time of Alexander the Great, the Samaritans built a temple on Mount Gerizim and a number of priests from Jerusalem, including a High Priest, went and ministered there. They were disowned by the Judeans.
(8) The Samaritan priest, if unclean, would not eat terumah, and therefore the Israelite may eat what he was eating.

(9) H reads ‘makings’ which has the same meaning as ‘bakings’. [As the continuation indicates, the ruling was made because the Samaritan Passover did not always coincide exactly with the Jewish Festival. Cf. Kirchheim ad loc.]

(10) For Gedor there is a variant ‘Kador’ and for Paggasha (the text in V is corrupt) ‘Pansha’. Apparently Gedor was a Samaritan village and Kfar Paggasha a heathen village near by with whose inhabitants the Samaritans freely mingled. Hence the doubt about the wine.
(11) Because some of it may have been used in heathen worship.
(12) [Cf. ‘A.Z. 29b (Sonc. ed., p. 146); another instance of a law relating to Gentiles which was later applied to Samaritans. An old jar may have contained the wine of a heathen.]

(13) [Since they are a mixed people, they include females who may not have been born to Israelite mothers and in turn their offspring are non-Israelite since their status in this respect depends upon that of the mother.]
(14) But perform ḥaliẓah instead. Cf. I, 11.
(15) [That the Samaritans denied the doctrine of resurrection is recorded in Sanh. 90b (Sonc. ed., p. 606, n. 1).]

chapter.title: INTRODUCTION
chapter.p: [Although civilized man today thinks of the institution of slavery with horror, it seems to have originated in a humanitarian motive based on utilitarianism. It was a moral advance on the practice of the victor putting the vanquished to death. Indeed the Latin word servus has been derived from servare, ‘to preserve’, as denoting a person who was not given over to general slaughter (cf. W. E. H. Lecky, History of European Morals, 1911, I, p. 102 n.).

In the economy of the ancient world slavery was indispensable, and Israel was no exception to the peoples who adopted it. But in this connection Israel was exceptional at least in one respect. Among the Romans and Greeks, e.g., the treatment of slaves varied in different periods. Not always was the master allowed to exercise power of life and death over them. Moralists arose who protested vehemently against the cruelties from which they suffered; but generally the lot of the slave was degraded in the extreme and his existence embittered.

With the people of Israel, on the other hand, the slave was never a mere chattel at the mercy of his master’s whims, and the legislation which affected him uniformly treated him as a human being. It is true that the Hebrew who sold himself for a term of servitude from straitened circumstances or was sold to earn the money wherewith to refund a theft, bore a stigma. The heathen slave, likewise, belonged to an inferior class. Nevertheless the Hebrew term which described them both, ‘ebed, was far from being derogatory. On the contrary, it was a dignified term since the Patriarchs, Moses, kings and prophets were designated ‘ ‘ebed of God’ and the phrase was applied to the whole community of Israel. It must be remembered that all the essential services of social life were regarded by the Israelites as honourable, and they who performed them were invested with a degree of dignity.

A consequence of this was that the slave in an Israelite household was not the exact counterpart of the slave in a heathen household. On the subject in general, cf. J.E. XI, pp. 403-408, G. F. Moore, Judaism, II, pp. 135-138, A. Cohen, Everyman’s Talmud, 1949, pp. 198-203, L. Baeck, The Essence of Judaism, 1936, pp. 203-207.

The last-mentioned authority remarks: ‘In the Greek and Roman world, to say nothing of the old eastern states ruled by despots, the slave was considered to be a thing; he was not a subject of the law, but merely an object of the law. In the corpus juris he belonged to the chapter devoted to the law of things. To the Israelite law the slave is a person entitled to rights, one who stands before his master with definite legal claims. The master is therefore not considered to be the owner of the slave, but only his possessor. He has not a full and unlimited freedom of dealing with him, but merely a restricted and conditional power of disposal over him. It is thus established that serfdom is not a relationship which has its foundations in the general order of law, incorporating acknowledged rights, but that it is merely a temporary form of domestic service. Thus the principle of slavery is thereby destroyed’ (op. cit., p. 205). He concludes his discussion of the subject with the statement: ‘Slavery, in the real sense of the word, did not exist among the Jews. Israel was the only community to possess a civilization which did not rest upon the shoulders of slaves, and thus created for the first time a truly ethical civilization’ (op. cit., p. 207).]

[Since the legislation of the Torah deals with the status and rights of slaves, and in Rabbinic times some Jews possessed them, the subject is included in the discussions of the Talmud. Whether the compilation which forms this tractate was made early or late can hardly be determined with certainty.

If the passage which is found in the Kirchheim MS. (cf. III, 4, n. 8) but omitted in the printed editions is authentic, it would be evidence in favour of an early date because it displays an intimate knowledge of the Roman forms of manumission which would have been more familiar to the Jews then than in the Geonic period. On the other hand, I. H. Weiss, Dor Dor weDoreshaw, 1904, II, p. 224, adduces an instance where the tractate presents an amalgam of two early Baraithoth in the Mekilta which is clearly the work of a later hand. There is the possibility that the original collection of material was made in the earlier Rabbinic era and in its extant form was edited in the Geonic period.]

The first chapter deals mainly with the various circumstances in which a Hebrew bondman, and more particularly a Hebrew bondwoman, obtains his or her release. It also contains a brief digression on the Jubilee.

Chapter II deals first with the treatment due to a Hebrew bondman from his Jewish master and the ‘parting gifts’ which have to be presented to him at the end of his period of service. It then describes the method of his redemption from a non-Jewish master, and the conditions under which an Israelite may be sold for theft.

The first half of chapter III specifies which Jewish bondmen may continue in service after their period of six years, and describes the ceremony of boring through the ear of such a one. The second half lays down the rules for the acquisition and liberation of a Canaanite (i.e. heathen) slave.
[In V the text of each chapter is continuous. In the present translation it has been divided into paragraphs and numbered in agreement with Higger’s edition.]
M. SIMON.

chapter.title: ‘ABADIM
CHAPTER I
chapter.p: [The regulations regarding] a Hebrew slave1 and a slave whose ear is bored [nirẓa‘]2 are in force only when the Jubilee [is in force].3

[The regulations regarding] a field of possession4 and a field which had been devoted [to the Temple]5 are in force only when the Jubilee [is in force]. R. Ishmael said: For that reason it is stated, As a field devoted; the possession thereof shall be the priest’s6—as possession [depends] on the Jubilee, so a field which had been devoted [depends] on the Jubilee.7 The Jubilee is on the same footing as the New Year in regard to the blowing [of the shofar],8 and the benedictions,9 except that [the blowing of] the shofar on the Jubilee overrides the Sabbath.9a When did the Jubilees cease [to be observed]? From the time when Pul and Tiglath-pileser, kings of Assyria, came up and carried the Reubenites, the Gaddites and half the tribe of Manasseh into captivity.10

11 A Hebrew slave is acquired by money purchase or by document, and he acquires his freedom by years of service,12 through the advent of the Jubilee13 and by deduction of money.14 The Hebrew handmaid has an advantage over him in that she acquires her freedom by the signs [of puberty]. The nirẓa‘ is acquired by the boring [of his ear] and acquires his freedom through [the advent of] the Jubilee or through the death of his master.

If a man writes a document of divorce for his handmaid,15 R. Ḥanina b. Gamaliel says that she does not become free, but the Sages say that she does become free. If he said to her,16 ‘Behold, you are free’, the Sages say that she does not become free.
[4. If one who is about to die says, ‘My slave So-and-so is free’, then he is free. If he wrote a deed of manumission for him, ‘Behold this [slave] is free’, the latter should have concern.]17

A man may sell his daughter from one servitude to another,18 and from one matrimony to another and from servitude to matrimony, but not from matrimony to servitude. [R. Simeon said: He may not sell her from one servitude to another, much less from matrimony to servitude.]19

If a man sells his daughter on condition of her not being betrothed by the master, his sale is valid but his condition is void, because he made a condition overriding what is written in the Torah,20 and whoever makes a condition which overrides a prescription of the Torah [does something which] is void.

If the father wants to betroth her and the son wants to betroth her, the father takes precedence. If the son wants to betroth her and the father to redeem her, the son takes precedence, because the precept of betrothing takes precedence over the precept of redeeming, as it is stated, Who hath espoused her to himself, then shall he let her be redeemed.20a Two must not be betrothed together.21

A brother22 must not betroth her. [This had to be mentioned] because it might have been argued: Seeing that the son who does not take the place of his father to act as levir may betroth her, does it not stand to reason that one who takes the place of his brother to act as levir should betroth her! Hence [the Torah] states, And if he espouse her unto his son,23 thus excluding the brother.

If he betrothed her at the end of the [six] years [of bondage], should she still be in his possession24 she is betrothed, according to the view of R. Simeon b. Eleazar, and if not she is not betrothed. The Sages, however, say that as long as she is in his possession25 she is betrothed, since that was the condition on which he paid the money [for her] at the beginning.26
If a man sells his daughter and then went and betrothed her to another, he made game of the master27 according to R. Jose b. Judah; but the Sages say that he has done nothing.28
chapter.ftnote: (1) An Israelite, according to the Rabbis, could become a slave either through being sold by the Beth Din to make restitution for a theft or through selling himself for a livelihood.
(2) Because he refused to go free after six years’ service (Ex. XXI, 5f.; Deut. XV, 16f.).
(3) This apparently means, so long as the years from one Jubilee to the next are being officially counted, as laid down in Lev. XXV, 8.
(4) Cf. ibid. XXVII, 16-21. A ‘field of possession’ is one that has been inherited as distinct from a ‘field of purchase’.
(5) Cf. ibid. 28f.

(7) A field of possession which had been dedicated by the owner, then sold by the priests and not redeemed before the Jubilee. Such a field at the Jubilee became the property of the priest. Cf. Rashi on ibid. 16.
(8) Cf. ibid. XXV, 9.
(9) [Nine blessings have to be said over the shofar as on the New Year; R.H. 26b (Sonc. ed., p. 120, n. 2).]
(9a) [The shofar is not blown on the day of the New Year which falls on the Sabbath.]
(10) Cf. 2 Kings XV, 19, 29.
(11) This paragraph is quoted from Mishnah Ḳid. I, 2 (Sonc. ed., p. 59).
(12) Cf. Ex. XXI, 2; Deut. XV, 12.
(13) Cf. Lev. XXV, 40f.
(14) i.e. by repaying his master his purchase price less the value of the service he has completed.
(15) Instead of giving her a deed of manumission. According to the Gemara, Giṭ. 85b (Sonc. ed., p. 412), there was no difference of opinion on this point.
(16) Without giving her a document.
(17) [Whether he is free. This paragraph is omitted in V and MS.K. but added in H.]
(18) i.e. he may sell her a second time if the first master dies or releases her.
(19) The words in brackets are not in V and are introduced from MS.K.
(20) Which declares, If she please not her master who hath espoused her to himself (Ex. XXI, 8). The Rabbis took this to mean that he bought her for the purpose of espousing her.
(20a) Ex. XXI, 8.
(21) A master cannot be betrothed to two maidservants simultaneously.
(22) Of the master of the maidservant.
(24) i.e. if there is still time for her to do work for him to the value of a peruṭah.
(25) Until the setting of the sun.
(26) viz. that the purchase money should also serve as the money of betrothal.
(27) And the betrothal to the second is valid; cf. Ḳid. 19b (Sonc. ed., p. 88).
(28) The second betrothal is invalid.

chapter.title: CHAPTER II
chapter.p: A Hebrew slave does work by day but not by night. R. Jose said: It all depends on his occupation. All agree that [the master] should not teach him to be a dyer, a butcher, or a baker for the public.1 He should not carry him to the privy or carry his clothes before him to the bath-house or gird his loins for him,2 massage or anoint him.

He eats the same food and drinks the same drink [as his master]; he sits at meals with him3 even if his stomach is full.4 If he is beaten or falls ill, [the master] does not reckon the time of his idleness,5 but if [the slave] runs away and returns, he does reckon the time when he was not working.
[An Israelite] may not sell himself in order to obtain clothing or bedding, but he may sell himself to maintain himself alive.

When [the slave] has completed his term of years, he must not be sent away empty-handed, as it is written, And when thou lettest him go free from thee, thou shalt not let him go empty; thou shalt furnish him liberally.6 R. Eleazar b. Azariah says: If the house is blessed on his account he is furnished liberally, but otherwise not. R. ‘Aḳiba says: In either case [the master] should not give him less than fifty zuz. We give him as parting gifts anything except slaves, documents and immovable property.7 Both a man and woman [owner is under the obligation to give parting gifts] but only a man can acquire a Hebrew slave while a woman cannot acquire a [male] Hebrew slave.
Two slaves should not be bought together, [so that a public sale should not be made with two slaves].7a
One who sells himself, one who runs away and one who gains his liberty by deduction of money does not receive parting gifts.
He who is sold for committing a theft should not be sold either in the market-place or in a bazaar, as it is stated, For unto Me the children of Israel are servants.8

If [an Israelite] sells himself to Gentiles, his relatives and the Beth Din are commanded to redeem him, but he is not commanded to redeem himself, as it is stated, One of his brethren shall redeem him; or his uncle or his uncle’s son shall redeem him.9 For R. Ishmael used to say: Seeing that others are commanded to redeem him must he not be commanded to redeem himself? [And if you ask] what do I make of the words, Or if he be waxen rich, he shall redeem himself?10 [The meaning is,] that just as if he redeems himself he does not return to servitude, so if others redeem him he does not return to servitude.11 R. Jose the Galilean said: If the Beth Din [sell him he returns] to servitude,12 but if relatives [redeem him it is] for his freedom; while R. ‘ Aḳiba said: If the Beth Din [redeem him it is] for his freedom but if relatives [redeem him he returns] to servitude.

If he stole two hundred [zuz] and his valuation13 is only a maneh,14 he is sold and sold again.15 If he stole a maneh and his valuation is two hundred zuz he is not to be sold.16 R. Eliezer said: In no case should he be sold unless his sale price and the amount of his theft are equal. He cannot be sold and sold again for the same theft and he returns [after his servitude] to the rank which he formerly held. This is the view of R. Meir; but R. Judah said: He does not return to the rank which he formerly held.17
chapter.ftnote: (1) But he can serve him privately in these capacities. MS.K. and H add ‘or a money-changer to the public’.
(2) [H understands the phrase to mean ‘support his master in walking’.]
(3) MS.K. and H add ‘and sleeps facing him’.
(4) lit. ‘heavy’, i.e. he is not hungry. This is the reading of MS.K. and H. V has ‘even if he is idle’.
(5) i.e. he deducts the time the slave did not work from the period of service.
(6) Deut. XV, 13f.
(7) i.e. things that do not grow from the soil, because Scripture ordained, Thou shalt furnish him liberally out of thy threshing-floor and out of thy wine-press (Deut. XV, 14).

(7a) The words in brackets are added by MS.K. The term ṭumaria, translated ‘public sale’, is obscure but it seems to indicate that too much publicity attaches to the sale of two slaves at once. [Krauss, Lehnwörter reads either טימיתא, ‘price’ (p. 264) or טימוס, ‘tax’ (p. 263).]
(8) Lev. XXV, 55. They must be treated as human beings and not as chattels.

(9) ibid. 48f. E.V. may redeem. To make sense of this passage we must read ‘he is [also] commanded to redeem himself’ instead of ‘but he is not commanded to redeem himself’. R. Ishmael learns this by a fortiori reasoning and uses the verse or if he be waxen rich, etc., from which it might be learnt that he need not sell himself again in order to repay those who have redeemed him.
(10) ibid.
(11) In order to repay them.
(12) To refund the money.
(13) As a slave.
(14) A hundred zuz.
(15) Each time for his valuation of one hundred zuz. [The correct reading is probably ‘not sold again’, cf. Ḳid. 18a (Sonc. ed., p. 82, n. 3.)]
(16) Since half of him cannot be sold (Ḳid. loc. cit.).

(17) [Cf. the discussion in Mak. 13a (Sonc. ed., p. 89). H has a different version of this paragraph: ‘If one has stolen a maneh and his valuation is a maneh, or [if he stole] two hundred [zuz] and his valuation is two hundred [zuz], he may be sold; but [if he stole] two hundred [zuz] and his valuation is a maneh he may not be sold. R. Eliezer said: He is not sold unless his sale price and his theft are equal. [If he stole] a hundred [zuz] and his valuation is two hundred [zuz], he may not be sold. He may not be sold and resold for another theft or for repayment of double (cf. Ex. XXII, 3, 6, 8) or repayment of fourfold and fivefold (cf. ibid. XXI, 37). [After his servitude] he returns to the rank’, etc.]

chapter.title: CHAPTER III
chapter.p: The nirẓa‘ should not have his ear pierced until he declares and repeats [his desire to remain in servitude], as it is stated, But if the servant shall plainly say.1 If the slave has a wife and children but the master has no wife and children, or if the master has a wife and children and the slave has no wife and children, he should not have his ear pierced. That is the view of R. Ishmael; R. ‘Aḳiba said: In either case he should have his ear pierced.

Anything may be used for the piercing, even a scissors,2 but [the proper instrument for] the command to pierce is an awl, as it is stated, And his master shall bore his ear through with an awl.3 He should only be pierced at the top of the ear according to R. Meir; but R. Judah said: He can be pierced also on the flap. He should be pierced only in the right ear in the presence of the Beth Din, as it is stated, Then his master shall bring him unto the Elohim.4 Both door and doorpost are mentioned [in the verse]; why are they both mentioned? It is to compare the door to the doorpost: as the doorpost is upright, so the door must be upright.

A Canaanite slave5 is acquired by money payment, by written deed or by seizure, and he acquires his liberty with money which is paid [to his master] by others or with a written document which he receives [from him]. Such is the opinion of R. Meir; but the Sages said: [He acquires liberty] with money which he himself pays or with a deed received for him by others, provided only that the money belongs to others.6

He goes free for loss of a limb7—for an eye or a tooth, for the tips of the ears, for the tips of the fingers and toes, for the tip of the nose, for the tip of the membrum and for the tips of the breasts in a woman. R. Simeon said: [The last-mentioned applies also] to a man.

If [the master] knocks out two of his teeth together, or blinds his two eyes together, he goes free but receives no compensation; if they were knocked out at different times, he gains his liberty for the first and receives monetary compensation for the second. If [the master] cut off some of his flesh or knocked out a tooth which was about to fall out, he does not go free.8
A slave of whom an Israelite is part-owner9 is [reckoned as] a free man.10

If one sells his slave after thirty days,11 R. Meir says that [the first owner has the benefit of the law of] a day or two,12 but not the second. [R. Judah says: The second also has the benefit.]13 R. Eliezer said: Neither has the benefit of a day or two.

Whoever sells his slave to a Gentile or [to an Israelite] outside the Land [of Israel], or one who goes free for the loss of a limb, [the slave] does not require a deed of manumission. R. ‘Aḳiba says that he does require a deed of manumission.
chapter.ftnote: (1) Ex. XXI, 5. The Heb. is lit. ‘saying shall say’, i.e. say and say again.
(2) Another reading is ‘nail’.
(3) ibid. 6.
(4) ibid. Elohim is understood as ‘judges’.
(5) Any heathen slave was called ‘Canaanite’ with reference to Gen. IX, 25.
(6) Because everything possessed by a Canaanite slave belongs, to his master.
(7) Cf. Ex. XXI, 26f.

(8) Because the flesh would grow again and a slave was liberated only for losses which would not grow again like an ordinary tooth or an eye. MS.K. inserts the sentence: ‘[A slave] can be emancipated by an אנטוקטא or a board or a tablet, but not by a headgear [presented by] kings’. [This addition is a variant of what occurs in Giṭ. 20a (Sonc. ed., p. 77). See there n. 6. Krauss (Lenhwörter I, pp. 267f., and his Talmudische Archäologie II, p. 99) gives a detailed discussion of the reading in MS.K. and quotes the view that it enumerates the Roman methods of manumission and the terms correspond to the Latin manumissio per vindictam, per censum, per tabulas and manumissio in praesentia regis.]
(9) While the other half is free.
(10) i.e. his master must liberate him.

(11) This is meaningless. Kirchheim emends, in accordance with B.Ḳ. 90a (Sonc. ed., p. 519): ‘If one sells his slave to another with the stipulation that he should still serve him for thirty days, R. Meir says’, etc.
(12) The law that if an owner strikes his slave and he survives a day or two days the owner is not punished.
(13) The sentence in brackets is added in MS.K

chapter.title: INTRODUCTION
chapter.p: Masseketh Sefer Torah, ‘the Tractate on the Torah Scroll’, deals with the preparation, correct writing and proper handling of sacred scrolls, particularly the Pentateuch which is used for the reading of the lections in the statutory religious services in the Synagogue.

Forming part of the collection known as Massektoth Ḳeṭannoth, it belongs also to the smaller collection, Sheba‘ Massektoth Ḳeṭannoth, ‘The Seven Minor Tractates’, which is the earliest collection of its kind in the Talmudic literature. All the seven are of great antiquity in their main contents and have their origin in the early period of oral traditions, when the writing down of such traditions was generally forbidden. Their author was a Palestinian who lived before the redaction of the Mishnah (beginning of the third century C.E.).

In the history of Rabbinic literature these tractates are of considerable importance because they represent the earliest digests dealing with a particular subject in a compact, comprehensive and detailed set of rules. Such regulations are scattered throughout the numerous pages of the Talmud, embedded in long and intricate discussions, together with material which has no direct bearing on the subject under treatment.

Although most of the rules in this tractate are to be found in the Tannaitic teaching in the Talmudic literature—Mishnah, Baraitha, and the Palestinian and Babylonian Gemara—twelve rules occur in it which cannot be traced in those sources. These are contained in II, 9f., III, 5-9, and V, 1-3, 6, 8.

There is a very close relationship between Masseketh Sefer Torah and the first five chapters of Soferim, the tractate on ‘Scribes’, and both probably assumed their present form in the Geonic period. It is also clear that the compiler of Soferim was acquainted with this tractate and drew largely upon it,★ but whereas Sefer Torah is characterized by a simple and direct style and a clear cut system of rules, Soferim has numerous interpolations, amplifications and much irrelevant matter. The numbering of the chapters corresponds in the two tractates so far as they overlap, but there is a difference in the length of the respective chapters, their contents, and the numeration and extent of the rules.

Chap. I prescribes the writing materials that must alone be used for sacred scrolls; the languages permitted in the originals and translations; indicates some deviations in the Septuagint from the Masoretic text; and deals also with the rules concerning the sheets, columns, and open and closed sections in the sacred scrolls.

Chap. II indicates the spaces that must be left between letters, words, columns and books in a scroll; the number of columns in a sheet; the width and length of columns and scrolls; the size of the upper and lower margins; blank spaces at the beginnings and ends of scrolls; special arrangement of lines in certain sections; the rollers, sewing and mending; and the disposal of outworn sheets.

Chap. III deals with the kind of books that may be written on one scroll; the extent of the spaces that must separate books of the Pentateuch and books of the Prophets respectively; which scrolls may be separated into smaller books; degrees of sanctity in the various sacred writings; palimpsests; procedure in case of scribal errors; manner of rolling and unrolling scrolls, and how many columns at a time are to be unrolled during the Scriptural reading; their reverential handling; and the respectful use of foodstuffs.

Chap. IV lists the divine names that may not be erased, the names that are always sacred and the words with the same spelling which are secular; and prohibits the profane use of any of the sacred names.

Chap. V discusses cases of error in the writing of divine names, concentration of thought and reverence when divine names are written; procedure when such names are written on a person’s body, on an article of furniture, the horn of an animal or any other object; the writing of small scrolls for children’s instruction; and the storage of disused sacred writings.
I. W. SLOTKI.
chapter.ftnote: ★ [I. H. Weiss, Dor (1904), II, pp. 224f., maintains that Sefer Torah is an abstract from Soferim.]

chapter.title: SEFER TORAH
CHAPTER I
chapter.p: RULE 1. It is not permitted to write a scroll of the Torah1 on skins of ritually unclean cattle or on skins of ritually unclean wild animals, nor may they2 be sewn with [their] sinews or [the parchment rolls of tefillin] be wound with their hair. It is an oral prescription delivered to Moses at Sinai that [these] shall be written on the skins of ritually clean cattle, or on skins of ritually clean wild animals, that they shall be sewn together with ritually clean sinews, [that the tefillin rolls] shall be wound with ritually clean hair, and that the writing be done with ink, because [this latter requirement] has support in Scripture, And I wrote them with ink in the book.3
RULE 2. It is permitted to write [sacred scrolls] on skins of nebeloth and on skins of ṭerefoth and there is no need to consider the possibility of their having been pierced at the animal’s heart.4
RULE 3. Skins5 for the [sacred] books, tefillin and mezuzoth may be bought anywhere, and one need not consider the possibility that they might be skins that were pierced at the animal’s heart.

RULE 4. The writing on ḳelaf must be on the side of the flesh, and on gewil it must be on the side of the hair; and if one changed the one for the other [the scroll] may not be used for the lection [in the statutory services].
RULE 5. [Sacred texts]6 may not be written on difthera, a tablet or erased paper;7 nor with coal,8 shoe-black, or ink containing gum or vitriol. Vitriol may not be added to the ink.

RULE 6. R. Jacob said in the name of R. Meir: Vitriol may be added to the ink. R. Judah said: R. Meir’s statement about [writing with ink containing] vitriol applies to [the whole] Torah9 except the section dealing with a suspected wife.10 R. Jacob retorted: [R. Meir] said, ‘Except the section dealing with a suspected wife’, [by which he meant that] only in the special scroll11 which [was used] in the Temple [must the ink contain no vitriol] because [the writing] had to be blotted out.12
RULE 7. R. Simeon b. Laḳish said in the name of R. Meir, who had it from R. Ishmael, that vitriol may be added to the ink.

RULE 8. [Sacred texts]13 may not be written in [obsolete] Hebrew characters or in the Median, Elamitic or Greek languages.14 Seventy Elders wrote the Torah for king Ptolemy15 in Greek, and that day was as ominous for Israel as the day on which the Golden Calf was made, since the Torah could not be adequately translated.

RULE 9. They [all] introduced [the same] thirteen alterations:16 ‘God created in the beginning’; ‘I shall make a man in image and likeness’; ‘And He finished on the sixth [day] and rested on the seventh [day]’; ‘Male and female He created him’; ‘Come let Me go down’; ‘And Sarah laughed among her relatives, saying’; ‘For in their anger they slew oxen and in their self-will they digged up a stall’; ‘And Moses took his wife and his children and set them upon a carrier of men’; ‘Now the time that the children of Israel dwelt in the land of Canaan and in the land of Egypt was four hundred and thirty years’; ‘I have not taken one desirable thing from them’; ‘And the [beast] with small legs’; ‘Which the Lord thy God hath allotted unto all the peoples to give light under the whole heaven’; ‘And they offer sacrifices to the sun or the moon or any of the host of heaven which I commanded should not be served’.

RULE 10. [Sacred scrolls] must not be written in gold. It is related that, in an Alexandrian scroll17 of the Torah, the divine names were written in gold, and when the matter came before the Sages they decided that it should be stored away.18

RULE 11. If Hebrew words were written in Aramaic or Aramaic words in Hebrew, if Ha’azinu was written in continuous lines,19 or if the breaking up [of the lines] was not done according to the rule, the scroll may not be used for the lections.

RULE 12. If one finished [writing nearly] all the scroll [of the Torah] and less than a column of text remained, one need not hesitate to extend the writing so as to make of this a small column on its own.20

RULE 13. If an open section was written as a closed one or vice versa, the scroll must be stored away. What is an open section? One which commences at the beginning of a line. How much space must there be at the end of a line so that the section beginning at the next line may be called an open one? A space on which may be written a name of three letters.21

RULE 14. Should an entire section be finished at the end of a column, if one [blank] line remained and [the next] section is a closed one, [the scribe] begins it in the middle of the line; but if it is an open section, he begins at the top [of the next column] and leaves that line [blank].22
chapter.ftnote: (1) The scroll of the Pentateuch used for the lections in public worship.
(2) The parchment sheets of which the scroll is made up.
(3) Jer. XXXVI, 18.

(4) It was a heathen practice to remove the heart from a live animal to offer it as a sacrifice, and this, in Rabbinic law (Mishnah ‘A.Z. 29b, Sonc. ed., p. 145) rendered the entire animal, including its skin, forbidden as an idolatrous offering.
(5) Before they were dressed; but dressed skins may be bought only from trustworthy persons who can testify that the dressing had been done in accordance with the law.
(6) Mentioned in Rule 1.
(7) Others ‘palimpsest’. GRA in Sof. I, 5 omits ‘erased’.
(8) Or, ‘black pigment’.
(9) Cf. ‘Erub. 13a [Sonc. ed., p. 82).
(10) Num. V, 11ff.
(11) A small scroll on which were written the curses that would befall an unfaithful wife.
(12) Cf. Num. ibid. 23f.
(13) Mentioned in Rule 1.
(14) According to Meg. 9a (Sonc. ed., p. 48) it is permitted to write the Torah in Greek, though this is not allowed in the case of tefillin and mezuzoth.
(15) Assumed to be Ptolemy Philadelphus who reigned in Egypt, 285-247 B.C.E., and who arranged for the Greek Version, the Septuagint, to be made, as narrated in Sof. I, 8 (cf. the notes ad loc.).
(16) For a comparison of these variants with the Heb. text, cf. on Sof. I, 8.
(17) Cf. note to Sof. I, 9.
(18) lit. ‘it shall be hidden’, i.e. not used for the lections.
(19) Cf. Sof. I, 10, n. 44, for the correct arrangement.
(20) The extension of a short passage over a full column is done either by enlarging the characters or, according to others, by making each successive line shorter than the one preceding it.
(21) The opinion of Maimonides, which has been adopted, is that space must be left for three words, each of three letters (cf. Y.D. CCLXXV, §2).

chapter.title: CHAPTER II
chapter.p: RULE 1. Sufficient space must be left between words1 so that they may be distinguished, and between letters so that they be not mixed. If the letters were mixed up or a break made in the middle of a word, the scroll must not be used for the lection in the statutory services.

RULE 2. [It is permitted] to insert between columns two letters from a long word, but not from a short one. If, however, [the part of a longer word forms] a short word on its own,2 it is forbidden [to insert it between the columns].
RULE 3. In a Torah scroll the space of two finger-breadths must be left [between columns], but in scrolls of the Prophets and in those of Pentateuchs3 a space of one thumb-breadth [only].

RULE 4. In the lower margin of a Torah scroll the space of a handbreadth is left, and in the upper margin two-thirds of a handbreadth;4 but in scrolls of the Prophets and Pentateuchs three finger-breadths in the lower margin and two finger-breadths in the upper. In all these cases5 if it is desired to extend [the margins] this may be done, provided they do not exceed [the space of] the written matter.
RULE 5. Between the books in a Torah scroll a vacant space of four lines must be left, and in a scroll containing the Twelve Prophets three lines.

At the end of a scroll and at its beginning sufficient [parchment] must be left to wind6 [it round the scroll]. In a Torah scroll no limit has been prescribed, but a roller should be attached at the end of the scroll and there is no need to do this at its beginning.7

RULE 6. A sheet of a Torah scroll must contain not less than three columns and not more than eight. In the case of ḳelaf parchments no limit was prescribed, [62b] and one may add [as many columns] as desired provided only there are not less than three columns [to the sheet].
RULE 7. If one finished [writing nearly] all the book8 and one column of text remained, one need not hesitate to make of it a separate small sheet.

RULE 8. If a sheet [of a Torah scroll] is worn out, one may not remove two [columns only] and replace them by two new columns; but three columns should be removed and replaced by three new ones, and the new columns must be written in the same size as the original script.

RULE 9. The width of a column [in a Torah scroll] must be such as to be recognizable at one glance,9 and in a small scroll not less than a handbreadth. R. Jose b. Judah says: It must not be less than the width of three fingers.

RULE 10. The height10 of [a scroll] must not be greater than its circumference,11 nor its circumference greater than its height, but they must be exactly alike,12 and this is the most correct procedure.
RULE 11. A Torah scroll may not consist half of gewil [and half of ḳelaf, but it may consist half of gewil]13 and half [of the ḳelaf] of deers, although this is not the best procedure.

RULE 12. [A tear in a Torah parchment sheet] may not be joined with glue, nor is it permitted to write on a patch, nor may [the sheets] be sewn together on the written side. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said in the name of R. Meir: [A torn sheet] may be joined with glue and it is permitted to write on a patch, but it is forbidden to do the sewing14 on the written side. If a scroll15 is torn, a patch may be placed on the outside.
chapter.ftnote: (1) lit. ‘between name and name’.
(2) e.g. in a word like yimlok (he will reign) the last two letters can form an independent short word lak (to thee).
(3) Intended for ordinary reading or study, and not for the public lections.

(4) lit. ‘two parts of a handbreadth’. This is also the reading of V and M in Sof. II, 4. According to Men. 30a (Sonc. ed., p. 195) and H in Sof. loc. cit. the upper margin must be three finger-breadths wide.
(5) lit. ‘here and there’.
(6) Reading with many authorities lehaḳḳif. V reads lehaḳim ‘to raise up’.
(7) This regulation does not agree with Sof. II, 5.
(8) This refers either to one book of the Prophets or to several of them written in one scroll.
(9) Accordingly, not more than three Hebrew words, each of ten letters, may be written in a line. If the column is wider, the reader experiences difficulty in passing from line to line.
(10) lit. ‘length’.
(11) When rolled up, so according to B.B. 14a (Sonc. ed., p. 67); lit. ‘its width’.
(12) lit. ‘takes the middle course’.

(13) The words of this Rule enclosed within square brackets are added from Sof. II, 10, q.v. If ‘although’ is altered to ‘because’, the text will make sense but will be contrary to the Rule in Sof. loc. cit.
(14) So according to GRA, H and M in Sof. II, 11. V reads here as in Sof. ‘the writing’.
(15) Other than a Torah scroll.

chapter.title: CHAPTER III
chapter.p: RULE 1. It is permissible to join the Torah and the Prophets in one scroll, according to R. Judah; but the Sages say: The Torah and the Prophets must be written in separate scrolls.1

RULE 2. Between a book of the Prophets and another one should not leave the same [empty space] as between two books of the Torah; but in each case the space must be that which has been prescribed for it.2 Furthermore [a book of the Prophets]3 must begin at the top.4

RULE 3. A Torah scroll5 may not be made into [separate] books of the Pentateuch, because it is forbidden to reduce a major sanctity6 to a minor sanctity.7 From scrolls containing sections of the Pentateuch, however, it is permitted to make up a Torah scroll. When may this be done? When the measurements8 and the number of the lines9 are alike.

It is not permissible to join together two sections of the Pentateuch or one and a half of them to form a single scroll.10 But if it was intended11 that additional scrolls be attached to them,12 it is permissible.

RULE 4. If a Torah scroll has spaces or stops [to mark] the beginning of verses, it may not be used for the lections.13 [Similarly] if a letter has been engraved or joined to another, the scroll may not be used for the lections.

RULE 5. A scroll [some of whose letters] are faded may not be used for the public lections.14 R. Simeon b. Eleazar says: If the outline [of the effaced letters] is distinguishable, it is permitted [to rewrite them].
RULE 6. A scroll of the Torah in which a whole line15 is faded may not be used. If the greater part of a line is faded and the smaller part intact, the use of the scroll is permitted.
RULE 7. Not more than four16 columns of the Torah scroll may be unrolled [at one time during the reading of the lection] but there is no objection to the reading of ten [columns] in one [lection].

RULE 8. A scribe may not put upon the written part [of a Torah scroll] a reed-pen with ink on it;17 nor may he take hold of the sheets of parchment and thereby unroll [the scroll]; nor may he18 grasp the parchments to extract the written sheets;19 nor may he remove a scroll from its [case] by shaking it out. All these [restrictions], however, are relaxed in the case of official revisers of Scriptural scrolls.

RULE 9. It is not permissible to place a Torah scroll on a chair and to lean on it with one’s elbows while reading; so according to R. Nehemiah. It is not permissible to place it over a chair [with its sheets] hanging down while it is read in the manner of ordinary documents, because [sacred] books must not be treated with disrespect.

RULE 10. A Torah scroll may not be placed on a bed and [certainly]20 not at its foot or under it; nor may one sit21 on a bed while a [Torah] scroll rests on it. It is related that R. Eliezer22 once sat [unknowingly] on a bed on which a [Torah] scroll lay, and [when he realized it] he jumped up as if a snake had bitten him. [Such respect is shown for the Torah] because Scripture declares, Ye shall eep My sabbaths, and reverence My sanctuary23—it is not the Sabbaths that one reverences but Him Who commanded [to observe them], for Scripture declares, This is my God, and I will glorify Him24 [which means,]25 I will perform the commandment in a beautiful way to His glory.26 Such is the interpretation of R. Ishmael. R. ‘Aḳiba expounds it: I will expatiate on His excellencies.27 Abba Saul explains it: I will be like Him,28 i.e. as He is gracious and merciful so be thou gracious and merciful.

RULE 11. Foodstuffs may not be treated with disrespect. One may not sit on a basket containing dates or dried figs;29 but he may sit on a basket that contains pulse and also on a cake of pressed figs, because it is customary to do so in such cases.30

RULE 12. Foodstuffs may not be used as a covering. R. Meir says: Any fruit which has a husk may be [used as a covering]. R. Judah says: Any fruit which has a stem or a stalk31 may be [used as a covering].32 Foodstuffs may not be eaten with the aid of foodstuffs33 unless they are consumed simultaneously.34
chapter.ftnote: (1) According to GRA (in Sof. III, 1) who adopted the reading of B.B. 13b (Sonc. ed., p. 66): ‘it is permissible to fasten the Torah, the Prophets and the Hagiographa together (in one scroll)’.
(2) i.e. four lines between books of the Torah and three between the books of the Prophets.
(3) If the preceding book ended at the foot of a column.

(4) Of the next column, the reason being that, if the books of the Prophets were separated one from the other, the beginning of each book would commence at the top of a column. This does not apply to Torah scrolls, which may never be cut up into separate books.
(5) Which contains all the five books of Moses.
(6) The Torah scroll in its entirety.
(7) A section of the Pentateuch.
(8) Of all the scrolls that are to be joined together.
(9) In each column.
(10) Since it might be mistaken for a proper Torah scroll.
(11) When these were written.
(12) To complete a full Torah scroll.
(13) Because all proper Torah scrolls must conform to the original without any deviations.
(14) So H and GRA in Sof. III, 8. V reads ‘one shall not rewrite [the letters] in it’.
(15) This is the reading in Sof. III, 9. V reads here ‘one letter’.
(16) And not less than three (cf. Sof. III, 10).
(17) So according to Sof. III, 11. The text in V is meaningless.
(18) This is the reading in Sof. III, 11. V reads ‘but he should’.
(19) Which are rolled up; lit. ‘and bring forth the writing without’.
(20) Cf. N.Y. on Sof. III, 13. The insertion of ‘certainly’ avoids an anticlimax.
(21) lit. ‘that one may sit’.
(22) In Sof. III, 13, ‘R. Eleazar’.
(23) Lev. XIX, 30.
(25) Connecting we’anwehu (I will glorify Him) homiletically with na’eh (beautiful) and understanding it as ‘I will serve Him in a beautiful manner’.
(26) lit. ‘before Him’.
(27) Heb. na’oth, lit. ‘beauties’, excellent attributes.
(28) He explains we’anwehu as the equivalent of ’ani wahu (I and He).
(29) Because they might be crushed and spoilt.
(30) Pulse and dried figs are not spoilt by sitting on them.
(31) Whereby it can be lifted if it should happen to fall into the contents of the vessel it covered.
(32) Since it would not be necessary to throw it away after use.
(33) Using them, e.g., in place of a spoon.
(34) And would not be thrown away.

chapter.title: CHAPTER IV
chapter.p: RULE 1. The following divine names may not be erased, viz.1 Alef-lamed-he-yod-mem,2 Alef-daleth-nun-yod,3 Yod-he-waw-he,4 Shaddai,5 Ẓeba’oth,6 ‘Eheyeh-’asher-’eheyeh.7 R. Jose says: Ẓeba’oth is generally treated as a secular noun.8

RULE 2. If one writes ’El9 it may be erased;10 if ’El of Alef-lamed-he-yod-mem or Yod-he of the four letters [of the Tetragrammaton],11 they may not be erased, because there are divine names corresponding to them.
RULE 3. All prefixes or suffixes connected with a divine name may be erased.
RULE 4. All ordinary words the letters of which are the same as those of a divine name may be erased.12

RULE 5. In For the Lord your God, He is God of gods,13 the first [two]14 are sacred and the last15 is secular. In Lord of lords,16 the first is sacred and the second secular. In the God of Abraham17 it is sacred; in the god of Nahor18 it is secular, and in the god of their father19 it is secular. In Thou shalt not revile God,20 [the noun may bear] a sacred or a secular meaning.21 R. Ishmael22 maintains that the noun is sacred.
RULE 6. All nouns in the Torah [signifying God] that are mentioned in connection with Abraham are sacred except the first.23 R. Ḥanina the son of R. Joshua’s brother holds that it is sacred.24

RULE 7. All names in the Torah mentioned in connection with Lot are secular25 except the last.26 [All names] in the story of Micah27 are secular, even [when they begin with] Yod-he.28 In [the account of] Naboth29 they are sacred even [when they begin with] Alef-lamed.30

RULE 8. In God standeth in the congregation of God, in the midst of the judges31 He judges,32 [the divine name] is used as sacred33 and as secular.34 In God delivereth me to35 the ungodly,36 the first is sacred and the second37 secular. In For hath any said unto God,38 the first [’el] is secular and the second sacred. [In the verse] And let my cry have no39 resting-place,40 etc., [the words whose consonants are the same as those of a divine name] are secular. In God hath given command to speed me41 [the name] is sacred. In Forbear thee from meddling with God, Who is with me,42 the name is sacred, according to the view of R. Jose b. Judah. In O God, the proud are risen up against me,43 the name is sacred but the reader must pause in his reading [after God].44
chapter.ftnote: (1) lit. ‘he who writes’.
(2) Meaning ‘God’.
(3) Translated ‘Lord’.
(4) Composing the Tetragrammaton.
(5) i.e. ‘Almighty’.
(6) Meaning ‘[Lord of] hosts’.
(7) I am that I am (Ex. III, 14).
(8) Which may therefore be erased.
(9) It can mean ‘to’ or ‘God’ so far as the consonants are concerned.
(10) It is presumed to be the preposition ‘to’. This Rule is omitted in Sof. IV, 2.
(11) Which are Yod-he-waw-he.
(12) Because they possess no sanctity.
(14) i.e. your God He is God.
(15) Of gods, signifying ‘judges’ or ‘princes’.
(16) ibid.
(17) Gen. XXXI, 53.
(18) ibid. Nahor did not worship the true God.

(22) In Sof. IV, 5, ‘R. Simeon’.

(24) In his opinion my Lord was addressed to God.

(26) Viz. And Lot said unto them: ‘Oh, not so my Lord’ (Gen. XIX, 18). Lot’s address to the angels is understood as ending at not so, and his petition to God then begins, My Lord, behold, etc. [So the Targum and Shebu. 35b, Sonc. ed., pp. 205f.]
(27) Judg. XVIIf.
(28) The Tetragrammaton.
(29) 1 Kings XXI.
(30) Meaning elsewhere ‘God’.
(31) The Heb. has the consonants of the divine name.
(32) Ps. LXXXII, 1.
(33) In God standeth.
(34) The name bearing the meaning of judges.
(35) Heb. ’el (to) which is the same consonants as the word for ‘God’.
(36) Job XVI, 11.
(37) ’el in the sense of ‘to’.
(38) ibid. XXXIV, 31.
(39) Heb. על, the same consonants as those of the name of God.
(40) ibid. XVI, 18. In Sof. IV, 9 the analysis is extended to the continuation of the verse.
(41) 2 Chron. XXXV, 21.
(42) ibid.
(43) Ps. LXXXVI, 14.
(44) In the absence of the pause, the adjective proud might erroneously be taken as qualifying God.

chapter.title: CHAPTER V
chapter.p: RULE 1. If [a scribe] wrote a sacred name twice,1 he retains the first and erases the latter.2 R. Judah says: If the latter occurred at the end of a column, he erases the first and retains the latter.3

RULE 2. If [the scribe wrote] a secular noun twice,4 he retains the first and wipes away the latter.5 R. Judah says: If the latter was at the top of a column,6 he wipes away the first and retains the latter.

RULE 3. If a scribe writes Yehudah and omits the daleth he inserts it above the line. If he intended to write the Tetragrammaton7 and wrote Yehudah8 instead, he alters the daleth to he9 and wipes away the final letter he.
RULE 4. If it was required to write Yehudah but [the scribe] intended to write the Tetragrammaton, although he [inadvertently] inserted the daleth,10 he erases it and writes another Yehudah.11

RULE 5. If it was required to write the Tetragrammaton but [the scribe] intended to write Yehudah, although he inserted the daleth12 he wipes away the final he and alters [the preceding] daleth into he.13 R. Judah says: He should [also] go over the entire name with the reed-pen and so sanctify it. The Sages said to him: This is not the best procedure.

RULE 6. If in writing the Tetragrammaton he made an error [by omitting] one letter he should suspend it above [the line]. If one erred [by omitting] all the name14 he should suspend it between the lines. So R. Judah; R. Jose says: [The scribe] wipes away the letters preceding it, writes the Tetragrammaton [in their place] and suspends [above the line] the part which he had wiped away. R. Ḥananiah b. ‘Aḳashia says: All the sheet must be stored away.
RULE 7. If one wrote Alef-lamed by mistake three15 times in the clause God delivereth me to the ungodly,16 one retains17 the first and erases18 the latter.19

RULE 8. When one is writing the Tetragrammaton, one may not respond even if the king greets him;20 but if one was about to write two or three divine names successively21 one may pause between them and respond.
RULE 9. After dipping22 the reed-pen [in ink], one may not start with a letter23 of the divine name24 but with a letter of25 the preceding word.

RULE 10. One who wipes away26 a single letter of a divine name transgresses a negative commandment. R. Ishmael27 says: On account of this it is stated, Ye shall destroy their name out of that place;28 and it is also stated, Ye shall not do so unto the Lord your God.29 It is permissible, however, to wipe away ink that dropped on the writing,30 since one’s intention is only to rectify it.

RULE 11. It is not permissible to make a scroll [of the Shema‘]31 or of the Hallel for children.32 R. Judah permits [the writing of a scroll] from In the beginning33 to the story of the Flood,34 and from the beginning of Leviticus to And it came to pass on the eighth day;35 but [in the case of] all the other books [of Scripture the writing of extracts is] forbidden.36 If, however, one intends to add to them,37 it is permissible [to write extracts from the Scriptures in scrolls].

RULE 12. The following names are to be divided:38 Beth-’el,39 Beth-’awen,40 Be’er-sheba‘,41 Poṭifera‘,42 Ẓafenath-pa‘neaḥ,43 [and the words] ḥarah ’af,44 ḥarah ’appi.45 R. Jose says: These must not be divided. All agree that there must be no breaking up of ‘Ammiel,46 ‘Amminadab,47 Ẓuri’el,48 Ẓurishaddai.49

RULE 13. If a person writes a divine name on his body, he must neither bathe nor anoint himself.50 R. Jose says: This is permitted provided only that he does not rub it off. [If he wrote it] on the horn of a cow or on the legs of a bed,51 he scrapes it off52 and stores it away.53 [If he wrote it] on a stone, he detaches it and stores it away.

RULE 14. Should one cut off a strip of a scroll,54 it may [be used for ordinary purposes] if it is a new one,55 but if it is an old scroll56 [the use of the strip] is forbidden. As regards worn-out scrolls, phylacteries and wraps of scrolls, these must be stored away.57 They should not be deposited [in an unclean place]58 but in a deserted spot where they decay naturally.59
