chapter.title: INTRODUCTION
chapter.p: Tefillin, ‘phylacteries’, is one of the ‘Seven Minor Tractates’ in the narrower sense (see Introduction to Sefer Torah). It is the plural of tefillah, a noun derived from the root TFL, ‘to attach’, which is similar to the Syriac TFLTA, meaning ‘attachment, hanging’. They are so named on account of their being worn on the arm and on the head. Another proposed derivation is from PLL, ‘to argue, prove’, because they are evidence that the name of God is called upon Israel (cf. Deut. XXVIII, 10, Tosafoth Men. 33b s.v. leṭoṭafoth). A third suggested derivation is from the root PLA’, ‘separation, distinction’. The tefillin are a constant reminder that Israel must separate themselves from all evil thoughts and deeds.

h1.small: SHAPE AND CONTENTS OF THE TEFILLIN

chapter.p: A tefillah is made of leather, shaped into a quadrangular capsule with a base of thick skin, tithura, on one side of which is a hollow rim, ma‘barta, through which a leather strap, reẓu‘ah, is passed. One tefillah is worn on the arm and the other on the head. Both must be black; but while the top and the sides of the hand-tefillah are smooth, those of the head-tefillah are grooved, being composed of four compartments with an ordinary letter shin on the right side and a specially formed shin with four heads on the left.

The middle of the strap of the head-tefillah is formed into a loop big enough to encircle the head, with the tefillah hanging from it above the forehead. At the back of the head the strap is made into a knot, shaped like the letter daleth, from which the two ends of the strap hang down in front of both shoulders and reaching below the waist (see the illustrations in J.E. X, pp. 22, 24).

One end of the strap of the hand-tefillah is made into a noose with a knot representing the letter yod. The other is threaded through the ma‘barta and then through the noose so that the knot adjoins the capsule while the loop is fastened round the left arm with the tefillah resting on the biceps facing the heart. The longer end of the strap is then wound seven times round the lower part of the left arm, ending with coils round the hand and two fingers, to represent the letters shin and daleth which, together with the yod mentioned, form the divine name Shaddai, ‘Almighty’. The shin on the head-tefillah, the daleth knot at the back of the head and the yod knot of the hand-tefillah also constitute the same divine name. In each capsule four passages from Scripture, enumerated in the tractate, are inserted.

The commandment of tefillin is derived from the following passages: And it shall be for a sign unto thee upon thy hand, and for a memorial between thine eyes (Ex. XIII, 9). And it shall be for a sign upon thy hand, and for frontlets between thine eyes (ibid. 16). And thou shalt bind them for a sign upon thy hand, and they shall be for frontlets between thine eyes (Deut. VI, 8). And ye shall bind them for a sign upon your hand, and they shall be for frontlets between your eyes (ibid. XI, 18).

Though Scripture does not specify tefillin in these verses, tradition from time immemorial interpreted the terms sign, memorial and frontlets as referring to the phylacteries. Many minutiae in the laws of tefillin are said to have been communicated to Moses on Mount Sinai. So familiar was the observance of the commandment that even the Mishnah (completed early in the third century C.E.) does not describe how it is to be performed. It is only from the Gemara and other oral traditions that the details are known.

According to Scripture the commandment is a reminder of the deliverance from the slavery of Egypt. In Ex. XIII, 9, the precept is followed by the reason, For with a strong hand hath the Lord brought thee out of Egypt. To the commandment, ibid. 16, is added, For by strength of hand the Lord brought us forth out of Egypt. The reference in Deut. VI, 8, is followed by, Beware lest thou forget the Lord, Who brought thee forth out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage (ibid. 12); and close to the commandment, in Deut. XI, 18 and preceding it, Scripture declares, And know ye this day … His works which He did in the midst of Egypt unto Pharaoh … and unto all His land (ibid. 2f.).

Another function of the tefillin is to be a reminder of God’s selection of Israel to be His witnesses and to proclaim His Unity. The text, And all the peoples of the earth shall see that the name of the Lord is called upon thee (Deut. XXVIII, 10), is interpreted by R. Eliezer the Great as referring to the head-tefillah (Ber. 6a, Sonc. ed., p. 25).

Practically the entire contents of this tractate are devoted to the details relating to the commandment of tefillin. It deals with the materials and languages that may be used for tefillin scrolls; the shapes and the kind of damage which disqualify them for religious use; and who is and who is not subject to the obligation.

Advice is given in avoiding any disrespectful treatment of the tefillin, and on the remedies should such treatment occur. Guidance is given as to persons from whom they may be bought, and specific laws are laid down on the number of scrolls to be placed in each tefillah, the contents of the scrolls and the kind of capsules required.

It may be stated that there is a difference of opinion between Rashi and his grandson, Rabbenu Tam, on the interpretation of the law relating to the order in which the scrolls are to be placed (for details, cf. J.E., X, p. 23). Some pious Jews, therefore, put on two pairs so as to satisfy the views of the two authorities. That which accords with Rashi is put on first and the other towards the end of the morning service. In certain congregations both are worn simultaneously.

Rules are given in the tractate on the exact place of the head and the arm where the tefillin are to be worn; the times for their observance, excluding the Sabbath and Festivals; which of the two tefillin is to be put on and taken off first; the procedure in the absence of one tefillah; and which shape or covering causes them to be forbidden.

Direction is also provided in circumstances when sacred objects are found on the Sabbath; and where and when tefillin may be kept or worn; and a story is told in confirmation of the respect due to them. Emphasis is laid on the importance of the commandment of tefillin which is as great as the study of the Torah day and night. Its performance and the observance of the precepts of mezuzah and ẓiẓith endear Israel to God.
It should be noted that the tractate is not exhaustive and a number of rules relating to tefillin are not included but are to be found in the Talmud.
[In V the text is continuous. The division into paragraphs and their numbering are adopted from Higger’s edition.]
I. W. SLOTKI.

chapter.title: TEFILLIN
chapter.p: It is not permitted to write [the four scrolls of] tefillin1 on skins of ritually unclean cattle or on skins of ritually unclean wild animals. It is permitted, however, to write them on skins of nebeloth and ṭerefoth and there is no need to consider the possibility of their having been pierced at the animal’s heart.2

If [tefillin scrolls] were perforated, they become unfit for religious use [if the hole occurred] in the written part; but if it occurred in the margin they remain fit. If the letter waw was shaped like a zayin or vice versa, straight-lined letters like curved ones3 or vice versa, open letters closed4 or vice versa, or if the shape of their letters had been altered [in any other way], or if they were written in [obsolete] Hebrew, or were made as a kind of amulet—they are unfit for religious use.

Women, slaves and minors5 are exempt from [the commandment of] tefillin. A minor who knows how to take care of his tefillin is subject to the law of tefillin. It is related that Ṭabi, R. Gamaliel’s slave, used to put on tefillin; Michal, Saul’s daughter, used to put on tefillin; Jonah’s wife used to make the festival pilgrimages6 to Jerusalem.7

[Regarding] the bearers of a bier [to the burial place] and those who relieve them8 and those who relieve the latter, whether in front of the bier or behind the bier9—all who are required [to carry] the bier are exempt10 [from putting on tefillin], but those who are not required for the bier are liable. When a halt is made for lamentations,11 those who are engaged in the lamentations are exempt, but those12 who cannot see13 the inside [space between the rows]14 are liable.

If a person says [to another], ‘Come and read [a Scriptural text] over my son because he is frightened’, or ‘Write, or place, upon him a [holy] scroll’, or ‘Put tefillin upon him that he may sleep’,15 he should not be listened to.16

A tefillah17 is susceptible of ritual uncleanness. [If it becomes unclean, the priest] sprinkles upon it [the water of the red heifer]18 and repeats the process, and then immerses it [in a ritual bath]. R. Ḥanina b. Gamaliel says: It is necessary to unloose it.19 If [a tefillah] fell into water and remained there long enough [for the writing] to be washed away, it should be subjected to an examination.20
Straps of tefillin may be bought anywhere.21 R. Simeon b. Gamaliel says: Any skin that had been used [for a secular] purpose is forbidden [to be used for the straps of tefillin].22

Tefillin may be bought only from a reliable person;23 and where there is no reliable person a pair of tefillin should be given [to an expert] who examines them. This does not mean that the seller gives him the scrolls, but that he himself chooses what he pleases and has them examined.24 If on examination the selected tefillin prove to be fit,25 he may take all the batch without any scruples.26

The [sections of the] head-tefillah are written on four separate scrolls27 [beginning with] Sanctify unto Me;28 And it shall be when the Lord shall bring thee;29 Hear;30 And it shall come to pass, if ye shall hearken.31 So also with the hand-tefillah, except that [all the four sections] are written in one scroll.32 If one wrote them in four separate scrolls [the tefillah] is fit for religious use. R. Judah says: They should be sewn together and put into one capsule.33 R. Judah, however, admits that if two tefillin34 were [like] the head-tefillah, one may wrap one of them in a piece of leather and so convert it into a hand-tefillah.

The hand-tefillah is put on the upper part of the hand35 [because Scripture declares, And it shall be for a sign unto thee upon thy hand,36 which means that the sign shall be for thee37 but not for others38]. 39So also [the Scriptural expression] between thine eyes40 [implies] the upper part of the head, [because] upon thy hand and between thine eyes [occur in juxtaposition we infer]: as upon thy hand [means] on the upper part of the hand, so between thine eyes [means] on the upper part of the head. This is according to R. Eliezer b. Jacob; R. Judah says: It is stated upon thy hand and it is also stated [in the same verse] between thine eyes [the inference being that] as upon thy hand [refers to] a place that is susceptible of ritual uncleanness by one [symptom of] leprosy,41 so also between thine eyes [refers to] a place that is susceptible of ritual uncleanness by one [symptom of] leprosy.42 [Another reason:] It is stated between thine eyes and it is also stated, Nor make any baldness between your eyes:43 as baldness occurs where there is hair [on the head] so you must put the tefillah only where there is hair [on the hand].44 It is stated, And thou shalt write them45 and it is also stated [in juxtaposition] and thou shalt bind them;46 [hence the inference that] the hand that writes [the mezuzah]47 is the hand that binds [the tefillah].48

The commandment of [wearing] tefillin is from dawn until evening. If a person sleeps in the day-time he need not trouble to remove his tefillin. If a man rises early to go on a journey, he should not put them on before the time [for the performance] of the commandment; but if he had put them on before [the proper time for the performance of] the commandment, he should place his hand upon them at the time [for the performance] of the commandment49 and say the benedictions.

[Absence of] the hand-tefillah does not prevent the religious use of the head-tefillah, neither does [the absence of] the head-tefillah prevent the religious use of the hand-tefillah.50 If a man inverted a tefillah capsule51 he has not fulfilled his religious duty.

When a man puts on [the tefillin], he should put on that of the hand first; and when he takes them off, he should take off that of the head first. A similar rule applies in the case of sandals, viz. when he puts them on, he should put on that of the right foot first, and when he takes them off, he should take off that of the left foot first.52 Likewise, any [dish] that is served last53 is removed first, except bread.54

If a man makes his head-[tefillah] round, this is a dangerous practice55 which does not carry with it [the fulfilment of] the commandment.56 To put [the head-tefillah] on one’s forehead or [the hand-tefillah] on the palm of one’s hand57 is in the manner of heresy.58 To overlay them with gold or put [that of the hand] on one’s neḳlah, which means a sleeve, is the manner of the outsiders.59 [63a]

Tefillin may be moved within a house [even on the Sabbath].60 If [on the Sabbath day] a man finds tefillin in a public domain,61 he should carry them [into a safe place] one pair at a time.62 R. Gamaliel says: Two pairs at a time.63 [This rule applies to] both men and women,64 to new tefillin and to old. R. Judah says: [This procedure] is permitted with old tefillin65 but forbidden with new.66

If a man finds a [Torah] scroll or a bundle of tefillin,67 he should pass them on to his fellow, and his fellow should pass them on to his fellow on the Sabbath,68 even though they be a hundred persons. If [there is no other person]69 with him, he70 should take them up [while standing] within four cubits [distance from them] and remove them to [the next point] within four cubits [distance from the first point];71 because R. Simeon said: Any prohibition72 imposed by a Rabbinical Court73 does not apply to holy writings.74

If a man is in a school house or in a House of Study,75 [or] in a privy or a bath-house,76 and forgot to remove his tefillin,77 he should cover them with his hair78 and leave the place.79 If he is unable to do so, he should proceed to a near-by house where he takes them off.80

[Tefillin] may be put into a money-bag even when there is money in it. They may also be suspended from the legs of a bed; but if another person81 be with him [in bed] it is forbidden. They must not be placed under one’s head;82 but if thereby they are protected83 it is permitted.

If a man carried a heavy load84 and was perspiring, he need not trouble to remove his tefillin. A potter should remove the hand-tefillah but wear the head-tefillah.85 A baker should remove the head-tefillah86 and wear the hand-tefillah;87 but if he uses both hands in baking he also takes off the hand-tefillah.

[Regarding a bath-house], if a man is about to enter the room where persons are undressed, he removes his tefillin at a distance of four cubits from the nude persons. If some are undressed and others dressed, he does not remove his tefillin but should not put them on at the outset.88

If a person is about to enter a tannery,89 a pond [enclosure]90 or a wash-house, he removes his tefillin at a distance of four cubits. If a person is about to enter a privy, he removes the tefillin at a distance of four cubits. If it was a superior bathing-place,91 one does not remove the tefillin before he reaches it.

It once happened that R. Eliezer went to Ubelin92 [where he stayed] with a certain house-owner. It was a practice there to bathe in a cave. When R. Eliezer took his clothes off and removed his tefillin,93 [the host] said to him, ‘Rabbi, is not the water of that cave better than that of this one?’ And although there was only a distance of four cubits between the one and the other, R. Eliezer dressed and put on his tefillin,94 because he never walked four cubits without tefillin. In this manner did R. Eliezer make the commandment of tefillin a permanent practice.

Thus used R. Eliezer to say: Great is the commandment of tefillin, for the Holy One, blessed be He, spoke as follows to Israel, But thou shalt meditate therein day and night.95 ‘Sovereign of the universe,’ said Israel to the Holy One, blessed be He, ‘is it possible for us to meditate day and night [in the Torah]?’ The Holy One, blessed be He, answered them, ‘My children, put tefillin on your heads and on your arms and I shall account it to you as if you meditated in the Torah day and night’; as it is stated, And it shall be for a sign unto thee upon thy hand, and for a memorial between thine eyes, that the law of the Lord may be in thy mouth.96

Beloved are Israel [by God], for they observe all the commandments that are in the Torah. How? Tefillin on their hands, tefillin on their heads, a mezuzah on their doors and four ẓiẓith on their garments. Concerning them David, king of Israel, said, Seven times a day do I praise Thee, because of Thy righteous ordinances.97

[The Sages] illustrated this with a parable. To what may this be compared? To a king who said to his wife, ‘Be well dressed and adorned in my presence’. ‘For what reason?’ she asked him. ‘In order that you may be acceptable to me,’ he replied. Similarly the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Israel, ‘My children, be well dressed and adorned in My presence with [your performance of] the commandments’. ‘For what reason?’ they asked Him. ‘In order,’ He replied, ‘that you may be acceptable to Me’; as it is stated, Thou art beautiful, O my love, as Tirẓah,98 [which means,] ‘Thou art beautiful when thou art acceptable99 to Me through [thy performance of] the commandments’.

(59) Persons who follow their own interpretation of Scripture and not that of the Rabbis. [On this paragraph, cf. J. Rabbinowitz, Mishnah Megillah, pp. 128f.]
(60) They are not regarded as articles forbidden to be handled on the Sabbath or Festival, although not worn on the holy days.
(61) Where they may be trodden upon.
(62) The hand-tefillah on his arm and the head-tefillah on his head in the same manner as they are worn on week-days.
(63) As there is sufficient room on the arm and on the head for two sets, he may put two hand-tefillin on his arm and two head-tefillin on his head.
(64) Although the latter are exempt from the commandment of tefillin.
(65) Which show marks of wear or have a proper knot, so that there can be no doubt that they were genuine tefillin.
(66) Since they may be only amulets.
(67) In a public domain where they may be trodden upon.
(68) Each one carrying them a lesser distance than four cubits. Carrying an article a longer distance in a public domain is forbidden on the Sabbath.
(69) The words in square brackets are missing in V but inserted by H.
(70) lit. ‘one [man]’.
(71) And so on, until he reaches a place where they can be properly deposited.
(72) Read ’issur with H instead of ‘omed (standing) in V.
(73) Such as the prohibition to carry objects in a public domain even within a distance of four cubits.

(74) Consequently it is permitted on the Sabbath to carry a Torah scroll or tefillin to a place of safety, provided all the stages between the points of taking up and setting down are each less than four cubits in length.
(75) Places in which the tefillin would not be sufficiently protected if left there.
(76) It would be disrespectful for the tefillin to be left there.
(77) Before the Sabbath had commenced, or before he entered the two last-mentioned places.
(78) So as not to be seen wearing tefillin on the Sabbath in public.
(79) Taking them off when he reaches his home.
(80) Leaving them there until the termination of the Sabbath.
(81) A variant reading is: ‘if his wife be with him’.
(82) To sleep on them; and much more so under any other part of the body.
(83) From thieves or disrespectful treatment.
(84) [This and the following regulations applied at the time when the tefillin were worn throughout the day and not, as now, only during the morning prayers.]
(85) Since his work requires the use of his hands only.
(86) Otherwise the heat of the oven might damage it.
(87) Using his right hand for the baking.
(88) So according to H. V reads: ‘he shall not remove them at the outset’.
(89) Where there are unpleasant smells.
(90) For steeping flax or similar things.
(91) [Cf. Tamid I, 1, Sonc. ed., p. 2, where the Temple was said to have ‘a superior privy’, its superiority being that it could be locked to prevent intrusion.]

(92) Or, ‘Obelin’. There was a village of that name near Jaffa in S. Palestine, and one near Sepphoris in Galilee. A visit by R. Eliezer to Obelin is mentioned in ‘Erub. 11b-12a (Sonc. ed., pp. 71f.).
(93) To bathe in one of the caves.
(94) To walk to the other cave.
(96) Ex. XIII, 9.
(98) Cant. VI, 4.
(99) Tirẓah is of the same root as raẓuï (acceptable).

chapter.title: INTRODUCTION
chapter.p: The commandment of ẓiẓith, ‘fringes’ or ‘tassels’, is derived from the following two verses of Scripture: Speak unto the children of Israel … that they make them … fringes in the corners of their garments (Num. XV, 38), and Thou shalt make thee twisted cords upon the four corners of thy covering (Deut. XXII, 12).

Ẓiẓith must be inserted in each of the four corners of the garment. As modern clothes have no four corners, the ẓiẓith are inserted in the ṭallith, a shawl of wool or silk worn during morning and certain other prayers. The ẓiẓith are suspended from the four corners of the ṭallith as described below.

In addition, a small ṭallith called ṭallith ḳaṭan or ’arba‘ kanefoth with ẓiẓith in its four corners is worn all day as an undergarment. It is rectangular in shape with an opening in the middle through which the head is passed, and it hangs down from the shoulders covering the chest and back. It is made of wool, but other soft materials are also used, particularly in those worn by children.

Four threads, one of them longer than the others, prepared especially for the religious precept, are inserted in each hole which is made near each of the four corners of the big or small ṭallith. The threads are then folded in two equal halves, the long thread projecting from one of these, and a double knot is made. The halves being held together, the long thread is wound round the others seven times. They are then separated and a double knot is made. Eight coils followed by a double knot in a similar manner is the next stage, and this is followed by eleven coils and a double knot, concluding with thirteen coils and a final double knot—a total of thirty-nine coils and five double knots. Originally a thread, or two threads, of blue wool formed part of the four threads, but this practice has been discontinued because the ḥillazon blue prescribed (cf. §10 of the tractate) became unobtainable.

Like tefillin and mezuzah, the ẓiẓith are a reminder to the Israelite of his duty to the Creator of the world and a symbol of His love for those who obey His precepts. The Scriptural injunction, And it shall be unto you for a fringe (Num. XV, 39) continues that ye may look upon it, and remember all the commandments of the Lord, and do them; and that ye go not about after your own heart and your own eyes, after which ye use to go astray . . that ye may remember and do all My commandments, and be holy unto your God (ibid. 39f.).

Beginning with the rules on which persons and garments are subject to the obligation of ẓiẓith, the tractate proceeds to describe how the threads for them are to be made and what their minimum length must be.

Two opinions are recorded on the question whether the absence of the blue or the white wool from the ẓiẓith, or one or more of the four ẓiẓith from the ṭallith, causes disqualification; and the distance of the hole for the ẓiẓith from the corner of the ṭallith is indicated.
Rules are defined on the type of person from whom ẓiẓith may be bought, and on the procedure to be adopted when one of the ẓiẓith is missing.
Various views are expressed on the degree of sanctity to be accorded to ẓiẓith and on the question of their removal from a shroud.

Ḥillazon is declared to be the only blue eligible in the dyeing of the blue threads; a description is given of the fish that produces it; and the tractate concludes with the ruling that the blue dye may be bought only from a reliable person.
[In the Talmud edition the text is continuous. The translation is here divided into paragraphs and numbered as in Higger’s edition.]
I. W. SLOTKI.

chapter.title: ẒIẒITH
chapter.p: All1 are subject to the obligation of ẓiẓith. R. Simeon exempts women since [the commandment of ẓiẓith] is a positive commandment which is dependent on a fixed time.2 Any minor who knows how to wrap himself with a ṭallith3 should be provided with it by his father.
A ṭallith which is [long enough to] cover one’s head and the greater part of the body is subject to ẓiẓith.

As regards a [linen] sheer, Beth Shammai exempt it [from ẓiẓith],4 but Beth Hillel declare it liable.5 An undergarment is exempt, but R. ‘Aḳiba holds that it is liable. A [double-sized] ṭallith that is folded over is subject to ẓiẓith, but R. Simeon exempts it.6

A ṭallith consisting entirely of blue wool is subject to ẓiẓith.7 A bolster converted into a sheet or a sheet converted into a ṭallith is subject to ẓiẓith. A night garment and bed-curtains8 are exempt from ẓiẓith.9 A toga,10 a travelling cloak,11 shawls fastened at the shoulder,12 a cloak worn on the head,13 and an ’anṭenah14 are exempt. This is the general rule: Any [garment] that is without four corners is exempt from ẓiẓith.

As for the commandment of ẓiẓith, Beth Shammai say: [It requires that there shall be] four threads, [each] of four finger-[breadths in length]; but Beth Hillel say: Three threads [each] of three finger-[breadths in length]. R. Jose b. Judah remarked: Although Beth Hillel said, ‘Three [threads, each] of three [finger-breadths in length]’, their ruling is practically identical with that of the other.15

Leaving out [from the ẓiẓith] the blue threads though not the white ones, or the white threads though not the blue ones, invalidates them because [the absence of] either the blue or the white invalidates the other. R. [Ishmael]16 maintains: The absence of one does not invalidate the other.
[The absence of one] of the four ẓiẓith invalidates the others, because all of them [constitute] a single religious observance. R. Ishmael says: They are four independent observances.

[Each] ẓiẓith is inserted [in a hole] within three finger-[breadths] of [each] corner; farther away than this is invalid If it was inserted in the border, it is invalid; if between a handbreadth [from the edge] and the border, it is valid. R. Eliezer b. Jacob declares it to be invalid.

[If a strip less than three finger-breadths in length]17 was cut off [from a ṭallith]18 and then rejoined to it, [the ṭallith] is valid. R. Meir declares it to be invalid.19 [If the detached part] was made into [a smaller ṭallith] on its own, it is valid.
If one buys a ṭallith from an idolater or a Samaritan and found blue threads in it, it is invalid;20 but [if a ṭallith is bought] from an Israelite, it is presumed to be valid.
A ṭallith, one of whose ẓiẓith is missing,21 may be worn in public.22 If two ẓiẓith are missing it may be folded into triangular shape.23 If three ẓiẓith are missing, it may not be worn in public.24

Ẓiẓith [of a ṭallith used as a shroud] upon a corpse should not be undone.25 Abba Saul b. Boṭhnith said, ‘My father told me, “When I die, undo the ẓiẓith [in my ṭallith] because they come within the category of holiness” ’.26 The Sages said: It does not come within the category of holiness, so one may use it as a shroud for the dead or as a pack-saddle for an ass.

Should a man dye [the ẓiẓith of] a ṭallith for himself, they are invalid for religious use if he intended to test [the dye].27 If he dyed them [with an ordinary dye], even four or five times, they are invalid, since the blue [of the ẓiẓith] must be dyed only with that of ḥillazon.28

What does the ḥillazon resemble? In its formation it resembles a fish and [the colour of] its body resembles [the blueness of] the sky. Its appearance is a very rare occurrence29 and consequently it is very costly.
If one finds blue [threads], even though they are twined,30 they are invalid, since the blue [for ẓiẓith] may be bought only from a reliable person.31
chapter.ftnote: (1) Even women.
(2) From which women are exempt. The duty of wearing ẓiẓith is restricted to day-time.

(3) lit. ẓiẓith, but applied to the shawl to which it is attached. [Cf. the wording of the benediction connected with the performance of the commandment in P.B., p. 14, where ‘fringed garment’ is simply ẓiẓith in the Heb.]
(4) Because woollen ẓiẓith in a linen garment are forbidden as mingled stuff, wool and linen together (Deut. XXII, 11).

(5) In their view the prohibition of wearing mingled stuff is superseded by the commandment of ẓiẓith, since the prohibition in Deut. is immediately followed (in verse 12) by the commandment of twisted cords or ẓiẓith. The juxtaposition of the two commandments indicates that the latter supersedes the former.
(6) Since if it should happen to be unfolded, the ẓiẓith would not be in their proper place, in the four corners, but in the middle of the sheet.
(7) The blue texture of the ṭallith does not exempt it from ẓiẓith although one thread of blue (Num. XV, 39) in each of the four ẓiẓith is sufficient.
(8) Or, ‘covers’.
(9) In the commandment it is stated, That ye may look upon it (ibid.), which rules out garments worn during the night.
(10) Reading ṭoga’ with Jastrow. V has ṭrigon which means ‘a triangular [cloak]’. [It was oval in shape and therefore did not require ẓiẓith; cf. Krauss, Talmudische Archäologie, I, p. 611, n. 589.]
(11) In V pilgas which Jastrow emends to pinolës (the Greek phainoles). [It is the paenula worn by Roman slaves; Krauss, op. cit. I, p. 170.]
(12) In V pokaltorin, which Jastrow reads as pibolaṭorin, the Latin fibulatorium.
(13) In V ’arbiḳwah. [Krauss loc. cit. identifies it with saga Nervica, a garment of various materials and in different colours.)
(14) According to Jastrow possibly a corruption of the Greek tebenna, a kind of Roman toga.
(15) lit. ‘the words of these are near to be like the words of those’; i.e. of Beth Hillel, who refer to the fingers of a larger hand, and Beth Shammai to those of a smaller hand.
(16) The name is added in H.
(17) So according to Men. 41a (Sonc. ed., pp. 247f.).
(18) That had no ẓiẓith (Rashi ad loc.).

(19) His reason being that, as it is proper to insert ẓiẓith within three finger-breadths from the corner, one might use a hanging thread left from the sewing as one of the four threads required for the ẓiẓith. But that would render the entire fringe invalid, since all the threads have to be made specifically for the purpose of the commandment, whereas the hanging thread was one ready made (cf. Men. Sonc. ed., p. 248, nn. 1f.).
(20) The colour might not be that of the ḥillazon blue, which is the only colour that is recognized.
(21) lit. ‘taken’.
(22) lit. ‘one takes hold of it and goes out’.
(23) So covering the missing ẓiẓith.
(24) lit. ‘to go out with it’.
(25) The removal of the ẓiẓith would be an insult to the dead, which is condemned in Prov. XVII, 5, Whoso mocketh the poor blasphemeth his Maker, and a dead man is the poorest of all.
(26) And should be undone before the ṭallith is used as a shroud.
(27) The dyeing of ẓiẓith must be for the specified purpose of the commandment. The reading ‘to test’ [lenassoth] is preferable to the variant ‘to cover himself’ [lekassoth].
(28) A species of mollusc.
(29) lit. ‘it only rises [from the sea] in seventy years’.
(30) As ẓiẓith are.
(31) Or, ‘expert’, who knows that only ḥillazon blue may be used.

chapter.title: INTRODUCTION
chapter.p: Mezuzah means literally ‘a doorpost’, but it is the technical term given to the small scroll which is placed on the right-hand doorpost of a dwelling-house as described below.

Deut. VI, 9, And thou shalt write them upon the door-posts of thy house, and upon thy gates, with its repetition in XI, 20, is the Scriptural origin of the commandment in general terms. Tradition supplies the practical interpretation in detail. As the tractate deals specifically with many, if not most of these details, it was given its title. Josephus (38-95 C.E.), in his Antiquities IV, viii, 13, speaks of the mezuzah as an old and firmly established institution.

Two passages of Scripture are written on the mezuzah scroll: Deut. VI, 4-9 and ibid. XI, 13-21. The scroll is a rectangular piece of parchment made of skin from a ritually clean animal and the script is Hebrew.

On the upper third of the rolled-up scroll the divine name Shaddai (Almighty) is inscribed; and in accordance with a cabbalistic direction three words, representing ‘the Lord, our God, the Lord’, are written at the bottom of the back of the scroll. It is enclosed in a tube or oblong case of wood, metal or any other suitable material. An opening is usually made in it to allow the name Shaddai to be seen, and to protect the writing without concealing the divine name the opening is covered with a transparent material. Some mezuzah cases are artistically carved and beautifully ornamented (see the illustrations in J.E. VIII, pp. 531ff.). It is customary to touch and kiss the mezuzah on entering and leaving the room.

Maimonides, summarizing the traditional rules on the conditions required to make a room or building liable to the obligation of a mezuzah, lays down the following requirements: It must have an area of four cubits square; two doorposts; a lintel; a ceiling and doors. The doorway must be a minimum of ten handbreadths in height; the room must be for ordinary and not sacred purposes; it must be used for human habitation; it must not be used as a privy or bath-room; and it must be a permanent and not temporary structure.

‘They (the Jews) are also to inscribe the principal blessings from God upon their doors, that God’s readiness to bless them may appear everywhere conspicuous about them.’ So wrote Josephus in the passage referred to above. ‘It is incumbent on every Jew,’ declared Maimonides, ‘to be most scrupulous in the observance of the commandment of mezuzah, so that whenever he enters or leaves the room he meets the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, and is reminded of His love and unity. Thus he will be awakened from his slumber, errors and vanities. He will be driven to the realization that nothing endures for ever except the knowledge of the Rock of the universe. This contemplation will inevitably bring him back to self-realization and plant him in the paths of the upright.’

Chapter I discusses the materials on which a mezuzah should or should not, be written; the marginal spaces to be left around the written text; and where perforation causes no disqualification of the scroll. It forbids the alteration of the shape of the letters and the use of obsolete Hebrew. A list of types of buildings and other structures and doorways that are exempt from the mezuzah concludes the chapter.

The second chapter lays down that the mezuzah is to be placed on the right-hand doorpost, and defines which of the two doorposts is to be so regarded, drawing a distinction between different types of houses and various other structures. It deals also with the exact position on the doorpost to which the mezuzah is to be affixed, limits the distance between the entrance and the mezuzah, and indicates the manner of affixing.

Regulations are given on the time allowed to elapse before a mezuzah must be affixed. A distinction is drawn between a tenancy in the Land of Israel and outside it, and between a house rented from a Jew and one rented from a Gentile. The chapter concludes with limiting the period within which a mezuzah and certain other ritual objects must be re-examined in order that their condition and suitability for their continued use may be verified.
[In the Talmud edition the text in each chapter is continuous. It has been divided into paragraphs and numbered in agreement with Higger’s edition.]
I. W. SLOTKI.

chapter.title: MEZUZAH
CHAPTER I
chapter.p: It is not permitted to write mezuzoth on the skins of ritually unclean cattle or on skins of ritually unclean wild animals. It is permitted, however, to write them on skins of nebeloth and ṭerefoth, and there is no need to consider the possibility of their having been pierced at the animal’s heart.1
It is required to leave [a space of] one line on every side [of the text of the mezuzah], according to R. Simeon b. Eleazar.
If a hole was made in the place of the script it is unfit for religious use; but if it occurred in the margin it remains fit.

If the letter waw [in a mezuzah] was shaped like a zayin or vice versa, curved letters like straight-lined letters2 or vice versa, open letters closed3 or vice versa, or if the shape of its letters had been altered [in any other way], or if it was written in [obsolete] Hebrew, it is unfit for religious use.

A magazine for straw, a wood-shed [and any] storage room are exempt [from the mezuzah].4 A stable for cattle is exempt, but if women make use of it5 it is liable. Cone-shaped huts,6 travellers’ stations, field sheds7 and tanneries are exempt from mezuzah.8
A bath-house is exempt, but if a dwelling-house adjoins it the outer doorway is liable.
A corner doorway that has only one doorpost, [or] a doorway made in [a structure of] boards which has only one doorpost is liable. R. Eliezer b. Jacob declares it exempt.

Arched doorways are exempt, but R. Meir and R. Judah declare that they are liable. All, however, agree that if they have the [usual] structure below9 and the arched section above they are liable to mezuzah.

City gates, the gates of open places10 and the gates of Temple Courts are exempt.11 [The doorways of] chambers in the Temple were exempt from mezuzah, but the Chamber of the Counsellors,12 which served as a residence for the High Priest on seven days in the year,13 and potters’ booths are subject to mezuzah. R. Jose declares them exempt.
chapter.ftnote: (1) There was a heathen practice to remove the heart from an animal while it was still alive and offer it as a sacrifice. Rabbinic law regards such an animal as an idolatrous offering (cf. Mishnah ‘A.Z. 29b, Sonc. ed., p. 145) and forbids its entire use, including the skin.
(2) e.g. an ordinary kaf like the final kaf.
(3) An ordinary mem like the final mem.
(4) Only dwelling-houses are subject to the obligation.
(5) In which to adorn themselves; but if they use any of the structures for bathing it is exempt (cf. Yoma 11a, Sonc. ed., p. 48; Y.D. CCLXXXVI, §2).
(6) [Used by watchers in a field or by hunters; Krauss, Talmudische Archäologie, I, p. 6.]

(7) [Krauss, Lehnwörter, p. 226, and Talm. Arch. I, p. 276, n. 81, reads hilaḳṭiyoth. Maimonides understood the term to mean ‘summer-house’, thatched on top and open on the four sides. More probably it was used for stacking hay, etc., where it was dried by the wind.]
(8) They are not dwelling-houses.
(9) Being four handbreadths wide and reaching to a height of ten handbreadths (cf. ‘Erub, 11b, Sonc. ed., p. 69).
(10) Where people assemble for special prayers or to discuss public matters.
(11) [But according to Yoma 11a, Sonc. ed., p. 47, city gates require a mezuzah.]

(12) Reading lishkath parhedrin, one of the Temple chambers, in agreement with Yoma 10a (Sonc. ed., p. 45). V and H read: lishkath shel beth happarwah, ‘the chamber of the Parwah house’, Parwah being the name of its Persian builder (cf. ibid. 35a, Sonc. ed., p. 161, n. 6).
(13) Before the Day of Atonement (cf. ibid. 2a, Sonc. ed., p. 1).

chapter.title: CHAPTER II
chapter.p: The mezuzah is placed1 on the right-hand side of the entrance from the street into the lodge, and [on the right-hand side of] the exit from the courtyard into the lodge.2

If a garden has a doorpost where it adjoins the courtyard, the mezuzah is placed [on the right-hand side of] the exit from the garden into the courtyard; and if a lodge is attached to it,3 mezuzoth are to be placed on both doorways [of the lodge].
Where small rooms open into a reception room,4 the mezuzah is placed on that doorway which is customarily used.5 If they are all customarily used, mezuzoth are placed on all the doorways.
If a number of rooms have doorways leading from one room to the other,6 mezuzoth are placed at the entrance of each one of them. R. Judah says: If the ladder is movable on the four sides….7

If a doorway leads from a roof [into a room], the mezuzah is placed [on the right-hand side of] the entrance from the roof. R. Nathan b. R. Jose said: In such a case Beth Shammai hold that the doorway is subject to mezuzah and Beth Hillel hold that it is exempt.

In a booth that is set back8 from [the edge of] a roof the mezuzah is to be placed [on the right-hand side of] the exit from the booth to the roof. R. Jose says: [On the right-hand side of the entrance] from the roof to the booth.

In the case of a portico that is set back from the rooms and has no other exit,9 the mezuzah is placed [on the right-hand side of] the exit from the portico into the rooms. R. Jose says: [On the right-hand side of] the entrance from the rooms to the portico.

If an entrance serves as two doorways and a wall [of not more than] one handbreath in width [separates them], only one mezuzah is to be affixed, according to R. Judah. [If the wall was] wider than that two mezuzoth are required.

The mezuzah is placed in the upper half of the doorpost;10 so R. Meir. R. Judah says: [It should be placed] below the handbreadth [from the top of the doorpost] and above one handbreadth [from the bottom].

If one made a groove in the wall at a distance of [not more than] one handbreadth [from the doorpost], and placed [the mezuzah] in it, the mezuzah is valid. [If the distance] was greater than that it is invalid.

If one made a groove in a stick and put the mezuzah in it, it is invalid. If one inserted [the mezuzah] in a tube and hung it up behind the door [or] behind the doorpost,11 R. Meir declared it valid, but R. Judah declared it invalid.
A new house is subject to the obligation of mezuzah as soon as it is completed.

One who lodges in an inn in the Land of Israel for thirty days is subject to the obligation of mezuzah, and if one rents [a house] he must affix [a mezuzah] forthwith. Outside the Land of Israel, [one who lives in an inn] is exempt, and one who rents [a house] must affix [a mezuzah] after thirty days.

[A Jew] who rents a house from a Gentile or from a Samaritan must affix a mezuzah forthwith, and when he quits he must remove it; but if one rents a house from an Israelite, he affixes the mezuzah forthwith and when he quits he must not remove it.

One who buys a house from a Gentile or a Samaritan is under the obligation of putting a mezuzah, but [if he bought it] from an Israelite it is presumed [to have been provided with the necessary mezuzoth].
If one buys a brick-mould from a Gentile, he should not heat it before he had examined it.

[The scroll in] the mezuzah should be examined once in twenty-five years, according to R. Simeon. R. Jacob says: A much longer time [may be allowed to intervene]. Both, however, agree that if it was transferred from one place to another it requires examination.

In like manner, water-tanks12 in a public domain must be examined once in seven years, but those situated in a private domain once in twenty-five years, according to R. Meir; but the Sages say: In either case the general rule is that wherever there is a top cover13 the examination takes place once in seven years, and where there is no top cover the examination takes place once in twenty-five years.
chapter.ftnote: (1) lit. ‘written’.
(2) It refers to where the lodge is in front of a courtyard and has two doorways, one facing the street and the other facing the courtyard.
(3) Between the garden and the courtyard, with doorways leading to each of them.
(4) Access to which is gained only through the small ones.
(5) So according to H. V’s reading is corrupt.
(6) lit. ‘rooms within one another’.
(7) The sentence is obviously incomplete. H reads: ‘If the ladder is movable a mezuzah is placed at every side’; but this also does not convey much sense.
(8) lit. ‘within’.
(9) Except through one of the rooms.
(10) lit. ‘from the half and above’. Another reading is: ‘on the upper third’; cf. the ruling in the name of Samuel in Men. 33a (Sonc. ed., p. 208).
(11) Hanging the stick on the doorpost.
(12) lit. ‘machines’. H has mogeroth, ‘stores’.
(13) Reading with H beth instead of V’s bath.

chapter.title: GLOSSARY
chapter.p: ’AB. The fifth month in the Hebrew calendar.
AB BETH DIN (lit. ‘father of the house of judgment’). President of the Grand Sanhedrin, second in authority to the Nasi’.
‘ABOTH (lit. ‘fathers’). Abbreviation of Pirḳë ’Aboth, ‘Chapters of the Fathers’, an ethical tractate included in the Mishnah.
’ADAR. The twelfth month in the Hebrew calendar.
’AGGADAH (pl. -doth). A form of the Heb. Haggadah, lit. ‘narration’. The non-legal portions of the Talmud.
’AGGADTA. The Aramaic form of ’Aggadah.
ALEF. The first letter of the Hebrew alphabet, not audibly pronounced.
‘AM HA’AREẒ (lit. ‘the people of the earth’). Denotes Jews who are not scrupulous in the performance of the laws concerning tithes and ritual purity; the opposite of Ḥaber.
AMIDAH (lit. ‘standing’). The series of benedictions which are to be recited while standing; cf. P.B., pp. 44-54. See also under Musaf.
AMORA (pl. -aïm) (lit. ‘speaker’). Name given to a Rabbi of the Talmud who lived after the redaction of the Mishnah.
ASHKENAZIM. Jews who originated in Central and Eastern Europe, in contrast to Sefaradim.
AẒERETH (lit. ‘closing’). The name given by the Rabbis to the Festival of Pentecost as the ‘conclusion’ to Passover.
BARAITHAH (pl. -thoth) (lit. ‘that which is external’). A Tannaitic teaching which was not included in the Mishnah.
BAREKU (lit. ‘bless ye’). The invocation preceding the benedictions before the Shema‘; cf. P.B., p. 37.
BATH ḲOL (lit. ‘daughter of a voice’). A pronouncement from heaven.
BETH. The second letter of the Hebrew alphabet, pronounced b.
BETH DIN (lit. ‘the house of judgment’). A Jewish legal court.
BETH HAMMIDRASH (lit. ‘the house of study’). A school for study of the Torah.
DALETH. The fourth letter of the Hebrew alphabet, pronounced d.
DEMAI (lit. ‘dubious’). Agricultural produce about which there is doubt whether the regulations concerning dues to the priests and Levites and ritual cleanness have been observed.
DIFTHERA. A Greek word for ‘leather’. It is defined in Meg. 19a (Sonc. ed., p. 115) as ‘a skin which has been salted and put in flour but not treated with gall nuts’. A form of parchment.
DINAR. The Latin denarius. A silver or golden coin, the former being one twenty-fourth the value of the latter.

῾ERUB (lit. ‘mixture’). There are three kinds of ‘Erub. Where it occurs in the tractate it refers to ‘Erub ḥaẓeroth, ‘a mixture of buildings with a court in common’. The inhabitants contribute to a dish of food which is deposited in one of the houses. By this act all the houses there are legally regarded as common to all, so that it is permitted to carry objects on the Sabbath across the court from one building to another.
GAON (pl. Geonim) (lit. ‘excellency’). In the post-Talmudic period the title given to the head of an Academy in Babylon.

GEHINNOM (lit. ‘the valley of Hinnom’). In Greek Gehenna. The name of a valley, south of Jerusalem, where the horrors of human sacrifice were practised; used in Rabbinic Heb. as the name of the place where the wicked expiate their misdeeds after death.
GEMARA (lit. ‘completion’). The discussion of the Mishnah which together with it constitutes the Talmud.
GER (pl. -im) (lit. ‘resident alien’). Term for a proselyte to Judaism.
GEṬ. Jewish document of divorce.
GEWIL. Scraped hide; an inferior kind of parchment.
HA’AZINU (lit. ‘give ear’). The Scriptural lection consisting of Deut. XXXII.
HABDALAH (lit. ‘division’). The service which marks the conclusion of a Sabbath or Festival (cf. P.B., pp. 216f).
ḤABER (pl. -im) (lit. ‘associate’). A Jew who is scrupulous in the observance of the laws relating to tithes and ritual purity; the opposite of ῾Am ha’areẓ.
HAFṬARAH (lit. ‘dismissal’). Reading from the Prophets which follows the lection from the Pentateuch.
ḤAKAM (lit. ‘wise’). One learned in the Torah.
HALAKAH (pl. -oth) (lit. ‘going’). (i) The legal section of the Talmud, opposite of ’Aggadah; (ii) decision arrived at after discussion on a point of law.
ḤALAL (pl. -lim). One who is disqualified for the priesthood because of his father’s invalid marriage.
ḤALALAH (pl. -loth). The daughter of a kohen from an invalid marriage.
ḤALIẒAH (lit. ‘untying [a shoe]’). The ceremony of freeing a childless widow to marry when her levir refuses to wed her (cf. Deut. XXV, 5ff).

ḤALLAH (lit. ‘rounded cake’). A piece of dough set apart as the priestly due from five species of grain (wheat, barley, spelt, oats and rye) which was being kneaded (cf. Num. XV, 17ff). After the destruction of the Temple, the piece was separated and burnt.
HALLEL (lit. ‘praise’). Psalms recited on Festivals and the New Moon (cf. P.B., pp. 219-224).
ḤALUẒAH. A woman who has undergone ḥaliẓah.
ḤANUKKAH (lit. ‘dedication’). The Festival to celebrate the cleansing and rededication of the Temple by Judas Maccabeus.
HE. The fifth letter of the Hebrew alphabet, pronounced h.
ISSAR. The Latin assarius; a small Roman coin worth one twenty-fourth of a silver dinar.
ḲAB. Measure of capacity, one sixth of a se’ah.
ḲADDISH (lit. ‘holy’). A form of doxology in the ritual (cf. P.B., pp. 37, 75f), or recited by a son for eleven months after the death of a parent (P.B., pp. 77f).
KARETH (lit. ‘excision’). Punishment for sin not inflicted by a Beth Din but divinely imposed through premature death or a sudden fatality.
ḲEDUSHAH (pl. -shoth) (lit. ‘sanctification’). The form of doxology which is inserted in the repetition of the ‘Amidah (cf. P.B., pp. 45f, 137f, 160f).
ḲELAF (lit. ‘split’). A superior kind of parchment.
ḲERË (lit. ‘read’). The Heb. text of Scripture as it is to be read according to the Masorah.
KETHIB (lit. ‘written’). The Heb. text of Scripture as it is traditionally written.
KETHUBAH (lit. ‘written [document]’). The Jewish marriage contract specifying the wife’s settlement.
ḲIDDUSH (lit. ‘sanctification’). The benediction over wine to mark the inauguration of a Sabbath or Festival (cf. P.B., pp. 124, 230f).
ḲIDDUSHIN (lit. ‘sanctifications’). The Jewish rite of marriage.
KISLEW. The ninth month of the Hebrew calendar.

KOHEN (lit. ‘priest’). A male descendant in the male line from the High Priest Aaron, qualified to minister in the Temple. After the destruction of the Temple, the distinctiveness of a kohen was preserved by his being called first to the reading of the Torah and not defiling himself by contact with a corpse except in the case of a nearest relative.
KOR. A measure of capacity equal to 20 se’ah.
LAMED. The twelfth letter of the Hebrew alphabet, pronounced l.
LOG. A liquid measure, equal to about 549 cubic centimetres.
LULAB (lit. ‘palm-branch’). The branch of the palm which, bound together with myrtle and willows, is used on the Festival of Tabernacles (cf. Lev. XXIII, 40).
MA῾AMADOTH (lit. ‘stations’). Groups of lay Israelites who represented the people with their presence during the offering of the sacrifices.
MA῾ASER (lit. ‘tenth part’). The annual tithe due to the kohen or to be consumed by the owner in Jerusalem or devoted to the poor every third year.
MAFṬIR (lit. ‘dismisser’). The person called to the concluding portion of the Scriptural reading and follows it with the hafṭarah.
MASORAH (lit. ‘tradition’). The traditional readings of the text of the Hebrew Bible.
MEGILLAH (lit. ‘scroll’). A term applied to the Books of Canticles, Ruth, Lamentations, Ecclesiastes and, without definition, Esther which is read on Purim.
METH MIẒWAH (lit. ‘a corpse which is a religious commandment’). A dead body without relatives to attend to its burial, the duty of so doing devolving upon whoever found it.
MEZUZAH (pl. -zoth) (lit. ‘door-post’). A piece of parchment inscribed with Deut. VI, 4-9, XI, 13-21 affixed in a case to the door-post.
MIDRASH (-shim) (lit. ‘exposition’). The aggadic exegesis of Scripture; a collection of such expositions.
MIḲRA’ (lit. ‘reading’). A term for the Hebrew Scriptures.
MIḲWEH (lit. ‘gathering [of water]’). The ritual bath used for purification after ritual defilement.
MIL. Greek or Latin for ‘a thousand [paces]’. A measure of distance, equal to 2,000 cubits, about 1,000 yards.
MINA. The Greek mna. A gold or silver coin worth 100 zuz.
MISHNAH (pl. -nayoth) (lit. ‘teaching by repetition’). The codification of Rabbinical law by Judah the Prince, c. 200 C.E.
MIẒWAH (pl. -woth) (lit. ‘commandment’). A religious duty.
MUSAF (lit. ‘additional offering’). The additional ‘Amidah included in the service on the Sabbath, New Moon and Festival.
NASI’ (lit. ‘prince’). The President of the Grand Sanhedrin and later of a Rabbinical academy.
NEBELAH (pl. -loth). An animal which died from natural causes and was not ritually slaughtered.
NEZIḲIN (lit. ‘damages’). The fourth Order of the Mishnah.
NIDDAH (lit. ‘an isolated woman’). A menstruant or the period of menstruation.
NISAN. The first month of the Hebrew calendar.
NUN. The fourteenth letter in the Hebrew alphabet, pronounced n.
‘ORLAH (lit. ‘foreskin’). The fruit of trees which may not be eaten during the first three years of planting (cf. Lev. XIX, 23ff).
PERUṬAH. A coin of small value.
PIRḲË ’ABOTH (lit. ‘the Chapters of the Fathers’). An ethical tractate included in the Mishnah.
PONDION. Abridged from the Latin dupondium. A coin worth one-twelfth of a zuz.
PURIM (lit. ‘lots’). The Feast which commemorates the frustration of Haman’s plot to destroy the Jews of Persia.
RABBAN (lit. ‘our master’). Title of respect, higher than ‘Rabbi’, accorded to four Tannaïm: Gamaliel I and II, Simeon b. Gamaliel and Joḥanan b. Zakkai.
RESH. The twentieth letter of the Hebrew alphabet, pronounced r.
SE’AH. Measure of capacity, equal to six ḳab, about 13,184 cubic centimetres
SEDER (lit. ‘order’). The ritual of the home celebration on the first and second nights of Passover.
SEFARADIM. The Jews who originated in Spain, Portugal and some countries of the Middle East.
SEFER TORAH (lit. ‘book of the Torah’). The MS. scroll of the Pentateuch used for the lections in the Synagogue.
SELA῾. A coin of the value of two shekels.
SHAS. Compounded from the initials of Shishshah sedarim, ‘the six Orders [of the Mishnah]’; a term for the Talmud.
SHEBAṬ. The eleventh month in the Hebrew calendar.
SHEMA‘ (lit. ‘hear’). The opening word of Deut. VI, 4, ‘Hear, O Israel’ which is daily recited in the liturgy.
SHIN. The twenty-first letter in the Hebrew alphabet, pronounced sh.
SHOFAR (lit. ‘ram’s horn’). The instrument sounded in the Synagogue on the New Year and conclusion of the Day of Atonement.
SIDRA’ (lit. ‘order’). The portion of the Pentateuch read in the Synagogue on each Sabbath.
SIWAN. The third month in the Hebrew calendar.
SOṬAH (lit. ‘a woman who goes aside’). A wife who is suspected of adultery and undergoes the ordeal of ‘the bitter waters’ (cf. Num. V, 12-31).
SUKKAH (lit. ‘booth’). A wooden structure, roofed with branches and leaves, in which the Israelite was commanded to dwell during the Festival of Tabernacles (Lev. XXIII, 34).
ṬALLITH (lit. ‘covering’). A woollen sheet with ẓiẓith attached to the four corners worn during certain services.
TALMUD (lit. ‘teaching’). A term to denote the Mishnah plus the Germara.
TANNA (pl. -aïm) (lit. ‘one who teaches by repetition’). The Rabbis who are quoted in the Mishnah and Baraithoth.
TARGUM (lit. ‘interpretation in another language’). The Aramaic translation of the Scriptures.
TAW. The twenty-second letter of the Hebrew alphabet, pronounced t.
ṬEBETH. The tenth month in the Hebrew calendar.
TEFILLAH (lit. ‘prayer’). (i) The ‘Amidah; (ii) One section of the Tefillin.
TEFILLIN. Phylacteries.
ṬEREFAH (pl. -foth) (lit. ‘an animal which is torn’). An animal which has a fatal organic disease, or one which has not been properly slaughtered.
TERUMAH (lit. ‘portion of an offering’). The portion of a sacrifice or of the produce which was set aside as the due of the kohen.
TISHRI. The seventh month in the Hebrew calendar.
TORAH (lit. ‘instruction, direction’). (i) The Pentateuch as distinct from the Prophets; (ii) The body of Jewish teaching based on the Scriptures and the oral traditions connected therewith.
WAW. The sixth letter of the Hebrew alphabet, pronounced v or w.
YOD. The tenth letter of the Hebrew alphabet, pronounced y.
YOẒER (lit. ‘former’). The benediction beginning ‘who formest light’ (P.B., p. 37).
ẒADI. The eighteenth letter of the Hebrew alphabet, pronounced ts.
ZAYIN. The seventh letter of the Hebrew alphabet, pronounced z.
ZIMMUN (lit. ‘designation’). The introduction to the Grace after Meals when three or more adult males are present (cf. P.B., pp. 279f).
ẒIẒITH (lit. ‘fringes’). Fringes attached to the corners of a Ṭallith (cf. Num. XV, 38).
ZUGOTH (lit. ‘couples’). Designation of the Nasi’ together with the ’Ab Beth Din.
ZUZ. A coin equivalent to the silver Dinar

chapter.title: AUTHORITIES QUOTED
chapter.p: (Only those authors are included whose works are not specified in the Commentary.)
῾ARUK. Talmudic Dictionary by R. Nathan b. Yeḥiel (11th cent.); edited with additions under the title ‘Aruk Completum by A. Kohut, 1878-1892.
ASHERI. Asher b. Yeḥiel (1250-1328); commentator on the Talmud and Halakist.
BA῾ALË HATTOSAFOTH. Collection of Bible commentaries published in Warsaw, 1889.
BACHRACH, Judah (c. 1775-1846); author of Nimmuḳë Hagrib printed in the Vilna-Romm ed. of the Talmud.
EBEN HA῾EZER. The third section of the Shulḥan ‘Aruk.
EMDEN, Jacob Israel (1697-1776); noted Talmudist. Among his works is ‘Eẓ ’Aboth, a commentary on Pirḳē ’Aboth.
FALK, Joshua b. Isaac (18th cent.); Talmudist, author of Binyan Yehoshua‘, a commentary on ARN and other Minor Tractates.
HALAKOTH GEDOLOTH. Compilation of halakic decisions by Simon Ḳayyara, a Rabbinical authority in the first half of the ninth century.
JASTROW. Talmud Dictionary by M. Jastrow, 1903.
KUNITZER, Moses (died 1837); Hungarian Talmudist and author.
MAḤZOR VIṬRI. Compilation of rules and decisions on religious practice by the French Talmudist Simḥah b. Samuel (died 1105).
MAIMONIDES, Moses (1135-1204). Philosopher and Talmudist. His works include a commentary on the Mishnah.
MEIRI, Menaḥem b. Solomon (1249-1306); French Talmudist. He wrote a commentary on Pirḳë ‘Aboth.
MEKILTHA. Midrash on Exodus (from chap. XII) of uncertain authorship; originated in the School of R. Ishmael (1st and 2nd cent.) and compiled a century later.
MENORATH HAMMA’OR. Ethical treatise based on Rabbinical material, written by Isaac Aboab, a Spanish Talmudist, in the fourteenth century.
MIDRASH AGADAH. Compilation of Rabbinical expositions of the Pentateuch, ed. from a unique MS. by S. Buber who assigns it to the sixteenth century.

MIDRASH RABBAH. The most important collection of Rabbinical comments on the Pentateuch and the five Megilloth. The section on Genesis is the oldest and originated about the middle of the fifth century.
NAḤMANIDES, Moses (1194-c. 1270). Commentator on the Pentateuch and on some Talmud tractates.
NISSIM, Rabbenu. African Talmudist of the eleventh century; author of “Key to the Locks of the Talmud”.
ORAḤ ḤAYYIM. The first section of the Shulḥan ‘Aruk.

OTHIOTH D’RABBI ‘AḲIBA. A Midrash in two versions on the names of the letters of the Hebrew alphabet which claims to have been written by R. ‘Aḳiba. The authorship is unknown, and the work originated about the eighth century.
OẒAR YISRAEL. A Jewish encyclopedia in Hebrew, ed. J. D. Eisenstein.
PESIḲTHA RABBATHI. Collection of homilies mainly on the Hafṭaroth of some of the Festivals and special Sabbaths, dating from the middle of the ninth century.
PIRḲË D’RABBI ELIEZER. A Midrashic work on Genesis and part of Exodus, compiled in Italy early in the ninth century. The author is unknown.
PSEUDO-JONATHAN. Aramaic translation of the Pentateuch, distinct from that of ’Onḳelos, known as the Jerusalem Targum, incorrectly ascribed to Jonathan b. Uzziel, a disciple of Hillel.
RASHI. Initials of R. Solomon Yitzḥaḳi (1040-1105). The greatest commentator of the Bible and Talmud.
SHULḤAN ‘ARUK. Codification of Jewish law compiled by Joseph Caro (1488-1575).
SIFRA. Rabbinical commentary on Leviticus, originating in the School of R. ‘Aḳiba and ed. by R. Ḥiyya (3rd-4th cent.).
SIFRË. Rabbinical commentary on Numbers and Deuteronomy. The former belongs to the School of R. Ishmael and the latter to the School of R. ‘Aḳiba.
SIFRË DI AGGADETHA. A collection of short Midrashim on Esther, ed. S. Buber, 1886.
TANḤUMA. Collection of homiletical interpretations of the Pentateuch compiled in the fifth century.
TOSAFISTS. Authors of the Tosafoth.
TOSAFOTH. Annotations on the Talmud by glossarists mainly in France of the twelfth and thirteenth centuries.
TOSIFTHA. A collection of Baraithoth amplifying the Mishnah, redacted from compendia written by R. Ḥiyya b. Abba and Hoshaiah (3rd and 4th cent.) with additions from later ’Amoraïm.
TUMMATH YESHARIM. A collection of Rabbinical works, including a commentary on ARN, by Benjamin b. Abraham Motal of Constantinople (17th cent.).
ṬUR. One of the sections of ’Arba‘ah Ṭurim, a code of Jewish law, by Jacob b. Asher (1269-1343).
YALḲUṬ (SHIM‘ONI). Collection of Rabbinical comments on the entire Bible from older sources; compiled probably in the early part of the thirteenth century.
YOREH DE῾AH. The second section of the Shulḥan ‘Aruk.
ZOHAR. A cabbalistic commentary on the Pentateuch attributed to R. Simeon b. Yoḥai (2nd cent.) but now generally believed to have been written by Moses de Leon of Granada (13th cent.).
